column10: I need an Ori II game now!!!!

This game is a masterpiece, a benchmark for it's category. Enough said. 

If you loved Ori and The Blind Forest, this game is a must have. 
It's hard to think of a better platformer.

Everything is made perfectly. Graphics are insanely beautiful, amazing soundtrack, amazing gameplay, it's very hard to master (prepare to be pissed off sometimes), but in the end, it's all worth. 

I almost died at the end, it's simply perfect. 

No other a game made me cry like an idiot. This one has...

Just buy it. It's worth every coin. 
It is the one of the best games ever made.

A great sequel to an amazing game. The polished movement, the addition of fun bosses and the visuals and the overall vibe of this game is very beautiful. The story is easy to follow and pull at your heartstrings. This is my second time getting the game and I've already played countless hours on this before now. I've replayed bosses, did speed runs and challenged myself to complete the game in different ways. If I was to say what my favourite game of all time was, it would be this series.

Will of the Wisps is beautiful to behold and experience in motion. One of the best feeling and looking games I have ever played. The Ori series is videogame excellence and a top class Platformer/ Metroidvania.
Amazing game. Very beautiful, fun and smooth mechanics and the story was well told.
amazing game

This game is truly a piece of art. 
I love metroidvanias. I've played quite a few and I love the genre. Ori and the Will of the Wisps is simply just one of the best games I've ever played and one of the best metroidvanias I've ever played. I have to say, what puts this game apart from the competition is the music. The music in this game is unbelievably good. Throughout the whole game, it is well written and expertly conveys the emotion and tone of events/areas. Besides the music, I have to say that this game does everything else just so right as well. The storybuilding, the environments that are so unique and just flow together, the sound design, the gameplay and controls. There is just something so special and so refined about this game.
If you somehow haven't elected to buy and play this game yet. Seriously do. If you haven't played Ori and the Blind Forest, do that first, even. I will gush about how good this game is, and I believe a lot of that is built off of the foundation that is the previous game. Plus, having played the previous game, you will be a lot more familiar with the world and characters which is a nice thing to have going into this game.
Seriously, play this. Seriously, play Blind Forest. And seriously, thank you so much to Moon studios for these incredible games. I hope so much that more content comes to this franchise. If not, what we already have is spectacular.
it's just a great game

One of the best metroidvanias. The game has a very large and beautiful world with a lot of additional tasks and items to collect. The storyline in the game is also very good. If you like games of this genre, then you should definitely play this game

Oh my god, this game is different. Minus the amazing art style, platforming and storyline, there really isn't much that can be compared between this game and Blind Forest. The combat is different, the health and energy systems work different, the abilities you get from the spirit trees are... actually mostly the same but still a little different, the savepoint system is different, literally EVERYTHING is different and I love it so much. If you like Blind Forest, you'll like Will of the Wisps.

If I had to put it simply: it's beautiful game.Not quite "The Perfect Metroidvania" that the devs claimed it would be, but a great game nonetheless. 
The art and music are the best part of the game for me. I really wish, they'd give us a photo mode in this game, just so i can take screenshots of all the pretty sceneries. They really improved on art in this game, because all locations don't look empty anymore, and each area actually looks unique, rather than just being a recolor of any other one.

As for gameplay, despite them clearly improving the combat system a lot, platforming still is this game's stronger side. My favourite two abilities are still Bash and Launch, as they feel the most unique and are really fun (and usefull) in combat. What i don't like are the Grapling Hook and the Spirit Light. The Hook is insanely inconsistent in how it works and i've messed up many parkours because of it. Spirit Light just goes against the game's design in general. Not only is it very slow to deploy and hard to aim, which goes against everything else focusing on fast-paced combat and movement, but it also kinda ruins the point of bash.(And you can use it to cheese certain platforming section).

As for combat,the system was absolutely improved. I would argue it's one of the best ones out there. The problem is similar to the first game, where you don't have enough stuff to fight. There are only 5 boss fights in the game and half of them happen before you get any abilities unlocked. Another thing i don't like is how the animation and artstyle ruin a lot of fights. Enemies either need an extremely basic attack kit, or they have too many different animations to be sightreadable.
This is especially true for bosses. Other than that i do geniuenly love the system and how it let's you change your tools on the fly.

Overall, if you like fast-paced platforming than this game is for you.

Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a fantastic beautiful 2d metroidvania platformer with challenging gameplay.
Its art style gets you really sat in the games world. While it has a very diverse color palette, it doesn‚Äôt scream at your eyes and make them bleed. From the water to sand everything is so vibrant a full of life it makes you question if there‚Äôs more to the silly little world of Ori. The characters are all wonderfully designed while not being over the top. The main character is literally a white cat thing and nothing else. But its far from simplistic. Theres so much attention to detail that it offently leaves me confused they only needed 5 years to complete this masterpiece of a bob ross painting. And its not just my opinion. The whole community and players outside of it has stated that its one of the most articulated and wonderful pieces of work they‚Äôve seen. It might as well be used as the definition for eye candy. But its not just the artstyle that‚Äôs good. Far from it infact. My personal favorite mechanic of this game is the movement. As I stated before the game is a 2d platformer. Its movement is very floaty and light which is perfect for a 2d platformer. Meanwhile the floaty movement is good what really makes the movement good is the skills you get. I wont get into detail of what those skills are so you can enjoy the game yourself. But the skills only serve to compliment the already extremely good movement. You have to think while moving around which just makes it even more fun because you have to strategies. And when it comes to combat the movement helps it to become so much more fun then it already is. Which brings me to the next part of the review. The combat. The combat is incredibly diverse with you needing to collect charms that help you unlock upgrades to specific abilities. Theres so much creative stuff you can focus on. And the more you play the game the more your creativity can get because as you progress the more charms you can have on. Unlike the first game in the series. The sequel bring a much more diverse and fun gameplay experience. And what I really like that this game does is you needing specific upgrades to unlock different areas. But what‚Äôs even better about those upgrades is they aren‚Äôt only used to explore the giant and beautiful map. they‚Äôre also there to serve as combat abilities. Talking about the map its so big and diverse in themes. I cant go into detail to much because I want u to explore yourself but theres so many little secrets and areas to explore. But the map isn‚Äôt really that confusing at all. The enemys and abilities only help to bring more life to the surroundings. Enemys are also a really great thing in this game. While they aren‚Äôt to hard they aren‚Äôt to easy. Sure if theres one youll have no problem but if thers 3 or 4 youll have a fun challenge. And the game doesn‚Äôt overload you with these enemys. They are very balanced and don‚Äôt need some overely complicated plan to kill. Meanwhile the bosses are a real challenge but not in annoying ‚Äúmeant to be hard‚Äù kind of way. They are balanced but still extremely hard. I only really didn‚Äôt have a fun time at the 3rd boss but that was just me having ‚Äúskill issue‚Äù. And the bosses designs are so brilliant and  fit their respective areas so well. Same goes for all the little npcs around the map that gives out little side quest that aren‚Äôt hard at all. And the npcs are so lively it feels like im actually helping someone whenever I finish their quest. The same goes for all the shop keepers or other npcs that aren‚Äôt quest npcs. The achievements in this game are brutal. But that isn‚Äôt really a bad thing. The achievements in this game are very fun to complete and not something u have to do to make the story feel completed.
Talking about the story its very good. The world building it sets up for you is amazing. Although it could have been better im happy with how it is. The game doesn‚Äôt feel to fast or to slow. Sure it can take a while to beat but you‚Äôll never have a ‚ÄúOh my god when does it end‚Äù moment. You‚Äôll probably be stuck at one of the puzzles but it‚Äôll only take 10 minutes to figure out. And the way they set up the puzzles isn‚Äôt just to throw them in there. The puzzles fit so well with environment its like you have to do these things to progress and not just ‚ÄúOh this is a puzzle that I need to complete‚Äù and I think that‚Äôs so impressive.  Ori is a amazing game that takes my breath away every chance it gets. I hope to dear god you play it because it would be a shame if u missed such an amazing experience.

This game is what most sequels should be.  Upgrades and revolutionizes every aspect of the first game, and doubles the playable content.  The way the game's progression flows so seamlessly (unless I got stuck on account of me being bad/impatient) together made it so entertaining that I even went and got all the collectibles in my first play through.  The way secrets become naturally accessible as you progress the story makes you want to collect them without even considering it.  It's perfect.  Also the music bangs, the visuals are insane, and besides the final boss fight I found most of the fights/chase sequences visually readable, which was great because I never focused specifically on how to progress a fight as I die over and over again during a specific sequence, I was just in the zone.

I‚Äôm usually very bad at metroidvanias so tend to avoid them, but this one is incredible.

It‚Äôs beautiful, the music is stunning, and the gameplay extremely rewarding ( it‚Äôs fun !), with interesting new abilities unlocking new areas. What‚Äôs quite remarkable is that the difficulty is well adjusted ( this is no hollow knight!), you never get lost thanks to the excellent level design, and you keep exploring just because you want to see more of it. To some extent, it reminds me of an open world game - the driving force ( curiosity) being the same.

Buy this game, you‚Äôre in for a treat.

First game was great - controls movements and enemy waves are just obnoxious and repetitive while punishing you to restart the wave of enemies in an area. Added a bunch of manure mechanics to turn it into a poor man's Hollow Knight, don't waste your money.

This game improves on the first one in almost every way possible. Combat is much more responsive and satisfying, with a much more customizable skills system. It uses a much forgiving auto save versus the first's manual save only. The story feels much more personally motivated now and some tasks appear to be doable in different orders. [spoiler]And a sad but fulfilling ending to Ori's story.[/spoiler] This game just manages to take what made the first one good and make it better.

[h3] Ori and the Will of the Wisps - An absolute must have! [/h3]

[b] Pros [/b]
- Great visuals all around
- Heartfelt story with impactful character animations
- Very atmospheric
- It feels as though the environment reacts to your every move
- Absolutely amazing soundtrack
- Satisfying sound effects throughout
- Fast game start-up and loading time (19 seconds total)
- No crashes and almost no bugs/glitches
- Comprehensive character stats are available, which I personally very much appreciate
- Plenty of side quests and achievements to keep you busy for awhile

[b] Cons [/b]
- Getting to some of the rare items can be frustrating at times. 
- The tutorial doesn't cover some aspects such as purple walls, but that's nothing a bit of YT can't fix. Edit: a LOT of Youtube vids, as there are plenty of "secrets" in the game :)
- Game was built using a proprietary game engine from a untrustworthy company.

Ori 2 is a great Metroidvania whith it's focus on platforming, movement and generel atmosphere. 
As a sequel it tries some new things but mostly sticks to what the first game implemented and improves them. 
So if you liked the first, it's the same but bigger and improved!

Graphics, music and platforming are it's strong suit.
The movement is incredibly fluid and the whole game brims with atmosphere.
While the combat is hugely improved compared to the first game it's not the games strongest suit either. 
The story is good, at least the how the whole game feels alive and vibrating with a lot of background work from visuals and such. The actual story around Ori could have been better or well more world building involving their story since it's hinted at points.   

+ Fun platforming and movement with intersting skills to traverse levels
+ Graphics, atmosphere, visual desing in genreal are amaizing 
+ Music
+ Nice power progression curve - both movement and combat

- Combat feels a bit lackluster. Bosses often have werid  and frustrating hit boxes 
- The story is a bit bare-bones and predictable, sad scenes don't hit hard because you kinda know what and how it will happen
- More world building around Ori, the spirits, the decay and the world  as a whole would be nice
- The auto save feature is a step back from 1 where you clold make you own save spots

If you like platforming, Metroidvanias and a visually very appealing game then I can recommend Ori 2 despite it's few flaws!

Really pushes tedium to the limit.  Some boss fights, the last one _especailly_, pushes their platforming design well past what it was designed for.  Games can be hard, but killing your players with bad telegraphing, changing telegraphs mid-fight, showing a boss health bar when they can't be damaged when previously they hid it, shockingly hard hitting attacks and unavoidable environmental damage are just bad design.

Really disappointing that they got too big for their britches and pushed out this garbage.  Only buy it if you're okay with never finishing a game because the designers hate you.  They took a hard left into just grief for grief's sake, at least the original game had sympathetic enemies.  This one's enemies are bad guys who are bad because they're bad, with no redemption.  You don't have to have sad writing, games are allowed to be happy.  The ending is such a letdown, even with the big reveal.  I don't care at all about these enemy characters like I did the first time around.

This game missed the mark in the same way Doom Eternal did for me. A extremely promising sequel that took significant ludic influence from outside itself, and in the process compromised what made the previous game good.

THIS DOES NOT MEAN I THINK WOTW OR DOOM ETERNAL ARE INHERENTLY BAD. THEY'RE BOTH COMPETENT GAMES BY CAPABLE DEVELOPERS AND THE FACT I HAVE TO SAY THIS IS INDICATIVE OF A LARGER PROBLEM WITH RABID FANS.

The game itself is... fine. Nothing in the game is egregious enough to have me outright say it's a 'bad game'. I didn't encounter any glaring bugs or major performance issues.

BUT, and this is two massive, jiggling, face-destroying cheeks worth of BUT... it's not a good sequel to Blind Forest. It doesn't improve on the first game, rather it wipes away most of the unique takes (i.e. movement over combat, save-anywhere, etc.) and pastes Hollow Knight on top, to... middling success.

Blind Forest was *not heavily focused on combat.* And that felt perfect! The levels play to the games strengths, and the platforming and movement "flow" carries the gameplay very well.
It frustrates me to no end that Moon Studios removed the unique (and *fun*) low-combat-high-movement focus in favor of a by-the-books metroidvania (read: Hollow Knight) combat system, sacrificing many opportunities for the chase sequences that made the first game truly unique, while not adding enough back in to make this another unique experience.

I understand that having animals inhabit the environment and interact with Ori makes sense, but lord it's just MORE Hollow Knight again. Map dude who sits in a specific spot then f*cks off, merchants for buying new weapons that you'll never use because there are like 15 different enemies, quests because sure, charms... Okay I admit I do like the charm system, that's neat, but it's STILL Hollow Knight.

Ori is not Hollow Knight. I don't care how good you think Hollow Knight was, it spoiled any chance Blind Forest had of getting a true sequel, as Doom Eternal did with Doom 2016.

For the obvious good parts: Visuals are great. Soundtrack is great. Chase sequences, where they still exist, are still phenomenal. The powers, new and returning (Bash, Dig, etc.), are all interesting.

But it pisses me off that they were so willing to copycat another franchise, as if there's nothing left to be explored of the previous direction.

And possibly the worst part is: they actively deny they took cues from Hollow Knight. For the love of all that is good on this godforsaken Earth, at least admit you were *inspired* by it.

Summary:
"Ori and the Will of the Wisps" is a critically acclaimed action-adventure platformer video game developed by Moon Studios. It is the sequel to "Ori and the Blind Forest." The game follows the emotional journey of Ori, a guardian spirit, as they navigate through a visually stunning, hand-drawn world filled with challenging platforming sequences and engaging puzzles.

The storyline revolves around Ori's quest to save their adopted family and the mysterious, enchanting forest of Niwen from impending doom. Throughout the game, players encounter various characters, unlock new abilities, and face formidable enemies. The gameplay emphasizes precise platforming, fluid movement, and a heartfelt narrative that explores themes of friendship, sacrifice, and the enduring spirit of hope.

"Ori and the Will of the Wisps" received praise for its beautiful art style, emotionally resonant storytelling, and tight gameplay mechanics. It is celebrated for successfully blending challenging platforming elements with an emotionally rich narrative, creating a captivating and immersive gaming experience.

A gorgeous, impeccably well designed Metroidvania platformer. This followup to "Ori and the Blind Forest" is better in possibly every way and sets a gold standard for narrative platform gaming. It's got beautiful art, vibrant level design, a fully orchestral score, the works. It feels like you're playing a lost Pixar movie (including the schmaltzy story) and you're missing out on a classic if you skip this one.

Pros:
- Platforming and movement are masterclass in design. Smooth and snappy. Controls like a dream.
- Probably the best looking platformer out there. Looks incredible at 1440p and 60+ framerate.
- Some of the best character animation out there. Truly outstanding work here. 
- Movement abilities are fun and varied.
- Tons of secrets and collectibles without being overwhelming.

Cons:
- Combat is better but still not great and many combat abilities are borderline worthless. Spam X to win.
- Bosses can look great but don't offer much challenge.
- Forward path can be a little obtuse at times, backtracking can be a chore.
- Lots of particle effects and detail can obscure puzzle clues (like levers) or confuse platforming (teleporters are especially a problem).
- Story can be corny and overly predictable at times. Really sappy stuff.

I am sad and disappointed.

tl;dr Great game, everyone should play it.

Better than the original game in almost every way, improving on most of my criticisms for Blind Forest. Yet it also lost a bit of uniqueness with that.

Improvements:
- even prettier with new graphics
- environment looks more vibrant and visually simpler to distinct
- you get decent traversal much earlier and aren't put through artificial suffering
- old save system where you "paid" for checkpoints with energy is gone and replaced with banal set checkpoints around the levels (which is still good, old system was a pain)
- ending is much better
- bosses and combat overall are done very differently and are actually good
- escape sequences still suck, but not as much
- MKB controls are much better (except for stupid sand dash, what the heck were you thinking devs)

Mild criticisms:
- lost opportunity to make serious side-challenges for the new combat - not much use getting good at fighting honestly
- level design quality is much better overall, but seemingly went too far from "too annoying" to "too simple" - again, except for the sand area that feels like it belongs in the first game

Will of the Wisps does everything right. Takes what was great about the Blind Forest and enhances it to a whole new level: the visuals, the sounds, the music, the story, the gameplay mechanics, everything.

The world is much bigger, feels much more alive, is incredibly detailed and versatile, and the story is touching and brilliant.

Gameplay wise, it's a much more fun and richer experience ‚Äî with a whole new set of skills and ways to unlock and enhance them, you'll feel much more powerful than what you felt in the Blind Forest. 

The level design is genius as always, without being overly complicated. It just makes you contemplate the cleverness on the crafting of this game.

An absolutely beautiful game. It has a touching story, the environments and backgrounds are drop-dead gorgeous, friendly critters are cute while the enemies are menacing or grotesque, soundtrack is relaxing and it has an amazing tranquil, but slightly dark atmosphere.
Gameplay doesn't lag behind at all either. Controls are responsive and smooth. Ori is super swift and nimble, so once you acquire more abilities the movement and combat are some of the most satisfying I have experienced in a 2D game.
Level design is neat, there are a lot of nooks and crannies to explore and certain amount of back tracking necessary, but it is not too complex and areas are easily visually distinguishable. On top of that, the map is fairly helpful and you have clear goals, so navigation is fine even if you are not well versed with the genre. Each zone has its own gimmicks and the world changes as you progress through the story, so it doesn't lose momentum.
Do not be fooled by the vibrant visuals and serene atmosphere - Ori still has challenging platforming parts, intense chase sections, boss fights and spirit trials. It can be a little difficult to distinguish everything on your screen when fighting several enemies at once during the combat trials due to all the colors, effects and high speed of the game though.

I regard Ori and the Will of the Wisps as beauty itself; why, watching its trailer alone is enough to stir one's heart. For this game, arts are of equal importance as gameplay itself. It is narrated alongside evocative, euphonic soundtrack‚Äîa symphonic suite, really‚Äîand rendered in a colourful art style full of contrast and light. It combines both realism (e.g. of foliage, rocks, bark, and mushrooms) with fantastic elements, giving off the impression of an enchanted, moving canvas.

Is Ori and the Will of the Wisps challenging? It is entirely possible to play through this game leisurely and without significant challenge as there are multiple modes of difficulty to choose from. They vary in damage values and the cost of purchasable abilities. Ori and the Will of the Wisps is noticeably easier than its predecessor: self-regeneration, powerful abilities, and fewer one-shot mechanics all lessen the risk of death. On other hand, escape sequences had been replaced by boss fights, although they greatly differ in difficulty.

Many new and interesting mechanics had been added: Grapple, Launch, Water Dash, or Spirit Edge elevated combat to a faster and more fluid experience. Controls feel responsive, so moving around feels satisfying, solving puzzles and defeating enemies gratifying.

What we have here is genre-defining platformer, rightfully so. While it may have borrowed ideas from the likes of Hollow Knight, its artistic vision remains wholly unique, uncompromised; its systems sophisticated and dynamic. Aside from Ori and the Blind Forest, there is no other platformer like this.

The first Ori game was pretty underwhelming and felt very overrated, so I went into Ori and the Will of the Wisps with somewhat low expectations. Thankfully, this game improves and fixes all my issues with the first game, with the 2 biggest improvements are the level design and the combat.

To start with the level design, the first game was fine. It was super linear and some of the levels felt frustratingly random. There is nothing wrong with linear, its just not what I expect in a metroidvania. Fortunately, this games level design is a less linear, which gave me a much greater sense of exploration. Unlike the first game, I did find my self backtracking to get to new areas using new powerups, which was nice. I also found a lot more secrets in this game, but I‚Äôm not sure if that is because there are more secrets in this one, or just that they were made easier to find. The annoying levels and areas from the first game seem to be nonexistent in this one.

The combat is the next massive improvement. The first games combat was pretty bad, spam-y, and auto targeted. There wasn‚Äôt really any skill involved and it just felt annoying. This game has a proper combat system with several attack types. It feels good and is such a big upgrade from the first game.

In addition to those changes, there are a lot of small changes that make the game feel better. The graphics are nicer, the checkpoint system is much improved, the game is longer, the game has side quests now, there are more upgrades now, abilities feel better, and probably a few more I‚Äôm forgetting.

On the downside, starting the game without most of the abilities unlocked in the first game felt a bit annoying, but it does not take too long to get many of them back. I also had some stutters in certain areas when playing on my Steam Deck, but it really was only a small handful.

Overall, Ori and the Will of the Wisps is really great.

Ori and the Will of the Wisps, the highly anticipated sequel to Ori and the Blind Forest, surpasses all expectations with its breathtaking visuals, emotionally charged storytelling, and refined gameplay mechanics. Moon Studios has crafted a masterpiece that not only builds upon the strengths of its predecessor but also introduces new elements that elevate the entire experience.

Visually, Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a work of art. The hand-drawn environments are stunningly detailed, creating a mesmerizing world that seamlessly blends beauty and danger. From lush forests to desolate deserts, each area feels distinct and alive. The use of lighting and particle effects enhances the atmosphere, making every frame a visual spectacle.

The narrative is equally compelling, weaving a heartfelt tale of friendship, loss, and resilience. Ori's emotional journey is complemented by a cast of endearing characters, each with their own struggles and stories. The game effortlessly tugs at the player's heartstrings, delivering poignant moments that resonate long after the credits roll.

Gameplay mechanics have seen significant improvements, offering a perfect balance of challenging platforming and satisfying combat. Ori's expanded move set feels intuitive, empowering players to navigate the world with precision and grace. The introduction of new abilities keeps the gameplay fresh and exciting, while the variety of enemies and bosses present formidable challenges that require skillful mastery.

The soundtrack, composed by Gareth Coker, is a true standout, enhancing the emotional impact of the story. The music seamlessly integrates with the gameplay, creating a harmonious experience that immerses players in the magical world of Ori. The combination of visuals, storytelling, and music forms a cohesive trifecta that elevates the game to a level of artistic brilliance.

While Ori and the Will of the Wisps is an exceptional game, it's not without a few minor flaws. Some players may encounter occasional frame rate drops or minor bugs, but these issues are overshadowed by the overall polish and excellence of the game.

In conclusion, Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a triumph in every aspect. Its captivating world, emotionally resonant story, and refined gameplay make it a must-play for fans of the genre and newcomers alike. Moon Studios has not only delivered a worthy successor but has also set a new standard for the metroidvania genre. Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a shining example of the potential of video games as a form of art.

I do not envy Moon Studios.  It must be so daunting to follow up on a game as incredible as Ori and the Blind Forest.  I fully support the route they took, which is basically more of the same, with some slight tweaks, and combat completely overhauled.

Ori2 is still a metroidvania.  The graphics are still amazing.  The animation is still incredibly fluid, and controlling Ori still feels great.  The new combat is fantastic, it really adds another layer to the game.  

Ori 2 was always going to have a tough time following up the original, in terms of plot and feels.  The first one is just so... tight.  Ori 2 begins right where the previous game left off.  Events take you to a new place, and you have a new adventure.  Ori is still a heartfelt, wonderful journey, but it has trouble reaching the high highs of the original.  Additionally, sometimes while you are playing, it feels like you are re-living the first Ori games greatest hits, rather than playing something new.  

Any complaints I have are merely nitpicking.  Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a fantastic game and a worthy heir to the original.   Once again I was totally blown away by the work of Moon Studios.

Pros:
- a story that engages you straight away and keeps you engaged
- beautiful visuals 
- diverse zones with different challenges
- easy to learn, hard to master
- some excellent set pieces and cut-scenes
- charm and likeability

Cons
- frustrating if you don't know where to find something needed to progress. This happened more than once. It was needless and annoying. I resorted to a guide three or four times, which I really don't like to do. But I don't like wasting my time searching for needles in haystacks, either. 
- often challenging in the wrong way. You know what to do (a certain series of jumps, say, or projectile re-directions), but actually doing it is really grindy and time-consuming and not at all fun. In the end, this happened one time too many. I quit the game and uninstalled it there and then. Shame, because it ultimately is a good game. 

I'm recommending it with caution. There's a ton to like, but there are also things to dislike, annoying things, which become more annoying the more you play.

Ori and the Will of the Wisps is another visual treat of a Metroidvania bringing a lot of improvements over it's previous entry such as overhauled combat, a skill system, and more varied map.

Ori's second outing borrows a lot from other Metroidvanias of recent years to improve upon the original. In particular Ori 2 adds skills, similar to Hollow Knight's charm system, where you can pick and choose certain bonuses, abilities, and/or buffs to Ori. The combat has had a complete rework compared to the previous entry. You know wield a melee weapon, that coupled with positioning and direction inputs makes for more engaging combat encounters.  

Just like the original, the highlight of the game is the visual and audio art. The game's look is a major improvement over it's predecessor, mostly due to it's better lighting. An issue I had with the original was how some foreground and background elements blended in too much. That is not an issue in this entry; As part of the combat overhaul, it looks like there was extra care to make sure enemies and their actions can be recognized easier. 

Ori tells a great story in the new land of Niwen. This time around there are more NPCs to interact with throughout your journey, even going the route of having a "home-base" in the middle of the map. This entry is somehow even more emotional than the first and is masterful in the way it tells it's story through set-piece and quiet moments alike. 

Ori 2 stumbles in some of the same areas as the original. The map design feels very similar, possibly with even more hand holding than before. Another complaint is that the power-ups don't feel as impactful as before. New abilities either supersede previous ones or are more one-off, only used in specific environments. I would have liked to see more varied abilities.

Overall, great game. One of the most artistic platformers I've played.
Game's a work of art with fun platforming and combat as well as a beautiful story

Probably one of the best 2D games I've ever played.  If you enjoyed games like Commander Keen back in the day, you'll absolutely love this.  Game play and problem-solving shines in this one.  Story itself is good, but again the game play is where this excels.  And the fast paced escape action scenes, which is what I'll call them, are intense and require very fast thinking/acting.  I definitely recommend using a controller.  I bought this game during a sale, never heard of it and bought based on pretty much the reviews alone, and can say I loved this game.  Took me a little over 20 hours, and it was a blast.  Highly recommend.

Ori and the Will of the Wisps is nothing short of a breathtaking masterpiece that not only lives up to its predecessor but surpasses it in every conceivable way. Moon Studios has once again woven a captivating tale set in the enchanting world of Ori, combining stunning visuals, emotional storytelling, and impeccable gameplay to create an unforgettable gaming experience.

This game is a shining example of what video games can achieve when all its elements come together harmoniously. It's not just a game; it's an emotional journey, a visual spectacle, and a testament to the artistry of game development. Whether you're a fan of platformers, captivating narratives, or simply appreciate the beauty of gaming, Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a must-play that sets a new standard for the genre.

Great Metroidvania and successor to the Blind Forest. 

Lore/Storytelling: Similar thing in this game compared to the Blind Forest in that the lore is simple and easy to understand, but quite compelling in a sense. Although I would have liked it more if the lore had some more depth (i.e. backstories for individuals for instance, or more history about the past in general). Other than that, the lore is understandable and nice! 7.5/10

Art/Design: No complains here once again! The game retains the same compelling art and design features as the Blind Forest, however it steps it up a notch. Everything is bright and decently colorful, while remaining easy to tell things apart (Foreground vs Background). I would say that the game's main feature is in the design of the game itself, which is why I would rank it a 10/10.

Gameplay: For starters, the game-play has seen improvement from the Blind Forest, however not everything has been fixed. Highlighting some things that have changed: Improved wall climbing physics, improved clarity, added difficulty (Bosses included, still kinda janky), Longer play through length (>10h), Overall better mechanics and ability system. Talking about the bad things, I did not enjoy the system of charms and hearts/energy. The charms seemed very weird and does not allow for any real combinations or big improvements (i.e. Hollow Knight does this VERY WELL). Moreover, the system for energy and life cells seemed a little too easy for me. For instance, by the time I made it to the end of the game (which includes a fun boss fight!), I could easily tank everything in my path without any worry. TLDR: Gameplay needs to be harder and more sophisticated, however it is still a big improvement from the Blind Forest. This results in an overall 7/10

Final ranking is a 8/10, would recommend.

Ori and the Will of the Wisps is an incredible metroidvania. It's definitely much better than the Blind Forest...in almost every single way. The combat feels way more satisfying and controlled, and I love how you get more weapons and attacks as the game progresses. Also, the exploration is a huge step up from the original game, where the endlessly annoying Sein is always telling you where to go--meaning you don't really get a chance to explore at all. But now the map is bigger, and fortunately Sein doesn't exist to show you the way you're supposed to go. Another amazing change in the sequel is the addition of boss fights, which just didn't exit in Ori and the Blind Forest. The art and music was never a problem in the franchise, but I'm glad to see they're keeping the beautiful and stunning art style.

Overall, I give Will of the Wisps a 10/10. I'll even say it could be on par with the masterpiece that is Hollow Knight.
It's not that I hate Ori and the Blind Forest, it's just that it was a little too linear and the combat was mid in my opinion. (I would give that game a 7/10 or an 8/10.)

Pros:
- great level design and great movement abilities. 
- incredibly satisfying fluid movement for both the combat and especially the platforming.
- Music and visuals is GODLIKE. Absolutely beautiful. Music is used perfectly. Every area for me is memorable, and I don't think I ever thought of disliking one.
- Story is simple, but nice. No in-depth lore that is hidden away like in soulslikes. The story is given to you right away. The story is nice and simple, easy to understand, and incredibly satisfying all the way through.
- Sidequests aren't hard or require unecessary reused backtracking.
- Map is well-designed and it's very hard to get lost.
- Character designs are on point and memorable. The world is MUCH more lively than the forest of Nibel.

Opinions / Cons:

I don't have many bad things to say about this game. It was delightful all the way through.

- Game is quite short (around 11 hours). I did every sidequest, collected all spirit shards, abilities, health and energy upgrades on hard mode without online guides. However, dong a platinum might take some significant effort due to the achievements wanting handicaps. I personally think it's harder to platinum ori than elden ring or hollow knight. The length of this game isn't a con, I actually like that they didn't do unnecessary padding.
- Combat feels underutilized. There are very few bosses and enemy types for the amount of abilities ori has. The few combat encounters the game does have are incredibly satisfying. The combat still adds a lot of depth to game though.
- Collecting the spirit lights around the map are a hassle (only for competitionists)
- There are some parts of the game where the UI will bug out. I collected an Ore and died after, but my UI still said I had it. When I restarted the game, then it told me the missing ore locations.
Everything a sequel should be. It's improves on the original in every way which is scarcely believable in itself. A true work of art.

Just like the first game, Ori and the Will of the Wisps excels at being a great platformer with its exceptional art style and OST. However, this one also achieves to be a good metroidvania unlike the previous game in which there was a great lack of abilities and a very limited world with not much to do. This game on the other hand, solves all the problems the previous game had as a metroidvania. It has a big map to explore, has a great number of abilities to play around with, and of course it also has a good combat system with enough depth to satisfy most players unlike the previous game in which all you could do was to left click as fast as you can. In the end, both games are great but Ori and the Will of the Wisps is even greater and achieves to be an amazing sequel to an arguably already good game

The pros:

If you've played Ori and the Blind Forest you should notice a considerable upgrade regarding, mainly, to the gameplay mechanics. Now you choose the weapons you use and the combination of weapons. The graphics are amazing and the soundtrack is just awesome. 

The cons:
There are a lot of weapons, skills, and such, that can be overwhelming for some players. But If you'll spend some time choosing the right weapons, abilities and skill upgrades that fit to your battling style, this aspect may not be  an issue for you, but a pro.

Blind Forest itself was amazing, but Will of the Wisps goes even further. They made everything that made the first title great, and made it so much better. The movement was wonderful, and I had a blast diving in and out of Luma Pools.

If you liked The Blind Forest and Hollow Knight, this game will take you on a ride.

Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a breathtaking masterpiece that surpasses its predecessor in every aspect. Moon Studios has crafted an emotionally resonant and visually stunning world, showcasing a meticulous attention to detail in every frame. The game's fluid platforming mechanics and intuitive controls make navigating its lush environments a joy, while the emotionally charged narrative tugs at the heartstrings. The musical score, composed by Gareth Coker, complements the game's atmosphere beautifully, enhancing the emotional impact of every moment. With its captivating storytelling, challenging gameplay, and jaw-dropping visuals, Ori and the Will of the Wisps stands as a shining example of what the platformer genre can achieve, delivering an unforgettable and magical experience for players.

10/10. 

The game is an absolute masterpiece from start to finish. Boss fights are fresh and exciting, with the right amount of challenging. Each environment is realized in extensive, gorgeous detail. The soundtrack, as ever, you'll find staying with you after every play session: its exciting and epic when it needs to be, and delivers the right amount of kicks to the heart too. Gameplay is fluid, responsive and fun. Whenever the game feels like its about to get stale, it throws new challenges at you. The game never lets you settle: it's constantly throwing new mechanics at the player. 

Combat is a step up from Blind Forest, which is a running theme with Will of the Wisps: this game 100% earns its title as a sequel. Whenever somebody asks me what I think a "true sequel" looks like, I will point to Will of the Wisps. Moon Studios have gone hog-wild in this sequel to Blind Forest, taking everything a step up, including even the story. Much like Blind Forest, the story is heartfelt, tragic, beautiful, and most of all, bittersweet. I won't spoil the ending, but I will say this about it: I, as a person, am not easily moved to outward displays of emotion when I play my games. Only a few games that I've played can I boast have actually made me tear up a bit, or take a second to contemplate what I just watched.

Will of the Wisps is now on that list.

What else do you want me to say? If you're reading this review, having the slightest bit of hesitation: don't. Buy this game now. Right now its a whopping $13.18, which imo is a bloody steal. Stop hesitating, get this game and play it. It's an adventure from start to finish, and imo it is Moon Studios' magnum opus. I legit cannot think of a single criticism it's THAT good.

Long review ahead, no spoilers. I've posted a very similar review for the first game (Blind Forest). Ori has become that game for me that I now compare all other games to. I've played it all the way through at least twice at this point and I can easily see myself  playing it through every other year or so. It's just a spectacular game and I'll outline my reasons for saying so below. As of this review I have logged just under 50  hours into Will of the Wisps (about 90 combined with game 1 and 2), have of course played the first one one (Also, you can play Will of the Wisps without playing The Blind Forest and not be confused, although of course I recommend doing both because they're so good) and for reference I play on PC and enjoy other games such as Terraria, Hollow Knight (although I never finished that), Spyro, Gris, and Kena Bridge of Spirits. 

1) Game-play is fantastic. And I mean this in every sense. No where is the game clunky, glitchy, or buggy (at least not in my experience). Movement and platforming are extremely smooth and not frustrating (when it was frustrating it was only a skill issue not a game issue). You progressively learn more skills that you can mix and match to fit your play-style and different combat situations (I love how they changed the abilities from game one). Combat itself is challenging (and the bosses in Will of the Wisps are admittedly harder) but if you've been playing the way the game teaches you to play and use  your abilities appropriately it's not overly challenging (punishing combat is why I didn't finish Hollow Knight for reference). 

2) Puzzles are just challenging enough and very rewarding. I love puzzles-platformers/games, I love finding secret collectibles and generally enjoy games where the main character is trying to make the world better or fix it from evil. Like the combat, the puzzles can be challenging however if you are learning the skills the game is trying to teach you usually they are self-explanatory and I don't recall having to watch many walkthroughs to figure things out (plus that takes the fun out of it). The Puzzles themselves are training for whatever combat you may need in that level or beyond and I think they do a fantastic job at preparing you for that. As opposed to The Blind Forest, Will of the Wisps has so many more side quests which are completely optional but oh so fun and I've done all of them. It adds so much replay-ability and diversity to an already long game with huge map which means you get to play more Ori. 

3) Like most - if not all - other reviews rave about, the atmosphere is incredible, just as good if not better than Blind Forest and still somehow original even though unique. Again, I mean this in every sense. The emotional story-telling is on point (the ending to this game makes my cry so so much in a great way). The level/map design is superb with every area so distinct and unique, even from Blind Forest. And THE MUSIC. The music is absolutely incredible of course, and it also is unique per section of map which I love it's not just the same music the whole game. The game is so beautiful to look at and play, it's actually not annoying to run around at the end collecting everything and finding hidden places because it's just so pretty (yes, I'm a bit of a completionist and so I had to get that achievementüòÇ). 

I literally could go on and on, but if you're still reading this and haven't purchased/played the game(s) what are you still doing here?

Ori and will of the wisps is a sequel that fixed the mistakes of the first game. It is smooth to control Ori and to the precise jumps it needs. Additions of the shards can make certain platforming sections easier such as glue, or make combat easier for you. You have variety of weapons you can choose from, such as a bow, hammer or a sword.

Oh yeah. They finally added close combat so if a creature is about to it you, you can hit it back instead. 

The progression felt natural and wonderful. The abilities were enhancing your movement abilities, but the level design is done in a way that lack of them does not hinder your ability to move and control Ori at all. What I also love is the addition of double jump right from the get go.

Collectables are mostly optional but it is fun and rewarding to collect them. The health and energy cells surely helps traversing through and other things such as the ore has cute things connected to it such as building your base to look better and better not only giving you the looks but also the possibility to move easily around.

Instead of leveling system they have chosen to do currecy system which I like more as it gives you the flexibility to buy items you want without needing to get unecessary things before. If there is some limitation it is linked to story progression (The monk won't give you unlimited breathing under the water without you unlocking the possibility to swim first) or to the items (You cannot buy upgrades of the weapons or the tools to it before you get the item.) 

You won't have as much troubles collecting the needed currency as there are many things you can do. Sidequests, races, arena's that you can find all over the map without being forced upon you.

And this game finally switched from having to manually save the game to actual autosaves. It might seem like sure thing, but if you have played the first game you would know the terrors of what manual saving was. It was replaced by healing ability which is more favorable for harder platforming sections

My negative that I can see is the fact, that the game tries to have bossfights where it doesn't need to. The wonderful artstyle and soundtrack could carry the game well to just the discovery and chase scenes that the first game had with the better adjusments to it, but instead they are doing bossfights which seem bit out of place and wonky for this game, that is though small low for the ammount that they made better.

Truly reccomend.

Really great sequel to Ori and the blind forest. It does everything better than the previous game and I like some of the darker tones in this title. The music as you're going thru the spider's nest is absolutely creepy and brilliant. Ori also has one of the best uses of HDR in a video game from my experience, right next to Tetris Effect Connected. 

The lead developer did an interview with Digital Foundry and it was great hearing his thoughts about these games. It's a shame they won't be making any more Ori games but I respect the decision. I've seen too many game series get milked to the point they don't even resemble what made them special anymore. I'll definitely be keeping an eye out for Moon Studio's next project.

A beautiful game and tech-showcase. This runs very well, and is the best PC HDR game I've tried. The story is moving and the score is great. My only complaint is the controls become a bit cluttered and complicated by the end, leading to some frustration, but well worth working through.

I haven't played it much yet tbh. HOWEVER, WOW. It's beautiful. Jumping around takes a few tries, but you can't be mad when it's *this* pleasing to the eye (also it's just nice to hop around for the heck of it). Getting from place to place is not impossible, but for someone like me that really struggles with hitting the right keys/buttons (on keyboard) at the right times- it takes a few tries. That just means I'll have more time to play and enjoy the game. Probably would be easier on a controller as some have stated.
That all being said...the story is also heart-wrenching. Ku is so cute and she needs to be protected at all costs, but also deserves to be happy. 
Seriously though, my mouth fell open at how beautiful it was, I didn't care *that* much when I couldn't climb the tree right away.

As a dedicated 3D animator specializing in environmental design and a fervent gamer, I've experienced many games that blend art with storytelling. Yet, "Ori and the Will of the Wisps" stands out as a shining gem in this regard.

From the moment the game begins, you're immersed in a world so beautifully crafted it feels like stepping into a living painting. The environmental design is nothing short of breathtaking. Every frame of this game could be a work of art, showcasing a mastery of color, lighting, and atmosphere that is a testament to the talent of the game's creators.

The animation is fluid and expressive, breathing life into every character and creature you encounter. As someone who breathes and lives 3D animation, I can't help but admire the attention to detail and the seamless integration of animation with gameplay, making Ori's journey feel both epic and deeply personal.

The storytelling is equally impressive. It's a heartfelt tale that tugs at your emotions, taking you on a rollercoaster of joy, sorrow, and triumph. The narrative is woven seamlessly with the gameplay, ensuring that every leap and every challenge feels meaningful in Ori's journey.

In addition to the stunning visuals and compelling story, the soundtrack deserves a special mention. It complements every moment of the game perfectly, enhancing the emotional depth and the overall experience.

"Ori and the Will of the Wisps" is more than just a game; it's a testament to the power of video games as an art form. It's a masterpiece that resonates with my journey from a solitary child to a cherished community leader, much like Ori's own journey in the game.

Whether you're a gamer, an animator, or just someone who appreciates beautiful storytelling, this game is an absolute must-play. It's not just a game I played; it's an experience I lived and will cherish.

Thank you, Moon Studios, for creating something truly magical.

An incredible sequel that takes everything that was so amazing about Blind Forest and perfects it. The art is utterly gorgeous, the story is beautiful and heartfelt, and the gameplay and combat design are extraordinarily fun. Especially compared to its predecessor, the combat and movement feels incredibly fluid and comfortable, allowing a wide range of playstyles and making boss fights never feel unbeatable, even in hard mode. My favorite aspect of the game is how well it builds and portrays its world and atmosphere - by the end of the game, I felt truly invested in the world, its inhabitants, and the story and history of the forest. Like Hollow Knight, another of my favorite metroidvanias, the world just feels so real, so alive. And I almost forgot to mention - the music (oh my god the music) is PHENOMENAL. Some of the best and most ingeniously utilized music you'll ever find in a game, without a doubt. WotW is most definitely worth the purchase, but I do recommend you play the first game (Ori and the Blind Forest) first! The events in the story are a direct sequel and continuation of the previous game, and while you could technically still get by and understand the story without having played the first game, having that context genuinely makes the world and story so much more impactful.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Historic Review: Games I played months if not years ago ‚Äì I decided to start reviewing right at the end of 2023! Memory of a trepanned, ADHD toddler with impulse control issues notwithstanding.

Teaboy's Basic(ish) Reviews....I read a lot of reviews when looking at games on Steam, and it quickly gets tiring ‚Äì those who write involved, down to the micron scale reviews, although helpful, end up like looking at War & Peace when you‚Äôve only got time for a quick 5 minute dump! This is middle of the road and to the point ‚Äì not easy for me as I tend towards sesquipedalian loquaciousness! Vociferously Verbose? Alright, verbal diarrhoea. (Although I hate panning a developer‚Äôs work and all the time, effort and love they put into designing these ‚Äì it is their life after all ‚Äì this is my honest, personal opinion of my level of enjoyment. Sorry devs!).

A note on time played: My Steam clock does not seem to work properly, indeed, it even minuses time on occasion! Plus, I have a tendency to wander off and leave games running at times, so time played may not be entirely accurate!


Teaboy‚Äôs Tonsil Titillators or Toenail Titbits! (Rating)

Tonsil Tickler (Totally Tops): The frenchy of which you always dreamt! To quote a master, ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs got a tongue like an electric eel and she likes the taste of a Man‚Äôs tonsils!‚Äù. An absolute masterpiece and joy to play.

The Tits (Terrific): Everyone loves playing with these! Not THE best bit, but such fun on their own you can be lost for hours....mmmm. What most games you really like score ‚Äì perfection is so rare after all.

Torso Teaser (Taker of your Time): It‚Äôs a flat stomach....sure it‚Äôs nice to look at, run your fingers over, slobber on a bit, sometimes that bellybutton gets your motor running....but it's just basically the corridor between the two ‚Äògaming rooms‚Äô. The definitive ‚ÄòMeh‚Äô - the middle ‚Äòsideways thumb‚Äô option for which everyone on Steam cries.

Todger/Tadger & (scroTum) Taters (Tedious): Is it an ‚Äòa‚Äô or is it an ‚Äòo‚Äô? Who cares! The meat can be fun to play with for about 5 minutes of your entire day, the rest it just hangs there and generally gets in the way of doing something else. The main problem of course, is the two veg sticking to your inside thigh. This is what this game feels like ‚Äì the occasional/rare bouts of fun, the rest bobbing like a 19th century British Policeman (now you know why!).

Toenail Tornado (Total Toss): A playthrough so appalling it‚Äôs like being trapped in a Turkish sauna with the ugliest, hairiest, fattest, sweatiest beast of a neolithic hominid who‚Äôs trimming his toenails using pliers and the splinters are reminiscent of a scene from the Normandy Landings. My god how did this get released!?


Teaboy Touts (Score): TONSIL TICKLER!!!!!!!!!!!!


The Review:

This is for both Ori And The Blind Forest & Ori And The WIll Of The Wisps (they are effectively the same game).

I think this is my Favourite Game Of All Time - hence the dozen exclamation marks above (my fave number)! When I played the 2nd one, I preferred the 1st, and I Still LOVED IT!

This is an action platformer that is more platformer than combat but plenty of both - unlike things like Blasphemous which to me is just hack n slash. This one requires learning and skill with a bit of timing to boot. Both games have the same controls and movements and map type and controls. The differences are obviously a different map (same layout format) and a change in the skill progression. In the 2nd game you purchase upgrades from a couple of creatures and you have to juggle abilities by selecting appropriate ones as you go through the game (there are many more than 1st game). I'm not much of a fan of this, after playing Baldur's Gate on the Playstation 2 with my brother (we always pronounced it Bal Jers - sounds so much more fantastical than the Boulders they pronounce it in game!) so many times as we Loved it, then the sequel introduced crafting and we spent So Much Time in the selection screens reading n swapping n forging....it totally destroyed the flow of the game. Luckily, Ori is not like that, it's much more basic/easy, but due to my personal experience I don't like the interruption. But for others it adds choice. It also is necessary for progression on a few occasions.

Other than that, both games are pretty much a continuation of each other. Playstyle is identical, which is the Perfect decision by the devs because the first game was Excellent. Don't fix it if it ain't broke! You increase a dual power bar as you level up, allowing more/stronger abilities. The abilities you get are great fun and vital at the same time - they get assigned to buttons of your choice as you unlock them.

A lesson to newbies I learnt the hard way - if you can't do something/get somewhere, it is because you yet lack the ability! I tried for ages to get places until I finally learnt that I had to go somewhere else and earn an ability! So if stuck, go to another area of the map you've yet to do. Trust me, you'll find a new way to jump or whatever and then you go, "Ahhhhhh!
NOW I can go to that other place." In the 2nd game I deliberately upgraded one skill tree to get a particular ability I knew from the 1st game makes it so much easier, however, I could not get it after getting all the upgrades it required....it was the same old story as above - some abilities are earnt through in-game progression, you have to open a part of the map/do something/complete some quest AND upgrade! Take note!

Movement speed is super important in platformers as many games are so sloooow.  This game is, yet again, perfect!  You move quickly, and the abilities can boost that significantly.  This is important as the map is large and there are, in my opinion, too few jumpgates.  Still, going back and forth is a lot more acceptable than most games that force you to backtrack.  The hardest part of this game is finding all the hidden items which will be the greatest reason for backtracking.  There is sadly a single glitch in the 2nd game whereby about half of players, myself included, could not 100% the game as one 'complete the set' never goes above 97% (one gem short kind of thing even though you've found them all).  

The action AND platforming can be frenetic at times, which is actually massive fun. Boss battles can be a bit annoying - like a side-scroller where you have to learn the right way by dying constantly and repeating. This the ONLY flaw in this otherwise perfect game in two parts!

And the music....the opening title screen tune....It is heartbreaking that it is so short - it's one of the most brilliant little tunes I've ever heard. Pure joyous magic.

Sadly, it seems from the ending that they will not be making another. I'd buy it without a second thought if they did. I wonder if it's like Batman and Halo - originators didn't want to spend their entire career developing the same game so handed it over....and they got worse. Still, I'd buy it and hope!

The boss fights were unique, distinct, and challenging, but could be learned through attempting them.  There were race/chase elements in the game that were similarly challenging and pushed you to min/max your speed with all your different abilities.  The graphics and atmosphere of the game were top notch.  It just combined all the things you want in a game really well.  10/10.

Ori and the Will of the Wisps stands as a masterful testament to the brilliance of 2D platformers, intertwining breathtaking visuals, emotionally resonant storytelling, and an enchanting musical score to create an immersive gaming experience. Developed by Moon Studios, this sequel not only lives up to its predecessor but surpasses it in every aspect.

One of the game's standout features is its awe-inspiring artistry. The meticulously crafted environments, characterized by vibrant colors and intricate details, elevate the game to a visual masterpiece. Each frame is a work of art, bringing the mystical world of Ori to life with a sense of wonder and magic. The level design is equally commendable, seamlessly blending beauty with functionality to deliver a platforming experience that is as challenging as it is visually captivating.

The emotional depth embedded in the narrative adds another layer of richness to the game. The poignant story of Ori's journey, filled with moments of sorrow, hope, and friendship, resonates long after the credits roll. The nuanced character development and the connection forged with the spirit companions, the Wisps, evoke a genuine emotional investment from the player.

A standout aspect of Ori and the Will of the Wisps is its evocative musical score. Composed by Gareth Coker, the soundtrack complements the game's emotional beats and atmospheric nuances flawlessly. The music serves as a guiding force, intensifying the impact of key moments and creating a deeply immersive experience. The synergy between visuals, narrative, and music is a testament to the meticulous craftsmanship behind the game.

The challenging platforming elements, coupled with demanding boss battles, contribute to the game's overall excellence. The decision not to grind for skill upgrades adds an extra layer of difficulty, enhancing the sense of accomplishment when overcoming obstacles and defeating formidable foes. The finely tuned balance between difficulty and reward keeps players engaged and invested in Ori's journey.

While some may find the game's level of difficulty daunting, it ultimately adds to the sense of achievement when conquering each section. The commitment to a challenging platforming experience sets "Ori and the Will of the Wisps" apart in a genre that often relies on nostalgia rather than innovation.

In conclusion, Ori and the Will of the Wisps stands as a testament to the potential of 2D platformers in the modern gaming landscape. With its mesmerizing art, emotionally charged narrative, and challenging gameplay, Moon Studios has created a masterpiece that transcends the boundaries of the genre. It's not just a game; it's an emotional journey that captivates players from start to finish, solidifying its place as one of the finest examples of gaming artistry in recent years.

[b]"Ori and the Will of the Wisps" doesn't simply follow its predecessor's recipe, but enrichens it with bigger world, more combat and a lot of new ideas. Its colorful visuals are gorgeous, lore is deep, the immersive atmosphere is both cheerful and dark, the story is epic and emotional, NPCs look unique and music is great. Yet, it really shines with its flawless gameplay that constantly evolves with new abilities and its fantastic level design that offers a lot exploration capabilities and some breathtaking platforming sequences. Precise control mechanics and fluid animations offer an amazingly pleasant experience that you won't find elsewhere. Miraculously the "more is more" logic of the developers crated a game with coherence and made it feel always interesting and rewarding.


Manometer: 9/10[/b]


The good
 - Gorgeous visuals. A majestic world with amazing colors, atmospheric lighting, faire tale vibes and various different places to explore. Although its atmosphere is eerie and magical, it has some dark parts and manages to immerse you right from the beginning.
 - Awesome gameplay. It's easily one of the most pleasant and fluid platformers ever made. Ori's movements are so smooth, transitions are seamless and its skillset always evolves so it never get monotonous. There is a big variation of upgrades, abilities and weapons that you can find or purchase and transform the whole experience. There are plenty of clever ideas and it's great to watch Ori's evolution from the initial just "run and jump" guy.
 - Precise, effective control mechanics Everything works flawlessly and it's awesome how cleverly they managed to fit all these abilities and combos in simple button combinations. Players get used of every new move quickly and can feel every movement in their fingertips.
 - Amazing exploration feeling. It's remarkable how the world opens gradually and how it lets you organically discover all these scattered hidden secrets, shards, orbs, other characters, vendors. It's nice that it gives you a lot of clues on the map so you don't just search entirely by luck. You take the clues and try to find the hidden path or a clever way to reach certain things.
 - Fantastic, smooth animations. Except of Ori's amazing movement set, everything inside its world feels alive. Plants, branches or water are not just static background elements and make it even more immersive.
 - Great level design to support some breathtaking platforming sequences that require continuous movement and good timing. Each level adds new elements and mechanics so each time your approach is different.
 - Battles are nice and pretty pleasant. It's not packed of enemies everywhere but there are some sessions of cool battles. There is a pretty good variation of well designed enemies with a variety of abilities and attacks.
 - Cool, epic story with some nice emotional moments. World's lore and all the pieces of information and backstories that you learn gradually make it even more interesting.
 - It has some nice side missions and a set of unique NPCs. Characters are well designed and there are a lot more than its predecessor, forming small communities and making the world feel more inhabited.
 - There are some parts with great cinematic sequences or chases with timed events and epic things happening at the background while you're running. Cut scenes are well made and atmospheric too.
 - It has some challenging small trials scattered in the world. They're speed trials or battles with waves that can give you some nice rewards.
 - Amazing calm music to accompany you through your exploration. It never gets tiring and during battles it raises the tempo to fit the action.
 - Simple yet nice audio design. Environmental sounds are good. Sounds of movement, slashes, explosions and more give you great feedback.
 - It doesn't want to mess with your nerves so it offers constant checkpoints and doesn't punish you with losing things when dying. Yet, some may find it too forgiving.

The bad
- After its middle point, at least in normal level of difficulty, when you start to have a lot of life and energy cells it loses its balance and gets rapidly easier and easier. Mobs, projectiles, nails, lasers don't feel dangerous anymore so you don't worry much if you get hit a few times. This affect massively the way you approach it and make you less careful. Also there are two or three ability shards that are clearly overpowered and simplify the game to a point that almost ruin it.
- Bosses are well designed visually and offer some cool cinematic sequences, but they're only few of them and their mechanics don't look very imaginative or refreshing. It's ok though. The game is more of a platformer than a souls like.

[h1]Speechless sadness[/h1]

[i]Honestly its one of those rare moments when alrdy amazing game becomes even better. 
For me [b]"Ori and the Blind Forest"[/b] been one of best examples how to create something more than just good platformer. It had smooth and responsive movement, visuals that can easly be used as your wallpaper, music which can hold you in main menu for some time after launching the game, and of course the story while being simplistic leaves memorable expirience.

After listing all above you would think "It cant get that much better" but it does. One of first big improvements might be new combat system, it allows you to fight your enemies with huge arsenal of weapons and skills without touching ground and flying all over your screen dodging projectiles and boss attacks. Yes [b]"Boss fights"[/b] another thing that been added to the game and when you learn their patern those encounters becomes more enjoyable than FromSoftware games, cause you not limited to dodge and attack buttons and able to use your own flow of fight. 
Then there is optional collectables\upgrades that can improve Ori in different ways it can be slight buff or change to ability mechanic, maybe utility stuff like enemies provide more exp but reciving extra health and damage and so on.[/i] 

Now to smaller additions:
[u]Even more new movement abilities[/u]
[u]NPC and Quests[/u]
[u]Non-linear order for locations[/u]
[u]And of course onion ninjas included[/u]

So the last thing i would like to say [b]"try to support more projects like this one"[/b] they totally deserve it.

Alright, I know I said it for Blind Forest, but this is the absolute best game I have played in my life. From the stellar animation to the calming music and smooth as butter gameplay, this masterpiece is incredible. After playing this, the previous game is near impossible to return to. Everything was improved so, so much, especially the movement. The level design is also substantially better, that with being a more interconnected world. Also, I especially love the fact that, rather than just restoring the land in the previous game, you also restore the life it once held. This is one of the few games I have played that calmed me down this much. The combat has also been majorly improved, with significantly more diversity in how you can defeat your enemies. However, there is one singular issue, and that is some of the controls. Occasionally, in the final "dungeon" of the game, a specific power for floating wouldn't work half of the time. Anyways, that aside, this game is easily a 10/10, and I can't wait to see what Moon Studios makes next! keep up the great work!

This game is a masterpiece. I mean, no joke. The combination of the music, the visuals, the emotional storytelling, and the fun and amazing combat and platforming is just beyond outstanding. All the great things from its predecessor return, but better in all aspects, plus epic boss fights that will give a great challenge to players. This is a wonderful example of a sequel that, without exaggeration, improves upon its predecessor in every way. The controls are tighter, the worlds are more fun than ever to navigate, and the worlds are more vivid than ever. Will of the Wisps is, for sure, one of the best Metroidvania and 2D platformers ever made.

It is also clear that much more time was put into the story of the game, which has a certain knack for tugging on the heart strings more than once, though the gameplay is more than enough to justify playing this game if you don't care about the story as much. Right now, there are some technical and performance issues that may disturb the experience but are fixable over time, which I really don't bother with and deny my not giving it 5 stars. It's a must-play. And believe me, tears will be shed. Kudos to Moon Studios for showing us all over again how to blur the line between a simple "game" and "art".

To put it simply, this game is more than I had ever expected it to be. 

By all means, I am far from a game connoisseur, but there are so many qualities about this game that could easily bring it up to #1 spot on my list of platformers:
- The magical and fantastical aesthetic of the game is consistent throughout with it's high quality backgrounds, VFX and characters
- The fluidity of movement and combat gives players an easy and free way to travel from point to point (by far my favourite feature)
- The progression and new abilities only build on the combat and movement, making unlocking new areas even more exciting
- It's pretty much an open world platformer, with lots of hidden secrets, side quests and freedom, allowing for progression to be made at your own pace
- Puzzles/races as well as fighting, which gives it more variety and adds on to what more you can do after completing the game
- Plenty of useful upgrades for all sorts of abilities and passives

My two points of criticism would be: 
1) How repetitive the story can be sometimes, with it's dragging loop of similar boss fights/chase scenes in each different area or losing Kuro and having to reunite later on once again. However, the game itself can be fairly short and is not too heavy on story so it doesn't really hold too much against the overall experience. 
2) How unguided, obscure and ambiguous quests are, especially at the beginning. I must say, there were times I did have to google parts as there was no explanation behind most things. Who knows, maybe I'm just a bit dim.

Overall, great game if you're as into fluid combat/movement, nice animation, aesthetics  and soundtrack as I am. For how short the game can be, the extra plot and repetitive bosses wasn't a huge deal breaker for me, especially since I completed it within 2 weeks with a 19 hour overall play time.

Ori and the Will of the Wisps surpass its predecessor, Ori and the Blind Forest, in every aspect, delivering an extraordinary gaming experience. 
It's graphically better. Visuals and artistic environments immerse players in a vibrant and enchanting world. 
The narrative is filled with emotional depth and memorable characters from the previous game, adding another layer of richness to the game. 
Combat mechanics have been enhanced, offering a satisfying and dynamic gameplay experience. 
Ori's mobility has been expanded too, granting players a greater sense of freedom and fluidity in movement. 
Additionally, the game features a larger map full of hidden secrets. 
In summary, Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a masterpiece and a must-play in the platforming genre.
