The definition of a Good Sequel! More of the good stuff that made Ori and The Blind Forest Great such as Gorgeous artstyle, fantastic music score, fast and snappy movement, cute if somewhat dark little narrative. Additionally, significant improvements were made to Ori's weaknesses: The combat has been entirely overhauled and while its not amazing it is solid and meshes well with the movement and the new boss fights, Additionally the game is noticeably longer taking than its predecessor, which for a game as fun as this one is a good thing in my books. The world also has significantly more NPCs and Sidequests to engage with making the world feel more full and pathfinding through the world a bit less linear. Overall a gorgeous metroidvania with great platforming, decent combat, and a moderate average completion time (9/10).

Perfectly balanced game design, and I do not use the terms lightly. First game in quite a while where I actually got all the side quests done. They make sense, aren't a boring grind, can be mostly completed naturally over the course of the game, and what little secrets there are, they can be uncovered with just enough healthy reasoning and without having to go through a slough in order to try different things out.

There are NPCs that make the world feel more alive and grounded. Ori can talk to them and they will make Ori feel relevant, which eliminates a pet peeve of mine with these sorts of games: the main character often feels like they barely exist to what few other characters are encountered along the way, and their accomplishments don't really affect dialogue or NPC stance towards the player character.

Finished in 12 hours on normal difficulty and used a PS4 controller with no issues, using Steam Big Picture with controls translation and standard layout.

Absolute 10/10, feeling very melancholic after finishing the game, hoping they keep the IP alive and bring us more of it soon.

Giving my boy Ori a good review because Moon Studios knocked out of the ball park with this sequel. They took all aspects from Blind Forest and made them 2x better plus added much more. There are a lot of elements borrowed from Hollow Knight in this one but made to work better for Ori
Combat in Will of the Wisps is much better with Ori having access to a variety of weaponry that can be used for addicting combo set ups. New and returning passive abilities remain in the game allowing different paths of non linear exploration. Map scale has also tremendously increased in size with all area having its own unique thematic/palette to it which makes Blind Forest look bland in comparison. The art direction in these level designs are almost too good you'll end up staying in an area much longer than you should just to admire it. All the music flows incredibly well with the pacing and scenes throughout the game Gareth Coker managed to create some of the most beautiful symphonies you will hear in a game. The story :cri

Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a stunning game with beautiful visuals, an emotionally engaging story, challenging gameplay, and a memorable soundtrack. It's a worthy successor to Ori and the Blind Forest and is definitely worth playing for anyone who enjoys platformers.

Wow. What a game! It's absolutely beautiful like the first one but improves upon everything else. The soundtrack is amazing. the pieces from the Windswept Wastes and the Mouldwood Depths especially stuck with me and just immerses you in the land. The vibrant and lush Luma Pools are gorgeous to look at. The story of Life, Death, and Rebirth is an emotional roller coaster that left me teary eyed a few times. I played this on hard difficulty the first time through and it was just the right kind of difficult but doable challenge I prefer. Like other have said, this is a masterpiece. A piece of art even. My favorite Metroidvania of all time has been Hollow Knight for a while now and I didn't think anything could come close to it but then this game comes along putting itself right next to HK on the top of my list.

It was a beautiful experience from start to finish, a rollercoaster of emotions, it‚Äôs fun at times, other times it‚Äôs heart-breaking, and in the end is irredeemably beautiful.

Every one of its elements works, the graphics are detailed and artful, they move in motion with animations that flow perfectly which contributes to the aestheticism of the game. The sound design and music are superb, thrilling and captivating.

The gameplay is pristine, it handles perfectly, from Ori‚Äôs movement, to the combat and freedom of upgrades you get; there‚Äôs more emphasis here in combat than in its predecessor, but traversal and platforming are still the focuses here.

The story is fantastic, a grand culmination of everything the first game did and more, it takes a simple concept but it elevates it with the rest of its elements to provide a conclusion to the franchise that‚Äôs both heart-warming as it is memorable.

In the end, some of the platforming segments got a bit annoying, but overall, this was a superb work of art, everybody should give this game a try.

And the game itself is incredibly fun, as with the first, I am addicted to it and want to play it every day (every hour preferable ha ha). that said, I personally think I liked the first one a tiny bit better. Yes the visuals are even more beautiful here, and they added extra even more interesting gameplay and boss battles. But they made the upgrade system more complex and they limited it as well, where you can only carry a few upgrades at the time, and even that number you have to upgrade at a slow pace. On top of that; you cannot change the difficulty once you have started playing.
This poses a bit of an issues because, as with the first game, in the beginning, without having any upgrades, the game is hard, and can be very frustrating. For people first playing this, this risks rage quitting and never coming back. Almost happened a few times with me. Luckily I stuck with it because once you have more upgrades this game gets very good.
I didn't think it was possible to top Ori and the Blind Forest but somehow they did it! 10/10

[h1]Ori and the Will of the Wisps: where platforming and emotions collide[/h1]

A beautifully crafted platformer that delivers an exceptional gaming experience.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2962727067

[h3]Story[/h3]

The game is a sequel to Ori and the Blind Forest, and follows the story of the titular character, a guardian spirit named Ori, and their journey to save their friend Ku, a young owl, and the forest of Niwen.

The game takes place shortly after the events of the first game, and begins with Ori and their adoptive family, Naru and Gumo, raising a baby owl named Ku. During a flight,  become separated, and Ori embarks on a quest to locate their friend. Along the way, Ori meets new friends and allies, and discovers that there is a dark force threatening the forest of Niwen, which must be stopped at all costs.

The story of Ori and the Will of the Wisps is one of friendship, loss, and sacrifice, and is filled with emotional moments and impactful storytelling. The game's narrative is masterfully crafted, and is brought to life through stunning visuals and a beautiful soundtrack.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2959000831

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]

The game offers an exceptional gameplay experience that is both challenging and satisfying. The platforming mechanics are smooth and precise, allowing for precise movements and acrobatics. The game's combat is equally impressive, with a variety of abilities and upgrades that keep the gameplay fresh and engaging.

Moreover, the game's level design is worth commending. Each area of the game feels unique and distinct, with its own set of challenges and obstacles to overcome. The game's bosses are also well-designed and offer a satisfying challenge to players.

Terrible, unintuitive and confusing level design. Complete overkill from a certain point on. Ori 2 seems to have been concocted entirely by going the complete opposite way of it's debut title trying to be the worst it can and succeeding at it. 
This feels like it was made by taking out all the discarded and rejected ideas that must've come up during the first game, and then taken out of the garbage bin just for milking's sake - and honoring the game's equivalent of a unbelievably bad, unwanted movie sequel.

I never understood this generation's fetichism for astoundingly, ridiculously difficult games, and admittedly, they're not my style. Have not been for long. Permadeaths, timed runs.. what's the point? Prove what? To who? Maybe it's just my reflexes slowing down. Maybe I'm just at that age where such things are just not enticing and of importance anymore.
The game is - unsurprisingly and again - absolutely gorgeous (albeit I can point a few places in the map where the information on screen is just a lot to take in). The music is, to say the least - incredibly moving and even meditative at certain places.
The thing is, contrarily to The Blind Forest, wich had a fair design, everything in TWotW is completely fabricated to screw you over in the hardest way possible. Now, this may sound obvious, but in The Blind Forest, as tough as it could get, there were 'rules' in place, wich the game never broke, and patterns, wich once figured out, felt absolutely logical, and rewarding while achieving progress.
From a certain point on, TWotW just feels like it's overwhelmingly winging everything it can at you. Claustrophobically so. It becomes a big game of trial and error, without any intuitive trait to it. While the game is winging everything at you, then again you're having to be winging it right back to figure out what the game wants from you, wich becomes tremendously tiresome and confusing. I had a blast the first few hours. The further you go, the poorer the level design , and how much it becomes an unintuitive mess. A big game of guessing, horrible mechanics, trial and error. 
An absolute chore, which made me keep thinking it couldn't finish and be over fast enough, to uninstall, and never touch again. 

The game, despite its previous patches to remedy the issue, is also still noticeably dropping FPS during certain actions and locations, so not very effectively optimized.

It's a perfect sequel! Does everything equally good or better then the first one with some additional fun things to do on the side ( few "races" and side quests, enough to keep u busy not 2 much to make u bored!)

+ Still super fun
+ Nice story
- Obv predictable story part
+ Nice/interesting ending (won't say more to avoid spoilers)
+ Greatly improved combat vs the previous game
+ Old and new power ups/skills
+ Secrets
+ Really nice map
+ Great boss fights
- I expected to have 1 more great boss fight as I had a feeling that I never full "beat" that boss
+ Game length is nice, would have liked it if it was longer as it does leave u wanting more, but its not short (been a while since I played the blind forest but I would say more or less the same length)
- In order to get the achiv to get all shards/full upgrade them you need to farm the "light" which can be kinda boring after u beat the game (I had my fun with the game, explored all areas and had almost everything collected before the final boss and still had 2 go back and farm after beating the game to get those upgrades for the achiv)

Ps: Achivs are not bugged, for those that don't pop just save, exit and load/continue on the same save file (as soon as you start loading the achiv will pop) -> happened to me for multiple "collectibles" achivs (get all energy shards, 100% all maps and get all shards and upgrades)

Overall great game and a must play for all metroidvania and Ori and the blind forest fans!

its stunning visuals, engaging gameplay, emotional story, memorable soundtrack, and minor technical issues. The game's platforming mechanics are challenging yet satisfying, with new abilities and upgrades keeping the gameplay fresh and exciting throughout. The game's ability to balance moments of intense emotion with lighthearted humor and adventure is noteworthy, and the stunning environments and atmospheric soundtrack combine to create a powerful emotional experience. Although there may be some minor technical issues or bugs that can detract from the gameplay experience, Ori and the Will of the Wisps is an enjoyable and memorable experience for players.

Ori and the Will of the Wisps, from a pure video game experience, is my favorite video game of all time. Gameplay is magnificent, the visuals are stunning, the story is emotional and heartfelt; it literally has it all! In my opinion, it is the most complete gameplay experience that I've ever had. 

This all may sound hyperbolic to most people, and I'll admit, these claims are very extreme. But I would not state my opinions this way if I didn't believe them. Let me break down the reasons why I love this game so much a bit further. I will note that this review is mostly spoiler free, so if you want to experience the game yourself--which I obviously highly recommend--you should still be able to read this review to get a good picture for what you would be getting into. 

Gameplay Design: The gameplay is that of any typical 2D metroidvania title. You explore a large world and come across upgrades and discover secrets along the way to make traversal easier throughout the game. It also encourages you to backtrack to old areas by sprinkling in hints of knowledge of where certain items are so you can return later with the appropriate upgrade. This also allows more skilled players a chance to test their skills and try and get certain items faster if they are creative enough with their current repertoire. The way you upgrade Ori is also wildly fun and flexible. In a respectful nod to the medtroidvania juggernaut "Hollow Knight," "Ori and the Will of the Wisps" adopts a similar upgrade system to the "charms" in Hollow Knight with the "shard" system. Hidden throughout the map are different shards you can equip to made your gameplay experience more dynamic, and you can equip or unequip shards at any time you want. It is a system that is extremely fun to play with to fit whatever situation you find yourself in, and the shards are fun to find too!

Combat System: One of the major criticisms of this games predecessor, "Ori and the Blind Forest," was that the combat was very limited, and that there were no boss fights. This aspect of the game has been markedly improved. There are a variety of combat options for Ori to choose from in this game, and they all have their own unique advantages and disadvantages in certain situations. You can choose up to three at a time to have on your face buttons, and this gives combat a much larger part of the experience this time around. Plus, the game also has multiple dynamic boss fights that will put your skills to the test! 

Platforming: On the other hand, one of the aspects of gameplay that the predecessor was most famous for was the platforming sections, as well as some unique movement abilities. I am pleased to say that this game has all of these elements as well! The platforming is probably even better than in its predecessor, with more variety of ways to move Ori around throughout the map. Needless to say, it is even more fun to move around as Ori in this game.

Map Design: The game flows seamlessly, and the reason that is the case is because of the masterful map design. The way the map is laid out makes going from one area to the next intuitive. Sometimes the game feels linear, only for you to realize that its just because the map is designed in a way that gently pushes you in a specific direction using visual cues. Its actually quite clever. The areas all fit together in a way that makes sense, and this game actually does something that is very difficult; it fits a wide range of different environments in relative proximity to each other with it actually making sense in the world!

Story: No story spoilers here, but just know that the if you played the first Ori game, that the story will probably move you just as much, if not even more than that game. It is definitely something that should be experiences at least once. 

Art Direction: The Ori series has always been well known for its gorgeous visuals. This game uses a combination of hand painted backgrounds with 3D character models that works immaculately. The game is masterful at using both the foreground and background to its advantage, with both characters and enemies jumping out of the foreground into the playable plane, which makes the game more immersive. The animations for the characters are fluid, with Ori in particular being a joy to watch; the way he jumps, the way he runs, the way he climbs, all the say down to the small details like Ori doing a handstand on top of a pole. This all makes the game that much more endearing to experience.

Sound: I will say this right now; this OST is my favorite of any video game I've played. I have a moderate music background, so I'm particular about my music. This OST makes fantastic uses of leitmotifs to let you musically understand what's going on in the game at that moment. At the same time, it uses a vareity of melody modulation and mode mixture to give a bit of spice to certain tracks. Not to mention that every area does have a unique sound of its own, and every cinematic moment in the story is enhanced by the OST to an insane degree. The sound design is also superb, with certain actions feeling extremely powerful and satisfying. There are also the little details like the little grunts Ori makes while swinging weapons, to gasps when he emerges from water.  

Technical Performance: Heavy criticism was given to this game upon launch for its many technical hiccups, and rightfully so. People have complained of stuttering, screen tearing, frame rate drops glitches where characters disappear, music glitches, to not even saving achievements. That being said, I want to emphasize that if that is your main reason for not getting this game, that these issues are (for the most part) resolved. There have been multiple patches to the game, and the developers have ironed out ALL of these issues. In my experience playing the game, I haven't experienced a SINGLE ONE of these issues. The game flowed seamlessly, no stuttering, minimal load times, and runs at a butter smooth FPS (mine was not capped so ran at 200+ FPS), all in 4K resolution. As far as technical performance, this game really doesn't have any issues, at least with my experience.  

Conclusions: Overall, this game as a lot of love put into it. You can tell the developers took their time with this game and came out with the best product that they could produce! This game is an absolute masterpiece, and is the new gold standard in which future metroidvania titles should be compared to.

Beautiful atmosphere and fluid movement which you'd expect from an Ori game. Never had a dull time completing the main game. I won't be 100%ing the game, but that doesn't take away from my enjoyment that I had while playing. Boss fights while sparse, felt so good and elevated even more by the OST. One of my favorite metroidvanias and cannot recommend enough 10/10

Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a worthy sequel to its predecessor. The visuals, while already great in the previous game, were improved even more and again offer a stunning experience from start to finish. One of my gripes with Ori and the Blind Forest was the stale combat system which has been completely revamped and greatly improved in this game. Combat in general has subsequently become a more important aspect, which some people may like or dislike. 

The quality of the story and soundtrack rivals the levels of the first game, which is an impressive feat in itself. It also brought some QoL changes that I greatly missed in the first game like quicktravel. From a gameplay perspective, a lot of new and fun mechanics were added to the different level designs. The shard system, which enables you to change your skillset on the fly, brought some great variety on how you wanted to play Ori throughout the game.

That being said, the escape sequences weren't as good as in the prequel and I thought that some of the boss fights weren't designed that well from a boss mechanic standpoint. Most of the bosses had very obvious and repeating attack patterns, which were easily abusable and made some of the fights a bit too simple for my personal liking.

All in all, I still think Will of the Wisps is the better game overall, which ‚Äî considering what I thought of the first game ‚Äî is praise of the highest magnitude.

Also the Moki are too cute, as a 30+yr old dude, i couldnt help but fall in love with them, i wanted to solve all their problems. 
Overall would totally recommend.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

The following is my review of Ori and the Blind Forest, which pretty much covers everything I think about Ori and the Will of the Wisps.
.
"Ori and the Blind Forest is an interesting case. In a vacuum, the game is very entertaining. Great art style, beautiful music, fun level-design. 
But Ori and the Will of the Wisps exists. Because of how much better Ori 2 is, I find it hard to recommend Ori 1. Ori 1 has some great features, but also some annoying parts of gameplay and an overall quick story makes the game forgettable in comparison. 
If you want about 5-10 hours of entertainment, Ori and the Blind Forest ain't bad at all, but if you want to spend more time (and have higher replay value), just go for Ori and the Will of the Wisps; it does everything Ori 1 does but better, fixes major issues, and adds a lot more interesting mechanics and gameplay."
.
TL;DR:
Ori and the Will of the Wisps does everything Blind Forest does but better, great game, buy it.

Very good game, nearly every place you go to looks like it was painted by a master.  Music is understated but supremely elegant.  Gameplay feels great, both platforming and combat, but between the two the platforming has a better gameplay feel.  I could sit back and just go from screen to screen over and over again flinging myself around like a monkey in a jungle and have a blast.   

Here are a few nitpicks I need to get off my chest though because this is not a perfect game, although still very good and recommended.  

The plot was mediocre and I simply did not care about the NPC they wanted me to care about.  All the characters talking like trombones didn't help any and the writing (sense there's no dialogue) is formulaic to the core.  

Having obviously Hollow Knight inspired charms is nice, but they are not balanced against each other very well.  For example I never saw the need to take off my triple jump because it made things so much easier then using any other charm would.  Some you will never use, some you will always use, that's probably not good design.  

The downside to the beautiful art is there is very little consistency in the designs of the environmental hazards so you hit spikes all the time because they don't always look like spikes, you will also get hit by enemies and hazards a lot because the beautiful artwork is sometimes in the foreground which blocks your view of what is going on.  

There is not enough buttons for all the things you'll need/want to do or to have assigned.  There is a pool of 16 (I think) abilities and movement skills and your controller has 6 buttons to use them with so you will just forget about a lot of skills or constantly need to shift them around.  

Combat always feels a bit too hard in the early game while you're figuring things out but too easy in the late game.

Throughout the entirety of the game, you will remain flabbergasted. This game looks gorgeous, thanks to the attention to detail and the hand-painted graphics that evoke a sense of awe and calm.The gameplay is different from Ori and the Blind Forest when it comes to battles, but it is still enjoyable. The overhaul brings new fighting styles, all complemented by new shop mechanics focused around the gathering of points. Additionally, apart from the main quest, there are intriguing side quests that bring life to the world, which is enormous.The story aspect of the game has not lost its touch. It is a worthy continuation for Ori and the Blind Forest, bringing the player closer to the universal aspects of life: kindness, friendship, sacrifice, family, and destiny.I consider this to be an exceptional piece of art, not just a game. It is a triumph in the era of stagnation for video game storytelling, graphics, and all accompanied by amazing music. I heartily recommend this game to everyone.

If you like Ori 1 for its platform- and puzzle gameplay, you probably wont like this one as much. It implements an unnecessary combatcomponent and uses its bossfights as a vehicle to force the metroidvania exploration aspect down your throat until it sticks out of your a**e again. Bosses are beefy, deal a ton of damage and require you to brawl them to death. Why?The fanbase didnt love or praise Ori 1 for this type of gameplay. Neither did anyone ask for it. Yes, the game is again astonishingly beautiful. Movement feels very good. But the fact that combat has become a CENTRAL aspect of this game just ruins it at least for the puzzle- and platformcrowd.

Easily the best Metroidvania game I've played, this is a huge step up in gameplay compared to the first game, greatly improved combat, movement, and even visuals. 

This sequel throws you right in with new movement capabilities and weaponry, the combat is incredibly cool with many different ways to defeat an enemy. When you get good it feels amazing to effortlessly chain different attacks together and see how an enemy reacts.

The movement is very free flowing, it's the opposite of Hollow Knight where it feels like you are moving around as a robot.

The visuals are somehow even better than the first, each frame in the game looks like it could be a wallpaper.

Gareth Coker somehow arranged over 3 hours of music for an orchestra to play, each sounding unique and beautiful. I'm super impressed by all the individual themes he uses to portray the mood perfectly.

It's gameplay, visuals, and music all come together perfectly to create one of my favourite games of all time. The game goes on sale for 80% off, if you like Metroidvanias or platformers it's easily worth the price.

Ori 1 is a good platformer game which focus more on jumping and bashing more than boss fights. Overall it's a pleasant experience and quite relaxing to play. Note that the skill bash allows a few seconds to adjust its direction. I didn't realise that in the 1st run and suffered many unnecessary deaths.

Achievement difficulty overall is not too bad. Three areas in the game will be locked when completed, which may cause some issues for collection achievements. No death, no skill and speed run achievements can be completed in the same run. I did it on the 3rd run with less than 2 hours, with the help of the duplicate saves function in game.

I played 80% of the time on steam deck and 20% of the time on PC. The switching between deck and PC is hassle-free. However, there seems to be some glitches in achievements when playing on deck. I got two achievements (50% and 100% map stones) unlocked in early part of the 1st run when the criteria is not met. There is also a noticeable difference between the 60 fps on deck and 120 fps on PC.

This game is just amazing. Ori is just so nimble and very fun to move around. The combat is very satisfying and rewarding at times. There are just so many combos that you can do to juggle the enemy in the air and sometimes one shot the enemies with energy consuming abilites. But the highlight of this game is the story. It's a story about family and what Ori and the rest of the family would do for each other. It's heartbreaking but also poetic, not gonna lie it's been a while since a video game made me teared up. TL;DR Play it if you want to immerse yourself in a beautiful world, play it if you want to be moved by a beautifully written story, play it if you want to annihilate enemies using swift and nimble combat movements.

Getting 100% was... Enjoyable, emotional at times, but mostly satisfying.

approximate amount of time to 100%: 30-40
Estimated achievement difficulty: 7/10
Minimum number of playthroughs needed: 2
Multiplayer achievements: No.
Missable achievements: Yes. A couple of "Finish the game without doing X" type achievements.
Grinding Achievements: All collectibles.
DLC-Only achievements: No.
Time-gated achievements: No.
Speed-run achievements: Yes, finish in 4h.
RNG-achievements: No.
Does difficulty affect achievements: Yes. Hard only.
Unobtainable/glitched achievements: No. (some users are reporting bugs but it seems they have been patched out)

Notes:
- Boss fights and races can be replayed - so the boss-related achievements can be tried over and over. (and on easy difficulty)
- Copy-save function is available.
- Super stable game at this point in time. Barely had a bug let alone a crash. With a single exception... 2-3 collectibles didn't register as being collected despite them disappearing on the map. A quit+re start fixed it.
- The No-death achievement can be cheesed by simply loading an earlier save when dying instead of allowing the game to respawn.
-"High and dry" unlocks once you clear the mill. You don't need to finish that playthrough.
- On hard mode, buying everything costs extra Light (game's money). Even tho I collected literally every bit of it from the map I was still short about 10k. Luckily grinding it in AFK farms is possible (check youtube, there are many ways).

In conclusion this is a clear recommend from me. Achievement wise it has a little bit of everything, and it's really well done.

It is a very rare thing for me to enjoy a sequel even more than the first game, but this is exactly what happened here. This sequel continues to be a visual masterpiece which takes you on a magical fantasy journey. The music is stunning and peaceful and dramatic in all the right parts. The story is sweet and tugs on heartstrings and the game play is very satisfying. Using skills and abilities to navigate your environments and use your terrain and enemies to your advantage makes all movement in game very exciting. The different play modes also give players of all skill the chance to enjoy the game.

This is one of those games that gives me this real sense of joy and satisfaction that I cannot seem to find elsewhere. Both this and the first game are complete gems. I'd recommend anyone and everyone to give both a try. They are truly masterpieces.

"I am a 50 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game.
I am a single father for my son who is now 14 years old. My son has recently started playing Counter-Strike: Global Offensive.
In less than a week, he has already played more than 20 hours.
It was terrible for me, because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son.
because he was always with his friends or watching YouTube videos.
So I decided to create a Steam account to play with my son. I started playing but it was my first time playing a video game since the 90s so I was pretty lost. I asked my son for help and we spent several hours together playing this game.
I liked it as it was the best time I have had with my son since my wife died. Playing video games reminded me that there is fun in everything and it brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside of the house."

The movement is everflowing and smooth and the soundtrack provides a fantastic atmosphere for exploration that you don't see in many other games. However, this game stands out in the visuals; fantastic contrast, beautiful shading, and excellent animation, all indicate this was made with incredible care. I played the first game quite a lot and enjoyed it. So I was expecting to enjoy this game as well.

I'd say that the first game is great, but this one is amazing. Visually pleasing to say the least and challenging at times. The developers and artists of this game really have done an incredible effort to produce this game.

At 6‚Ç¨ now when it's on sale it's a must buy.

What is there to say? 
Play it. It's phenomenal. 
The controls are immaculate, the music's amazing, and the combat can give you a good (but not unfair) challenge. Between the beauty of the game, the fun of the traversal, and the slow increase of enemy battles, exploration never gets tired. There does become a fair amount of back tracking, and the world's too large for my old brain to keep good track of, but the world's so inviting and fun that I don't mind the constant traversals--whether I'm on the right track or took a wrong turn.
Plus, the rather steady stream of upgrades, new movements/weapons and basket of optional "tasks" keeps all the action pretty fresh.

It feels like the game is just a remake of the first one, because it's very similar based on what your objectives are. The combat is still very lacklustre with an emphasis on other things. I think this is because the game's movement is very centred on platforming rather than fighting. Giving an example of how unbalanced the combat is there is an achievement for killing a boss under 2 minutes and I've got it first try. But aside from that the game succeeds pretty well in other things it's trying to do. Personally the songs feel very forgettable as the game is a literal forest, So you have normal forest, ice forest, purple forest, spooky forest etc. I believe it's hard for them to make a song that's distinct from each other and that's why they feel sort of weird. The game is absolutely beautiful, with satisfying platforming and improvements to the upgrades you can buy throughout the game. The game is a minor improvement from the first and is definitely worth playing 7/10. I bought both for 10$

Ori and the Will of the Wisps is the highly anticipated sequel to the beloved platformer Ori and the Blind Forest. While the game is still visually stunning and offers a captivating soundtrack, some players may find that it falls short of the expectations set by its predecessor.

One of the main criticisms of the game is its relatively short length. Some players may feel that the game's storyline is rushed and not as fully developed as they would have liked. Additionally, while the game's platforming mechanics are still solid, they may not feel as fresh or innovative as they did in the first game.

That being said, Ori and the Will of the Wisps is still a beautiful and emotionally engaging game that is sure to captivate fans of the first game. The game's unique art style, intricate level design, and poignant story make it a worthwhile experience for anyone who enjoyed the original.

Overall, while some players may be disappointed by the game's length and lack of innovation, Ori and the Will of the Wisps is still a beautiful and engaging platformer that is well worth playing. Fans of the first game should definitely give it a try, but may need to adjust their expectations accordingly.

The list of grievances i have with the game is pretty big, so i'll summarize : 
Negatives
- more a movie than a game
- loves to remove control from you for the tiniest things
- doesn't do environmental storytelling well at all. A picture says a thousand words, no need to shove my face into the picture and say "hey this is what the picture is saying!!!"
- story is once again lackluster
- combat is middling
- gives you tutorials for basic things that don't really need it, but some things are pretty obscure (pole rotation to get height, waking up Baur...)

Positives : 
- graphics are amazing

Neutral
- mechanics are alright (sometimes bugged, they are *not* made for keyboard but still better than ori1 on that regard - notable example of not thinking about kb/mouse is the fact that bash/grapple/burrow in midair are based off direction pressed, not mouse position??)

All in all it's ok to play and finish but def not an experience i'd recommend unless you're just looking to occupy hours.

Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a perfect game: its visuals are outstanding; its story pulls on your heartstrings; and its game play makes you feel like a platforming god! I've loved playing this game and that's why I recommend others to play it.

Even better then the first game: they fixed the terrible combat system, gave you more of a reason to explore and put way more interesting powerups in along with some great platforming. While I still think it's combat can be clunky, it is at least enjoyable, and the perk system can create some fun customisation. The biggest drawback is strangely enough too few face buttons, as by late game you'll want to have so many navigation power on full time you won't even get a chance to try and use a lot of the stranger combat abilities. Still an easy recommendation though, a great visual and gameplay classic.
Great sequel to the original Ori.

In all the games I've ever played, only two of them get full marks from me -- this game, and Ori and the Blind Forest, Moving story, beautiful animation,.. Great gaming experience. Without doubt, Ori is a successful game. It even deeply impact the game industry.

It's one of the very few games that can make me cry. [spoiler] The very cute owl, Ku, was killed by Shriek? Fine, I can stand this. The flexible and kind spirit, Ori, finally embraced the light and gone? Well, that's a miserable ending, but I can still hold it. BUT when Shriek finally defeated by Ori, severely injured, and used his last bit of strength, lain under his parents' wings, tears slid from my eye... Even after Ku's death, I've browsed this game's story and already known what will happen to Shriek... [/spoiler]

And also, compare with Ori1 (Ori and the Blind Forest), this game's graphic quality is even much better. That's unbelievable and amazing because Ori1 already has the top-class graphic quality.

BUT WHY I LEAVE A NEGATIVE COMMENT HERE? You need to know, when I first posted this review one and half a month ago, I gave it a negative comment. At that time I just completed this game under normal difficulty. Although it took me about 19 hours, I still missed some major story of Ori. So the previous comment may be a little subjective. But now, I played an additional 18 hours, completed the full collection under hard difficulty, fully experienced Ori's story. Unfortunately, I still think this game has some minor (OK, maybe major?) flaws, which makes me feel disappointed and uncomfortable. That is:

1. In the poster, Ori and Ku, stand side by side, beautiful. Originally I imagined in this game Ori and Ku will fight together, and that must be interesting and thrilling. [spoiler] In this game, Ori made lots of effort,and eventually found Ku. I was happy because I think a new era that Ori and Ku fight together to protect this forest was coming. But when I found Ori couldn't dismount from Ku, and couldn't change his weapon, I realized something was wrong. Just about ten minutes after Ori met Ku, Ku was killed by Shriek, and this cute owl was gone, till the end of the game Ori embraced the light that revived Ku. So, what's the meaning of Ku in this game? Just show players how Ku died and make us feel sad? [/spoiler]

2. [spoiler] That's too abrupt that Ori finally sacrificed himself, embracing the light and becoming a spirit tree, even without meeting Naru, Gumo and Nibel once more. I know on the way to Willow Tree, the wall painting drops a hint that Ori will become a spirit tree finally. But, I still think that's really really abrupt, only make me feel sad and disappointed. It brings me nothing positive. If add this: "During the last fight between Ori and Shriek, the spirit tree is severely damaged, if Ori doesn't embrace the light imminent, Niwen will be dark and hopeless again. Ori has no choice but sacrifice himself to save the light immediately.", I believe Ori's story will be more moving and complete, and players will be more willing to accept Ori's sacrifice. [/spoiler]

That's all. I love this game, love Ori. Playing this game is just like an amazing journey, makes you happy, makes you cry, and after that you'll miss it. Ori1 & Ori2 are the only two games that get full marks from me till now. More important, it inspires me a lot in my personal game development. When I'm tired of coding or learning Computer Graphics, this little spirit will always come to my mind and push me go further. So, I want and I have to use the most strict standard to judge this game. I'm so sorry I leave a negative comment here.

Decades of metroidvanias wrapped up into one. Moon Studios took inspiration from so many titles, to make this one of the best video games ever created in our history. Ori is beautiful, fun, challenging and emotional. Once I picked up my controller, I could not stop playing this game. It's world is so alive and immersive. Just playing this game for the art alone is worth it. But, this title has a beautiful story that is told very well through more than words. Gareth Coker's beautiful score assists the artwork and characters to set the mood perfectly and tells the story through your ears as well. Not only does it improve on the first experience for fans of the first game, but fans of Hollow Knight will appreciate the challenge this title offers and how fluid Ori's movement is. Even so, just remember this is not an easy game and takes some skill to play, but it's worth it and you will feel accomplished that you got through a tough spot. Boss fights in this game are incredibly enjoyable and really memorable. Trust me when I say that even if you get frustrated by dying, don't give up! Don't be ashamed to put the game on easy, because finishing the game for the story alone is sooooo worth it. If you like to cut the onions. then Moon Studios delivers on that tear-jerker ending. I haven't been hit so hard by a game ending since Final Fantasy X. Just play this game. It is alive and makes you feel alive too.

I bought this game on a Friday night because i saw it on sale. I started playing on Saturday and had already beaten it by Sunday. I accumulated 25+ hours in less than 48 hours because I was glued to it. If it wasn't to sleep, eat, bathroom, or some IRL necessity, I was completely lost in the game. When I started the game, I played for what seemed to be an hour or so, but then I looked at the time and 6 hours had passed? It was that kind of game for me, simply AMAZING!

Visual: Every part of this game looked stunning. The art is beautifully done and the colors are so vibrant. All throughout the game, I couldn't help but admire the different areas in astonishment. Each area has its own feel and theme but no one area felt disconnected from the rest. The same goes for the characters. The art style is a bit cartoonish though (not that this is a bad thing).

Gameplay: Plays like your typical metroidvania type of game. Find power-ups to get stronger. The more power-ups you find, the more areas you'll be able to explore, etc.  However, there is no gear in this game. Instead, you find abilities that let you explore combat in different ways, and you can upgrade these abilities to change how they behave. Your base attack is a sword and that's pretty much it. Controlling the character felt smooth and nothing ever felt wonky so combat felt nice too. I played using a controller and the button configuration/placement felt really good (though I have no idea what it feels like to play with keyboard/mouse).

Level/Map Design: Overall, it feels similar to games like Hollow Knight or Bloodstained. Personally, I felt like the location of the save points were not optimal and there weren't enough of them so teleporting still felt like a chore because I'd have to walk a long way to where I wanted to go even after teleporting. Also, the games I mentioned have a very boxy/rectangular looking map so one can easily count the distance by looking at the map once and get to where one needs to go in one take. This game's map isn't so easily read. Yes, it gives a general sense of where you are in that area, but I found myself looking at the map way more often to make sure I was going in the right direction. Another difference I felt was the game didn't feel too linear. For instance, most of these types of games push you go in the direction you're supposed to and even if you veer off it will push you in the right direction. This game felt like if you veered, you'd really be lost. Yes, you do have quests that guide you to the next objective, but you can explore a lot on your own and go to places you aren't supposed to at the current time. Therefore, there's a lot of tracking back and forth. This part frustrated me a little bit as I felt I wasted a lot of time going to areas over and over again just to know I can't go further. If you're an explorer type of player like me who doesn't just go straight for the next objective, then this might frustrate you as well. Still, this wasn't bad enough for me to dislike the game.

Grinding: Thankfully you don't have to farm the same monsters over and over again to get all the upgrades. Most games like to have a ridiculous 5000000000 shard upgrade or something like that just for you to get an achievement for "get all upgrades", but all the upgrades in this game are reasonably priced and you can get almost all of them just by getting to the end area and collecting all the secret hidden goodies. That doesn't mean you won't have to grind at all because you will still need extra resources, but you won't be doing it for hours and days just to get an upgrade. 

Music: Beautiful! Simple yet stunning. It had a calm minor feel with some rhythmic variations. It matches the forest/nature environment perfectly.

Story: Some parts made me sad; some parts made me mad, and some parts made me laugh. It's a simple tale and nothing crazy happens but it's a journey that kept me entertained.

There's still more to say about the game but I feel like this covers the gist of it.  Overall, it's a great game especially if you pick it up on sale. No, you may not binge it like I did, but I'm sure you'll still enjoy every moment of playing it from start to finish whenever you do turn it on to play. Solid 9/10

The game is good... but I personally liked the first game a bit more. Here's my reasoning, the first game has a really unforgettable score but this one has a bunch of scores and it felt more difficult to nail them down. The first game had much greater mystery, in this game there are a bunch of NPCs to talk to but the first game kept it to, I believe only two. The NPCs help the world feel more alive but takes away from a lot of the mystery and lonesomeness. This game also focuses more on combat then the first which I though I would like as there wasn't much of a combat system to speak of in the first game, but it felt very odd and hard to learn. I imagine that this isn't a problem for those using controllers but if you play on keyboard, it always feels like you need another button that you can hit comfortably which can make some movement a bit awkward.

Some positives. The antagonist of this game is miles better than in Blind Forest, and I say that with love for both, but the antagonist of this game is pretty much flawless. The design, the theme, the story, the fear factor, and the threat are all real and incredible. The art is a pretty clear step up from the first game, each area feels unique and vibrant.
So yeah, the game is really good but my opinion is that it's not *quite* as good as the first one. Would absolutely still recommend.

Combat is easily the weakest aspect of the game. There are several options for attacks but none of them are unique and very little upgrading, leading to a static playstyle once you pick out your favorite skills. Hit sparks on some moves can obscure ability to react to enemies attacks. Game also has an unhealthy reliance on enemy contact damage->player stagger,which makes it very frustrating to play from time to time. Bosses are egregious to play against, with many enemies stagger animations overlapping with player melee range. This typically always results in contact damage if not playing a 1 hit then run playstyle. They also have varying hit boxes and several invulnerable phases which worsens the experience.

That said, everything else about the game is phenomenal. Simple, yet sincere and heartfelt story. Some of the best stylized visuals and animations across any game. As a metroidvania and platformer, is near perfect. Controls are tight and movement tools come together to create an incredibly satisfying rhythm especially during escape sequences. Map design is satisfying and rarely causes disorientation. Areas are visually distinct and interesting to discover, coming with their own unique skill to master. Only issue is that occasionally some puzzles will grind gameplay to a halt.No performance issues or bugs that I encountered. Soundtrack is quite good and elevates important story beats. Aside from combat, mostly respects the players time such as very few instant kills, frequent autosaving, difficulty options, fast travel, fast movement, etc. Achievements are fairly forgiving to accomplish, particularly with the built in backup saving feature which is especially useful for the untouchable achievement (had to use it twice which saved me at least 4 hours of play).  Incredibly game hampered only by its average combat.

This is my first video game review, but I felt compelled to write it.  I'm old enough to remember when the Atari console came out.  Haven't really played video games since 2015 or so.   Ori and the Will of the Wisps was my first game getting back into it, and it reminded me how much fun video games can be.  I liked that you unlocked skills as you played, giving you time to master them before increasing your skill set.  The worlds were rich and beautiful, and the soundtrack made it feel like I was in a movie.  Being old, I am not a big fan of the open world, just go and fuck around GTA style.  This game naturally guided me through to the end which I like.  Wish I could wipe my memory and play it again as new.   This game is a gem.

This game is one of the best games I played - great story, wholesome, sad, hopeful, calming, anxiety-inducing, easy, hard. It's just so much in one. Anyone would have fun playing and your sibling or partner would have a blast watching you play as well.
Very good game. i like that there's more customization compared to the first game, so that you can make your own builds, rather than just using what you're given.

It's another beautiful ori game and the ending is very bittersweet. Happy but sad and not altogether unexpected but a little out of left field. 

Everything is emotionally inspiring and captivating like a true work of art. It does everything it can to make you feel, and it works (though this one is a little soppier) lol Truth be told, I prefer the 1st to the 2nd because I feel there is a lot more going on and things seem slightly less impactful. Everything about the first had more oomph, the 2nd is more battle-focussed but it does instil a sort of 'feeling of sacrament' to the environments.

The game is very different depending on difficulty. Easy is a joy to breeze through and focus on the story; Normal is good if you know what you need to do; and Hard is certainly challenging and requires you strengthen yourself up before you progress.

What I mean is - even the VERY FIRST BOSS a few minutes into the game can either be a frustrating "what do I do?!" or a cakewalk depending on your difficulty - it makes a huge difference.

I still maintain that the game is not the kind of game you should speedrun - it's an artistic experience with beautiful visuals and soundtrack that should be savoured slowly and carefully. I feel like it's at odds with the intent of the game and I thought the devs realised that when they took out certain achievements from the revamped edition of the 1st game? "Caveat completionists" is all I can say too because there's certainly a challenge here if you want one! lol

Would I recommend it? Absolutely, but take your time and try not to lose your cool if you die to the same thing again and again or can't figure out where to go next.
Progressing in the Luma Pools can take some thinking (hint: feather + bubble) and I found when hiding from Shriek I forget one or 2 of the safe spots (and having to go back to the last checkpoint can get tedious), but everything else makes up for it and it's very enjoyable if you're on the most appropriate difficulty.

A solid game that has some very minor annoying design decisions that may have you going "Well that's bullsh*t." It's also a bit embarrassing that a production like this crashes when being exited, a issue that was introduced via a patch, c'mon Moon...

In conclusion, excellent game, lovely art, fluid mechanics, wonderful soundtrack as always. Definitely deserves the overwhelmingly positive rating.

I can't really say too much that hasn't already been said by many others.  It's one of the best, if not the best, Metroidvania ever made.  Absolute breathtaking and awe-inspiring in every way.  The one thing I wanted to add to what others are saying, is that you can ignore the "Difficult" and "Souls-like" tags.  It is not either of those things in Normal mode.  Those tags are REALLY overused on Steam.  It's nowhere near the difficulty of a game like Hollow Knight, for example.  I'm pushing 50 and I have the hand/eye coordination of an old man, and I beat it with no great difficulty. I give Ori and the Will of the Wisps a score of 11/10.  Both it and its predecessor, Ori and the Blind Forest, are absolute masterpieces in gaming and in art.  Ori and the Blind Forest already set the bar insanely high, yet somehow, the developers managed to improve upon it in almost every way possible in this sequel.  Every aspect of this game is beyond phenomenal in their quality; from the art style, graphics, world/level design, gameplay mechanics, sound design and music, story, lore, characters and more.  It is all near perfection.
I simply cannot praise this game enough and in my humble opinion, I firmly believe that Ori and the Will of the Wisps and Ori and the Blind Forest are two of the best games ever made of any genre, bar none.

If you like action/adventure puzzle platformers, great stories, music, beautiful art, or just gaming in general, Ori and the Will of the Wisps and Ori and the Blind Forest are must haves.

Top shelf stuff, a wonderful experience if you have the grit and patience for the challenges it presents, as not much ground will be under your feet in later stages. The visuals are radiant eye sex and the world with all the old-new characters feels deeply alive even in its starting sorry state, makes you invested as you spirit blast your way with all the metroid-feeling rewarding powerups to restore it.

Welcome additions were the skills, the "weapons", the sidequests and all the little nuances you can get to learn and know about the world through talking with everyone, slowly piecing it together. I had a feeling they buffed up the original concept well and lead it to a complex ending without compromising or easing on difficulty or story because of popularity. It allows itself to become heart-wrenching and face-slapping at some points too again like the first episode, which can be trying for the player.

Really worth getting, i'd put it on the biggest screen i could get on next playthrough but it has to rest for a bit.
Really Really nice game!

Absolutely amazing game. I played the previous game in the series and loved it, but this was easily better than the first one. It took a great deal of inspiration from other successful metroidvania games (namely, Hollow Knight), which really resulted in an overall improvement to the game. The combat system was more fleshed out, the boss fights were more interesting, and a great deal of mechanics (such as warping between save points) have really made the moment to moment gameplay much more enjoyable. There are also way more collectibles and even the addition of sidequests! The story was also quite compelling and emotional. This all added up to an easily recommendable experience.

Ori and the Blind Forest was a masterpiece, but this game was somehow better in nearly every way. The Will of the Wisps has much more fluid combat, and it sports a vibrant world brought to life by uniquely interesting characters, which make the first game seem almost lonely by comparison. You've got to love the Moki's innocent lines.

Some new abilities open up more movement options (though nothing can compare to Bash) and the boss fights + combat shrines are a load of fun. My integrated GPU doesn't meet the minimum system requirements, but I still throughly enjoyed the game on its lowest settings with occasional stutters.

One criticism though is that the energy-consuming combat abilities can make the boss fights too [i]easy[/i], like Spirit Arc + relevant shards letting me quickly mow down one of the later bosses on my first try. Most purchasable combat abilities seem irrelevant and I still end up favoring the basic combat (which is very satisfying) the most. This game definitely has a very different feel from OBF's heavier focus on platforming, not that it's lacking for it in any case.

Edit: After having played through the game on Hard, I will say that I felt as though Ori shouldn't have become a combat-focused game. Although the combat isn't bad, the game's beauty becomes incredibly distracting when you're trying to search for the location of your character, your white mouse cursor, or warnings before attacks like Shriek's directional dives. When you're playing on a difficulty where getting hit three times takes you from full health to none, the glowing, multicolored objects on screen make it very hard to keep track of important game elements. This also applies to the often blurry line between background scenery and solid platform elements - it's all a little too much sometimes.

Will of the Wisps makes Blind Forest look like a prototype - an amazing and beautiful one, but a prototype still. This game manages to turn its predecessor, which was essentially just an adventure-platformer with some combat, into a fully fledged action RPG with quests, NPCs, boss fights, challenges and an in-depth abilities and upgrades system. WotW is a gigantic step-up from BF's basic skill tree, adding a lot more complexity and diversity to the gameplay, while also making important changes for balancing.

Since this is an Ori game, it goes without saying that the visuals are on another level of beautiful, and the music perfectly hits the tone in any situation. It's really clear how much love the devs put into building this amazing world that makes you want to explore every nook and corner. Combined with the emotional story and great characters, this game is an experience unlike any other. Yes, it is [i] very [/i] difficult at times, but in the same way as a Souls-like that gives you the feeling of achievement and reward in the end. 

[u] Conclusion:[/u]
I deem this game well-worthy of the title of a classic, do yourself a favor and play it.

I'm a big fan of the first Ori game, and to no surprise its successor was a masterpiece as well. Setting off where the first part started, Ori and the will of the wisps features: Great art, excellent story and character development, astounding music, amazing effects and smooth and nice gameplay with many abilities. Ori is one of the few, if not only, game that can make me cry, even on successive playtroughs. 

The only thing I can critique for this game is that the last fight is... well... hard. But not for the right reasons. I really like challenges and play almost all games I can on the hardest difficulty. Fights should be hard due to mechanics. Not RNG, which was the entirety of this fights challenges. [spoiler] Particularily the last part of the fight, where you have to keep yourself in the air by dashing through the comets/stars and also dodge Shrieks diagonal attacks is utter madness. Sometimes the comets would exclusively fall on one side and if you're unlucky you'd just fall. Also, Shrieks diagonal attacks are really stupidly programmed as far as I could tell. Sometimes they would hit you, despite you being at the very corners of the screen, then they won't hit you even if you're right in there and without the launch's invincibility frames. Also, sometimes the diagonal attack would follow you, because the camera keeps centering on Ori, essentially making it impossible to even dodge. And this attack does more than half of my life as dmg and I am only missing one life container. Even though Shriek does not have much HP left, I often would die without chance after having the chance to damage her once. [/spoiler] Unfortunately, this totally killed my enjoyment at this point. RNG is one of the most unfun mechanics, if implemented the wrong way. And here it definitely is. This is a very poor point in the game to rely on RNG, as it also caused me to totally be angry at the game or the devs, resulting in me not being able to enjoy the successive cinematics I would've surely cried at because it was just so frustrating one moment ago.

Please, dev team, keep up the good work with doing your games. I mean it. I really love them. But... just stay away from stupid RNG. At least in crucial moments like these. Okay? Thank you for your effort!

Beautiful. Haunting. Evoking. These are just a few of the words I would use to describe this game. The last game I played beginning to end was Donkey Kong Country II. I was looking for a platformer-like game that would entice me to spend my limited free time as a mom of 4 to love playing again. This one did it. HOWEVER - I wish the team had taken a bit more time to test the UX of the game. For example, when Ori receives quest details, you get them once, and then all you get is some vague description on the map. No way to trace what others have said. Also, some of the key moments that let you advance in the game, have no foretelling or hint of any sort. Of course there are things that you can figure out, but some is by chear luck one might actually learn. All in all, I love this game and hope to see more of Ori and his pals in the future.

Outstanding visuals and music, and improved gameplay make for a worthwhile, and even better sequel to what was already a great game with Ori and the Blind Forest. Ori and the Will of the Wisps takes what worked with the original, and turned it up.

The visuals and music were already a staple of what made the first game so popular, and nothing has changed. Again it looks and sounds amazing, and I would be hard pressed to imagine something being more aesthetically pleasing than the original, but it tops it with its own sequel.

In terms of story, it is just as heartfelt and emotional as the first game, if not more so. The visual storytelling with these games has always exceeded anything they have tried to do with dialogue. While, yet again, the story isn't anything complex, it is moving. The world building is even better than before, with a multitude of characters you can meet and perform tasks for with the new quest/side quest system. This aids in helping you care about Niwen as you are saving it. The world feels more lived in this time around.

One of the most clear improvements with the Will of the Wisps is its combat system. Something TBF lacked was engaging combat. The combat in WOTW is so much more satisfying and engaging. It isn't a click and dodge as it was. Now you have a variety of weapons you can choose from and upgrade. With different aerial combos, and actually being required to aim now, combat feels more earned.

The platforming is also another change that saw pretty massive improvement. Going back to TBF after playing this one feels so slow. There are a variety of new ways to get around, and it flows really well. Because the skill ceiling is higher, you can really feel this sense of mastery by the end.

Ori and the WIll of the Wisps loses nothing of what made Ori great in the first place, and only improves upon itself. If you like a story that is told rather than felt, it might not be for you. If you like platformers, you shouldn't miss it. I'd gladly recommend it.

[h1]DISCLAIMER: THIS IS A MOSTLY INFORMATIVE REVIEW[/h1]
[b]TL;DR I definitely enjoyed this game and I think that anybody with a hint of enjoyment for platformers and/or metroidvanias should give this and "Ori and the Blind Forest" a go. Both these games are excellent, and you'll especially enjoy them if you like games like Hollow Knight.[/b]

It's one of those few cases where you just gotta play the game because it's special like that.
There are very few games that hit this list for me, and I'm proud to say Will of the Wisps stands tall not only as a great successor to Blind Forest, but as a great game in its own right that manages to compare even to the likes of Hollow Knight.

Like the aforementioned, Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a metroidvania, with a heavy emphasis on exploration, discovery and multiple sidequests thare are literally intertwined with eachother. Aside from all the side content is a pretty simple story; you are a spirit in a dying land where the Light (all-feeding source of life) has been separated into several weaker Wisps, forcing you to go and acquire these Wisps and bring them back all together to save the lands and everything in it.

The artstyle is definitely the main draw for Ori as a franchise, where both games display an enormously high standard of quality for their graphical design. For the most part, a lot of the environments are hand drawn and cleverly overlapped with lightly cell-shaded 3D models. Essentially, this gives a lot of environments and characters in this game a sort of depth you'll often struggle to find in other similar games. There is a level of detail unheard of in every place you go, every area you visit, and, for lack of a better way of putting it, it all looks beautiful.

To top it all off, Will of the Wisps introduces a much more refined version of the combat system from the first game. In the first game, you had a wisp that did pretty much everything for you; attack, use abilities, etc. while you were left with almost exclusively mobility tools and cool gimmicks.
This game brings back a lot of those cool gimmicks and mobility tools, but Ori himself is actually able to fight as well. You have access to a surprisingly large variety of attacks and abilities that all change the way you can play the game, having access to 3 of them at a time and allowing you to swap between them on the spot if you need to.

Enemy design is mostly limited. You'll encounter a lot of the same enemies or more powerful variants of the same enemies, which may ruin the fun for some people in regards to the otherwise greatly improved combat. 

Platforming is also at its best. On top of having access to a lot of great options from the first game, Will of the Wisps introduces brand new abilities for Ori to unlock and provide greater challenges like you've never seen before that are extremely fun and satisfying to use. 

In terms of difficulty, there are a few difficulty spikes in some areas, especially bosses. Some platforming puzzles are notoriously more difficult than others and don't offer rewards that, personally, feel like they reward you enough. 
Most bosses in the game follow a pretty simple likewise design, having multiple phases where the surrounding level changes and demands more and more attention from you as you try to fight the boss itself, or sometimes transitioning you into a quick parkour segment where you're forced to run for your life across a series of obstacles. It can definitely be hard at times, but I wouldn't call them the hardest bosses in any game as I personally have only died once or twice to some of them. 

[h1]Overall,[/h1]
I think Ori and the Will of the Wisps is an amazing game worth experiencing at least one, especially if you're already into the Metroidvania genre and have thoroughly enjoyed games like Hollow Knight. This game offers plenty to explore and plenty to see, making 100%ing the game more satisfying than anything I've played before.

This was played fresh off beating the original Ori game. So what did I think?
In short: Stupid owl child, [spoiler] I wish he stayed dead, [/spoiler] it's his fault we got this game because he didn't turn around or land in that goddamn storm
Best gotten when it's on a good sale.

It's perfectly serviceable, though I wouldn't exactly recommend getting it outside a sale.
A lot of the uniqueness with the original (om)Ori game has been lost in favour of more conventional game design.
Ori now gets to wield a big hammer (as well as the standard blade and some other things I neglected to use), several movement abilities have been moved around (the wall climbing ability has been turned into an equippable thing instead of holding a trigger, the bash letting you jump off enemies has been re-mapped and now shares it with a new grapple ability, etc.), instead of the shrine-to-shrine travel you can teleport to any visited shrine anywhere should you buy that ability.

Oh yeah, there's shops. You can buy stuff with funny light you pick up.

The original platforming stuff is there, however Ori now fights by him-(her? idk, I'll write him)-self, instead of having the little wispy spirit thing (which is basically gone here) attack for him as he avoids the dangers. This turns Ori to less of a small spirit trying to restore order to more of a fighter, which doesn't really fit Ori, that seemed like more of a pacifist in the first game. This means that there's more combat in the game, making this less of a pure platforming challenge.

Perfomance was fine, but I highly recommend going into the options as soon as you can so you can turn on the framerate limiter, so that the game doesn't stress your machine trying to bang out as many frames as possible. My machine survived because it's a full gaming machine with recent enough components.

The fighting was fine, if not easily exploitable once you get the Bash and the hammer, however I normally tended to just avoid fighting and just zoom through to the next objective as fast as I could.
I beat this in about three days? 8.8 hours.

The story is even more generic this time, so Ori almost entirely carries itself on the visuals and its gameplay this time. Story was fine, but nothing I haven't heard of before. [spoiler] Two pals get lost in a storm, decay bird gets bullied, stupid owl child dies, adventure happens to revive the stupid owl, Ori turns into a tree, etc. [/spoiler]

Miscellaneous things:
The hammers up-air lifts you up a bit. I used that a lot to get to places in ways maybe I weren't supposed to.
The dash is now more a roll, even in the air, and the sound is different, so it's not nearly as fun to spam.
Quests exist now.
The old save system is gone, now it saves whenever you quit, go on one of those healing/fast travel point altars, and there's checkpoints if you die.
Some abilities you unlocked by finding some points are now relegated to some kind of shard system where you have a limited amount of slots to equip them to.
Couple extra bugs, I ended up behind some thorns and also I got teleported far back one time, and some things dissapear then re-appear, noticed one instance of that.
Can't really think of anything else other than [spoiler] I wished the owl STAYED DEAD. [/spoiler]

To re-cap:
If you enjoyed the first (om)Ori, don't expect more of the same (om)Ori. This time, it stays closer to generic game convention.
I played on an xbox controller, like in the first game. Due to things being changed around, it took time to re-adjust my muscle memory from the first game. Wish I could rebind it.
Ori gets to wield a bigass hammer.
The story isn't anything special.
The environments and the visuals stay looking good.
Giant toad-frog-thingy.
Some extra platforming gimmicks.

If it's on like 50% sale, or close to the price of the original Ori, then I recommend it, if you don't mind something a bit more mundane this time around gameplay and story-wise.
If your skill is around mine, you could beat it in a single day.
Loved this game. Worth every penny. Can't wait to see if there's more of Ori.

TL:DR A disappointing and mean-spirited cash-in on the brilliant and beautiful first game. Gameplay is more of the same with some bells and whistles, but everything that made the first game exceptional is just gone. If you liked the first game, save your money and your time. There's nothing here except a soulless glowy-cat killing everything on screen. Oh except there's merchants now.

Wow. I have never played a worse and more mishandled sequel in my life. And I played Duke Nukem Forever. I am utterly shocked and overwhelmed by how much of a disappointment this game is after the first one.

So petty stuff first. The graphics optimization is HORRENDOUS. The graphics are identical to the first game, but this one runs considerably worse. Tons of clipping, stuttering, and major sound glitches. My computer is pretty old, but the first one runs flawlessly and there's no apparent reason this game should run any different than the first one, so if they have updated it only shows in the issues, not the product.

The real issue though is the game itself. The first game was a powerful, emotional story with deep messaging about loss, forgiveness, healing trauma both personal and generational and hopefulness in the face of adversity. I cried multiple times. It also had thoughtful gameplay that reinforced the message. This game has a throwaway sappy plot comparable to a Hallmark commercial, and right off the bat, it's just senseless violence against random woodland creatures. Last time they had me healing the forest. Now in the first moments of gameplay I'm burning it down. Before I fought corruption and disease. Now I'm fighting animals in a forest where I don't belong.

It's a shame, because some of the new gameplay elements are really fun, but they're tied to a game that has ZERO respect for itself or the player. Ori and the Blind Forest is a MASTERPIECE. Ori and the Will of the Wisps is just another game in an endless sea of Metroidvanias.

There is absolutely nothing special about this game. It just exists to cash in on a predecessor it's not worthy of. Oh also, there's no more making your own save points, and the wells are WAY further apart than the first game. So make sure you have lots of time on your hands before starting a play session.

Perfect!!!

Even better than the first one. I'm usually not the biggest fan of platform games but this one truly knocks it out of the park. The gameplay is based on smooth series of jumps and skills in a way that makes it so satisfying to play. Now to compare with the first game of the series: 
- for the negative point: the escape sequences are slightly easier than those in The Blind Forest, so they're less thrilling. Instead there are now "spirit trials" (time trials) which are nightmarish, but they're challenging and not compulsory to progress in the game. 
- the map is much bigger. There are so many things to explore, and because of this, new gameplay mechanics such as burrowing in the sand, surviving in the dark etc. 
- there are secondary quests, and this makes the exploring aspect of the game more fulfilling. 
Aside from the gameplay, the game is just gorgeous in its very unique way, a one of a kind artistic direction. The story is beautiful and bittersweet, and the ending really ties up in a way which makes the player feels that they earned it. And of course the score by Gareth Coker is once again absolutely incredible from beginning to end. 
I recommend greatly Ori and the Will of the Wisps, even to people who are reluctant to play platform games.
Play the first one if you haven't, then come back to this game and your life is completed

[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review [/h1]

Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a game developed by Moon Studios GmbH and published by Xbox Game Studios and is the sequel to Ori and the Blind Forest and follows the same metroidvania style of the first game

I almost guarantee that your first playthrough will be very emotional... that's basically all I can say

The game is challenging as if you were playing Dark Souls... the game is not just for admiring the beautiful sights. It is going to test you

Precision is key, especially near the end, where you rarely even have ground to step on before something is going to shoot you

As in every metroidvania you are rewarded for exploring the forest

Ori and the Will of the Wisps, just like the first game, is just gorgeous. The graphics, art style, animations, effects and the music makes you feel just like what the developers intended

It will make you cry during a cutscene, and make you excited and full of adrenaline throughout the game

Ori and the Will of the Wisps is worth every cent, that is if you enjoy metroidvania games

If you do why not give it a try!

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

[b] REVIEW SOURCES: [/b]
[list]
[*] None

It's a lot more polished than the first, they took a page from Hollow Knight and I don't hate it. In fact, I quite like it, this game is just better in every way and more fun than the first one. It is formulaic, but it did it well.

Better exploration with varied rewards to look for and more options for your build. Different combat abilities and play styles to choose from are good.
There's even some great new technical design choices, the map reveal reward is amazing to not need a guide if you miss something. And the built-in autosave slots system is a godsend, especially when there can be some unfair instadeath for harder achievements.

If only all sequels could be like that.
