Ok, so first off, just look at it. If you aren't impressed by looks alone here then I don't know what happened to your eyes.

Beyond the looks, this is also a phenomenal metroidvania. The platforming is fast-paced, well animated, and precise. There's also a really fun combat system that actually takes some skill to master. These two systems also have really fun progression curves. That doesn't leave you too under-or-overpowered at any point. Of course the platforming and combat systems are heavily intertwined and synergistic, and so are their upgrades. 

The music is also very beautiful and compliments the story and visuals very well. Oh also, the story is great. Without barely any spoken words. The story manages to convey feeling that many stories can only dream of (just like the first one).

In short, strong recommendation on this gem.

Ori and the will of the wisps is an incredible sequel to an already enjoyable game- it addresses pretty much all the weaknesses of the first game and builds on it's strengths tremendously, resulting in a fantastic experience.

[b]GRAPHICS[/b]
This was already great in the original but the sequel steps up the quality of the visuals even more- it's honestly absurd how pretty the game looks. The foreground is also well seperated from the background this time so i had no issues understanding the layout of the levels (an issue i had with the previous game)

[b]COMBAT[/b]
Will of the wisps has a more involved combat system than it's predecessor, although it's not something incredibly complex, it's strength lies in how you can use the movement abilities at your disposal to swiftly defeat your foes. It was incredibly enjoyable juggling myself in the air and defeating enemies and bosses this way. 

[b]PLATFORMING[/b]
As you can probably imagine from the points above, this was my favorite part of the game- it's great because things don't take long to get very interesting as you end up getting most of the movement options from the original game relatively early on, so as the game progresses you end up getting loads of great movement abilities to progress through the world

[b]STORY/SOUNDTRACK[/b]
I wasn't really expecting much of a story in this game considering the one in the original was very barebones, but there's a great narrative that ties everything together- I personally prefer the way Hollow Knight does it instead but that doesn't mean i didn't enjoy the story here.

As for the soundtrack, it's really good! Everything fits the moods and tone of the areas you explore and I ended up liking it a lot more than I expected. 

[/b]MISCELLANEOUS STUFF[/b]
The game also has a bunch of other things which I thought were fairly interesting- combat and platforming trials which test your mastery of the game's movement abilities which were pretty enjoyable, a spirit shard system similar to hollow knight's charms which had some great optional abilities in it (although a good chunk of them I didn't care for) and quests for npc's which generally had great dialogue and were very charming. 


Overall, I feel like Will of the Wisps is an incredible metroidvania which takes what people love about the genre but mixes in a lot of fantastic platforming to create something truly wonderful- I'll be thinking about this game for quite some time.

I didn't think there could be a game more beautiful than Ori And The Blind Forest. Then I played this Ori And The Will Of The Wisps.

This game takes everything that made the first Ori game absolutely wonderful and improves it. The graphics are just as pretty, and environments you explore throughout your adventure are even prettier, the story is very moving, and the gameplay is fun and rewarding.

It isn't just a remake of the first Ori, though. I found the puzzles harder, which is, of course, a good thing. The skill tree has been overhauled, and there are new mechanics in place.

Not EVERYTHING is better in the sequel. I did like the original's skill tree better, and I miss the hectic chases through sweeping landscapes like at the end of the Ginso Tree, which have been replaced here with boss battles. They're interesting, and many of the characters have three-dimensional personalities rather than being all good or all bad; that was just something I really enjoyed in the first game and missed in the second one.

Oh, and the music! If the music in Ori And The Blind Forest was gorgeous, then the music here defies description. Gareth Coker has outdone himself and produced my favourite soundtrack ever.

Hats off to Moon Studios. Thank you for making one of my favourite games and then making one that's somehow even better. An easy 10/10.

Strongly recommended if you like the game genre.

[b]Ori and the Will of the Wisps[/b] hit a home run and is a more than worthy sequel to the already fantastic [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/ready2b/recommended/387290]Ori and the Blind Forest[/url]. This sublime experience combines the best of storytelling with delightful action-platforming to create my [b]favorite gaming experience of 2020.[/b]

[u][b]Played with PlayStation 4 controller[/b][/u]

[h1]‚úîÔ∏è[u]Positive:[/u][/h1]
[b][+] Versatile movement in a beautiful metroidvania.[/b] 
As you progress and obtain more abilities (even more than the first game), Ori gradually becomes more monkey-like in their movements, opening up the world for more exploration.  The whole map essentially becomes a delightful playground with hidden nuggets/collectibles in every nook and cranny. Thanks to the responsive controls, the different mechanics can easily be combined with one another to result in fast, agile, and fluid movement - which happens to be the perfect accompaniment for the exciting escape sequences and the thrilling boss fights.

[b][+] Emotional and thrilling storytelling.[/b] 
The incredible writing and direction, supported by the beautiful art and the divine OST makes the whole experience feel like a fairytale brought to life. I wouldn‚Äôt dare to deprive you from such a wonderful story by spoiling it here, so do yourself a favor and get the game. I will openly admit that I cried like a baby multiple times.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2169324939
[b][+] This sequel makes several notable improvements compared to the first game:[/b]
[olist]
[*][b]Auto-save.[/b]
Thank God they removed the manual save system introduced in the first game.

[*][b]New combat system![/b] 
Ori no longer has only the auto-lock on spirit fire attack, which I personally didn‚Äôt care for. Instead you can unlock and upgrade multiple abilities (including melee and ranged attacks), which can be assigned to the X, Y, B (Square, Triangle and Circle for PlayStation) buttons at your leisure. Combat options were lacking in the original so really appreciate this customization upgrade. Personally, I couldn‚Äôt get enough of the giant hammer and Shock Smash upgrade. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2177313275
[*][b]Addition of equipables![/b] 
Similar to the charms in Hollow Knight, Ori can now equip Spirit Shards (equippable items that provide upgrades to you or your abilities). Again, I find that the customization options allow for a more self-tailored experience. I basically had two sets of Spirit Shards that suited my playstyle: one for exploration and one for combat.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2177313407
[*][b]Improvements to the map and teleportation.[/b] 
The map immediately displays any warpstone and collectable you come across without requiring a map upgrade first (as was the case in the original). The map also makes it abundantly clear where the objective is, which areas you have and haven‚Äôt explored yet, and it even shows your latest movement in the form of a dotted line, making it incredibly difficult to get lost or disoriented. Furthermore, you can now teleport to any warpstone from any location, which greatly reduces the necessity for backtracking and helps to keep the pace of the game up. 

[*][b]Addition of side quests is always a blessing.[/b] 
Several great side quests were included in this title but there was one in particular that I really enjoyed: [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2177313569]‚Äúhand to hand‚Äù.[/url] It is essentially a trade sequence quest where you aid the next NPC by providing them with the item the previous NPC gave you. Helping the many creatures felt like I was contributing to the livelihood of the forest.

[*][b]Addition of a main hub.[/b] 
Important NPCs, such as vendors, relocate to the main hub in Wellspring Glades, after you meet them in the wild. Since the land is plagued by corruption and is tyrannized by the evil Shriek, NPCs will immigrate to this safe haven, inadvertently creating a diverse community. By offering resources, such as Gorlek ore and mysterious seeds, found during your journey to Grom (builder) and Tuley (gardener), you are also able to upgrade the main hub until it turns into a lively village. Investing in the community felt rewarding, and encouraged me to search for all the collectable items and help all NPCs.
[/olist]

[b][+] The game provides the necessary tools to unlock everything without relying on external help/guides.[/b]
If collecting everything is your cup of tea (it certainly is mine), then you will probably appreciate this point. There are map upgrades you can either buy or obtain which mark the location of all missing collectables, making them much easier to obtain. Furthermore, if you need to farm for more currency, Spirit Shards can be used to speed up the process; for example, by combining Consume (Enemies have 70% more Life and deal 70% more damage, but drop double currency) with Turmoil (Enemies respawn faster).

[b][+] Perhaps a minor detail but the game automatically pauses if your controller disconnects[/b]. 
Kudos, Moon Studios.

[h1]‚ûñ[u]Neutral:[/u][/h1]
[b][-] I enjoyed playing it so much that finishing it felt bitter-sweet.[/b]
As much as I loved the game, I felt sad knowing that it would be a while before another game would blow me away like this again. I‚Äôm sure most of us have at least one game that we wish we would wipe from our memories and replay again - Ori and the Will of the Wisps falls under this category. [u]Can‚Äôt wait for the next installment![/u]

[h1]üèÖ[u]Verdict:[/u][/h1]
[h1]‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ Marvellous[/h1]
A practically-flawless sequel and a must-have if you enjoyed Ori and the Blind Forest. Highly recommended to everyone else.

[b]Ori and the Will of the Wisps[/b] is a game that I can definitively say is one of the best sequels to a game that I have ever played. It takes everything that was fantastic about the original and continues to play with and incorporate more ideas to expand upon the original. Maps are expanded, movement options increased, new weapons and types of attacks and magic are added. The game feels fantastic to explore and the visuals have grown to be even more beautiful than the original. [i]Moon Studios[/i] truly understands not only what they excel at, but what makes Ori and a game series excel, and with the fluidity of the movement options and how well they understand their own franchise, I cannot wait to see what they produce next.

I'm starting to think it's unfair to compare it to Metroid Prime, but Will of the Wisps has a bigger problem with how easy some of the acquisitions are. It's also more trial-and-error without something equivalent to the Scan Visor, but I guess 2D Metroid games haven't really done that either.

I do still recommend it, because its controls and progression are pretty smooth. It rewards players who take their time to explore, but also if you learn each room's fastest moves/routes.

The games fairly good. But to be frank, I greatly prefer its predecessor. I‚Äôll go over the details for anyone who likes to read~

On the topic of its gameplay, it‚Äôs very easy to compare it to a game like Hollow Knight. Mainly because it very obviously [strike]ripped[/strike] took inspiration from it. Both in its upgrade system and its core gameplay, as well as some enemies and even the bloody map maker. Now I quite liked the orb from the first game, it was unique and gave the games gameplay a nice identity. It also made the game more immersive to some extent. The hit and kite tactics of Hollow Knight work great in Hollow Knight, but they give this game a sort of gamey feel that constantly breaks immersion by reminding you that you‚Äôre exploiting AI as a vital game mechanic, dus reminding you that you are playing a game. That is however my opinion, I am aware that a lot of people like it, and it‚Äôs done well enough to not be eligible for significant criticism.
What is eligible for criticism is that this game was very obviously scraping the bottom of the barrel in terms of its structure. As far as its story goes, it is identical to the first game. From the progression to the locations, even its main antagonists are identical. This games quest system is perhaps the only unique part about it. That and the boss fights. A large problem it has is that a lot of its mechanics are not properly implemented. The most notable being a particular grappling hook ability you get early on in the game. The grappling hook has you latch on to specific surfaces and objects, but the control over it is rather lacking. Grapples are generally proximity based, and not in a good way. The button for this ability also overlaps with another ability, so it is very easy to accidently grapple to something, or to not grapple at all if the proximity reader has a brain fart. Very often, I would try to jump off of an enemy, and because the binding is the same, I would go flying through that enemy to a grappalable area at the edge of the screen. The primary problem here is the fact that this was very obviously intended for a controller, despite having a cursor, you can‚Äôt control what you‚Äôre grappling on to most of the time. And what‚Äôs ironic is that this works very badly on controller as well. I did discover that you can rebind the thing, though be it when it was too late. But even then, the proximity-based hook is still quite horrible. Theres also an upgrade that lets you grapple to enemies, that stops working whenever theres a grappalable surface nearby.
The grappling hook is the most obvious case, but there are other problems like it. Like projectiles automatically locking on to things instead of going where you‚Äôre aiming. That‚Äôs sort of the main problem, this game lacks a degree of polish. It very often feels like it is just the first game with a new combat system slapped on top.
In fact, as outlandish as this might sound, this game gives the impression that the dev team here played Hollow Knight and got so into it that they just decided to make a follow-up to the first Ori game while they were riding the high of the Hollow Knight hype. It certainly is the best reason I have for why the story is basically a Copy/Paste job and the combat is unpolished and lifted from another game.
Now, on the topic of the actual quality of the gameplay, it‚Äôs generally good. The Hollow Knight combat is implemented well enough, though I often wander why the hammer doesn‚Äôt have a backswing when it clearly swings backwards. The platforming is straight out of the first game, and ignoring that atrocious grappling hook, it‚Äôs still as good as it was originally. All the new abilities combined with the new upgrade system also leave room for some fun experimentation and customization.
This is also, ironically, the only game I‚Äôve played that actually shows the one and only advantage of a controller. That being the maneuverability of a thumb stick versus the eight directions you can go in with arrow keys.

As far as functionality goes, I recall this game being bugged as hell on release, glad they fixed it now. Though, since they bothered to reskin the cursor, it would have been nice if they also made it so it didn‚Äôt fly off the screen on dual monitors.

On the topic of the story, without spoiling much, I greatly prefer the near perfect story of the first game. The first games story was simple, but feel-good, the ideal escapism. The ending of this one, to me just felt‚Ä¶ sour‚Ä¶

Aesthetically, the games lovely. In case it wasn‚Äôt obvious.

Lastly, there are the Spirit Races. Their alright, however, personally, they are a #1 on my dislike list, even more than the grappling hook. It‚Äôs not even the fact that their really tight, it‚Äôs mainly the fact that they introduce a rather competitive air to a distinctly uncompetitive game.

[hr][/hr]
Overall, this games only significant problem is its many new mechanics which are half-baked and overlap. Everything else can be chalked up to preference. In my personal preference, I greatly dislike this one. I prefer the first game in every way. That said, my personal opinion does not matter. From an objective standpoint, this game is just fine.
So, for anyone who likes Metroidvania style games, go play Hollow Knight. For anyone who likes top tier platformers with a simple, yet endearing story, try Ori and the Blind Forest. If you like both of those, then you‚Äôll probably like this game too.

Since this game came out I've been trying to find the right words as to how I feel about this game, and why I felt disappointed by this game, despite having loved the first one.
This game doesn't really feel like a "sequel" to Ori and the Blind forest, it feels more like a *very* heavy remaster. This is due to the fact that its the same character but you remove all the abilities from the first game, and then it uses all the same abilities and ideas from the first game, and reworks them and also add a TON of new stuff. The main factor in my disappointment for the game laid in the fact that it just didn't feel very "original" compared to the first one, but looking at it as more of a remaster I can appreciate this game a lot more, because it improves upon the first a FUCK TON.
The combat is 1000x times better, the already pretty visuals became the most stunning 2D visuals I've ever seen in a game, the movement abilities are so fluid and and overall just awesome! The cut scenes are fucking beautiful, the music is great, the level design is way more fun and ineractable. I really liked the funny blue moss and this has the best was area in a video game by FAR.
I believe my main complaint lays in the world building/story of this game. It does have some neat side quests and some lively NPCs and that's cool, but I think where this game really really fails as a metroidvania, is weaving its abilities into the world. Every single ability is just... an ability. They aren't items, they have no story, you just progress through an area and find your next tree and it gives you a movement ability, or you just go up to the charm NPC and buy "Double jump". A lot of the NPCs just felt like they were there to serve their functional purpose rather then feel like their own characters that also have a purpose. It made the whole game just feel like it was made to be as much of a video game as possible without actually feeling like an immersive world, which I think for a metroidvania is very important. That on top of the fact the main story of the game just lacks any sort of depth at. But in the end game-play is what's important, and they did do a pretty good job with that.
There's only a few bosses in this game, and they look really cool, and they're fun but they're nothing super enticing, I never felt the want to go back and do the bosses again, they weren't very hard, I prefer more patternistic type bosses that force you have to learn attacks and how to dodge them so that the fights feel more like a dance (Exactly what the main dev said he was going for but clearly that didn't happen) but these were decent enough.
Another thing I felt, and this isn't necessarily a bad thing, never did I think I'd be complaining about this for a metroidvania, but the amount of movement abilities was a little overwhelming to a point where I think it was a little overboard. Having a whole wheel of movement abilities that you had to equip a few a time of just felt like too much. Maybe I wouldn't feel this way if the map was a lot bigger to actually feel like it was more suited for more different movement combinations and experimentation, with the movement abilities more spaced out and more progression locks.
There was also a ton of people saying this game copied hollow knight, but if you look more into it all of its systems were inspired by many other older games, and even if it did take inspiration from hollow knight it plays FAR differently, has many different abilities, and there was clearly a ton of work put into this game.
Overall a really fun game, amazing improvement from the first game, still $30 for a 20 hour game felt a bit steep. I really hope Moon studios makes another game! (Hopefully a bigger one next time, its really sad to see such awesome mechanics and gameplay go bye so fast)

I said in my Ori and the Blind Forest review how despite it being an amazing game it's not my favourite metroidvania. That's still the case for Ori and the will of the wisps but it's definitely in my top 5 and is an incredible game worthy of your time and a better game than it's predecessor. 

Positives 

I thought Ori and the blind forest was a god looking game but they have managed to top that, this is an incredible looking game with a fantastic artstyle and really good biome diversity, it's insane how good this looks and it will age like wine. 

Again with the OST, they've managed to make something better than before and it's incredible. 

I was worried this game would just be more of the same as the first game when it came to the story and to be fair the start of the game does feel like a retread but I'm thankful this game really comes into it's own. We have a similar but not less impactful plot, many new npcs with side quests and personal stories and a hub that's can be explored for secrets and upgraded. 

It's a much longer game but still doesn't outstay it's welcome. I've played both for roughly the same amount of time but will of the wisps definitely felt a little longer but again didn't outstay it's welcome. 

Combat is better and feels more satisfying, in blind forest it was merely passable but here it is a lot more fun engaging with enemies.
Save system is better this time around, requires less micro management. 

Negatives 

It can feel a but samey with the plot but really for me that's not really an issue especially considering the ending 

Ummm I can't think of anything else, it's that good. 

Conclusion 

This really is a masterpiece and a rare example of a sequel being a massive improvement on the first, this isn't just a gateway game for metroidvanias, this is a gateway game into computer games in general. Whilst it's not my favourite this is an important game of the genre and will be held forever as a timeless classic, just remember to grab the tissues again.

The game is masterful just like its predecessor, however, there are crippling issues that made this game way less enjoyable than the first one. Keep in mind that this review is coming from a KBM perspective, and while my overall opinion of this game is positive, I have highlighted (or 'nitpicked' if you would like to consider it that way) several major issues that I take with this game that greatly contributed to my frustration and detracted from my enjoyment of Ori 2.

Don't get me wrong - Ori and the Will of the Wisps is an absolutely beautifully crafted game, with extraordinary soundtracks, breathtaking graphics, an stunning visuals. The introduction of the weapon system is a breath of fresh air, and the animation in-game is just as captivating. Nevertheless, I cannot help but be disappointed by how much this Hollow Knight-esque combat system detracted from its original format, and that is the platforming aspect with Ori's signature "Bash" at its core.

While working just like it did in the first game, the Bash's charm has lost its entire purpose other than serving the sole goal of solving platforming challenges. In the first game, we had to redirect projectiles as our way to deal with hostile mobs, and and juggle between many projectiles (or one multiple times) in order to solve the platform puzzles. Here, the weapons take up much of the combat, and while it is masterfully animated, there are major issues which detracts from my enjoyment.

Firstly, while the main weapon can lock onto a target and executes the full combo when connecting the first hit, the direction of your attack is determined by the direction you are facing, and not the direction of your mouse. Of course, this is coming from a KBM player, and thus I am sure the system works well for controller players. However, as Ori is, at its core, a platformer, players should be granted some form of combat forgiveness that would make the combat system more fun rather than frustrating to be hit because you are locked into an animation when the attack goes the wrong way.

This auto-target (or lack of) system brings me to my second point, and that is how the game treats your movements - in a game that is overly encumbered by it. There are way too many different movement commands in Ori, and not only does the game not tell you the extent to which you are execute these moves (namely, dashing through dirt platforms - which ultimately is a minor discomfort once learnt, but still), it tries to predict your move by auto selecting objects within range to facilitate the flow of actions. Now, when it works, it works great, however, when it doesn't, it creates major frustrations where the game will pull you in one direction or force you to dash in mid-air when you are trying to dash through a platform or grapple to a different object that your cursor is covering over.

Lastly but not least, the story is decent, but not outstanding, and the game-play pales in comparison to the first game. The section with the bird-riding is short and could have been explored a lot more if not for story purposes, while the platforming difficulty is significantly lacking in creativity as more attention is given to mob-fighting and not solving puzzles. In the end, this creates a shallow Hollow Knight feel with a shadow of Ori's former platforming greatness, as Ori 2 tries to accomplish both but fails to do either one great.

In the end, Ori and the Will of the Wisps is still a great game that I would recommend picking up for anybody who enjoyed the first game. The nostalgia factor is strong, and I applaud its attempt at integrating something new, even though the execution of said system could have been done a lot better in favor of player satisfaction rather than artificial difficulty over poor combat optimization.

I was so excited to finally be able to run this game after playing the Ori and the Blind Forest over a year earlier.  There was no disappointment either.  Ori and the Will of the Wisps is everything a sequel should be: the same foundational gameplay mechanics but expanded and improved upon.

To start, the gameplay was essentially only made better.  While the first game seemed to have a pretty weak combat system only there because it had to be, Will of the Wisps seemed to revamp the entire system and make it actually engaging versus mashing the same attack button over and over again.  The addition of shards made combat a bit more strategic as well, as the player could actually select power-ups to complement their strategy.  The introduction of boss fights and gauntlets further legitimized this new facet.  Overall, this was a huge improvement that added a lot to the game.  What I personally adored about the first game was the creativity that came with movement, and this game certainly improved on that.  It was not just more movement that I liked, but rather each new mechanic immediately tested the player's ability to combine multiple movements to reach the objective.  Boss fights often consisted of "escape platforming" which was great in this game as it was in the first.  Other miscellaneous aspects like quests and optional areas made the game more interesting to explore as well.

There were some minor objections to certain aspects of gameplay...notably just Spirit Trials.  The concept itself is actually really fun and challenges the quick platforming skills players are required to have, but the spike of difficultly between this and the rest of the game is absurd.  I would rather fight the final boss ten times before doing the hardest Spirit Trials.  I am so glad I completed the one in Baur's Reach when I did because I was about two retries from losing my damn mind.  Yes, it gets easier with more practice using movement mechanics, but the spike of difficulty is more what I take issue with.

As with the first game, I did not really care for the story.  It is a bit trite and not really the most compelling, but it does not need to be for me to enjoy the game.  I will compliment the level design this time around.  The distinct areas were beautiful and fun to explore.  The unique gimmicks of each area rarely became tedious.  Finding the NPCs for certain quests gave players a reason to come back.

I have very few complaints about this game.  This is a solid Metroidvania game with enjoyable platforming.  Ori games have definitely been some of my favorite to complete in the past few years.

Loving Ori and the Blind Forest this game is what it needs to be. As beautiful as the first chapter, Ori and the Will of The Wisps is definitely more of the good stuff of the series. Storywise, I cant help the feeling that the previous game was richer. Narrated parts seemed to be less, and though you get to interact with more characters, it doesnt feel to compensate as they get a little monotonous and just utilitary. Quests didnt catch my interest and felt a little like shallow side stories. I get to think that taking what was taken away to make space for this new features was not worth taking.

It may be a detail, but it still bugs me that Shriek is born with the bones when her fathers are regular Owls. Felt like the symbolism was a little forced there.

The rating is still good though, as I feel the game belongs to the outstanding section. The beauty, the creativity of it, the challenge it presents, all of that stuff is there. Its just that the movie part of it felt a little off.

I've been playing video games for close to 20 years now, i grew up on the tail-end of the N64 generation. As I've gotten older than landscape of games has changed dramatically from the old days when there was no processing power and good graphics where essentially block figures with chat bubbles for dialog. I'm not bashing new games, I've come to love games that come out today, but in a different way. 

When I picked up the controller and played Ori for the first time i was instantly transported back 20 years in time. I felt like a kid again that just got home from school and couldn't wait to play the game I was working on. It reminded me why I fell in love with video games all those years ago. To the game devs, thank you. A game hasn't made me feel like this in so long. This game will always hold a special place in my heart.

WOW. I'm not even done with this game yet, but I can wholeheartedly recommend it to everyone. Pick up Blind Forest, then play through this one. You have to, I'm forcing you.

This game takes everything that made Blind Forest great, and dials it up to 11. The visuals are absolutely breathtaking, this is by far the most beautiful game I've ever played, and probably ever will. Unless they make another one. The music is on par with the art. I would buy this game just as an art book. Luckily, it also comes with a fantastic game.

The main improvements this game made over Blind Forest were definitely to the combat, though. The addition of a dodge, as well as much more refined and responsive melee combat instead of spamming a ranged attack all game, is absolutely glorious. Adds so much depth to the gameplay it's silly. 

There is also an added perk system, where you can mix and match different passive abilities you obtain to suit your desired playstyle. 

Just like the first game, the platforming is really tight, and the world is very fun to explore. Only this time, it's significantly bigger, with side quest objectives to give you extra incentive to explore everything. 

100% a must-play video game. This one is getting recommended to everybody I know. Thank you Moon Studios, for releasing this masterpiece. We are undeserving of the effort that went into this title, but I am so glad it happened regardless.

10/10

Although I recommended "Ori and the Blind Forest", I did so while noting a number of minor flaws. I was greatly pleased to find "Ori and the Will of the Wisps" fixed all of my criticisms of the original; this sequel is pretty much perfect. Some ways this improves on the original:

* Much longer. The original took about 12 hours to 100%, yet I'm at 18 hours on this one and am not quite 100%. The speed-running achievement has been bumped up to 4 hours, although I imagine it will be harder to get than the 3 hour achievement from the original. The map is much larger with more areas and variety of environments.

* Legitimately a metroidvania. The original played like a platformer with metroidvania elements, whereas the sequel can honestly be called a metroidvania. The level design is much improved and Ori gains a greater selection of powers for fighting enemies and getting around, on par with Super Metroid's great design.

* More emphasis on combat. Whereas the original didn't have any real boss battles, the sequel has legitimate boss encounters. The run-or-die escape sequences are still there (typically right before the battle), but they're not nearly as painful. The level designers have seriously toned down the instant death traps, with many things that were lethal in the original just causing damage in the sequel.

* The quicksave mechanic has been discarded. In the original you had to manually quicksave constantly to prevent an instant death trap from erasing all of the powerups you had collected since the last save. The sequel automatically saves every screen, which is a serious quality-of-life upgrade. Likewise, the linear upgrade tree has been replaced with shops, providing better customization.

* Better cast, better plot. You interact with an extended cast of characters, most of whom talk and have unique personalities. The race of lemur-like critters are absolutely adorable. Rather than just one god tree, this forest is home to half a dozen giant, wise beast gods. The plot is more bittersweet than the original ‚Äî irreversibly bad things happen frequently and things don't work out perfectly for everyone. The story still isn't all that deep, but it's a suitable fairy tale.

Overall, this is the best metroidvania I have played in a long time. It eclipses "Ori and the Blind Forest" in scope and is well worth the time and money. I absolutely recommend it.

Ori and the Will of the Wisps is the highly anticipated sequel to Ori and the Blind Forest and it builds upon the strong foundation of its predecessor in every way. The game features improved graphics that are even more breathtaking than the first, with detailed environments and character designs that are a joy to behold.

One of the standout features of Ori and the Will of the Wisps is its outstanding boss fights, which are challenging and varied, and require a combination of quick reflexes and strategic thinking to defeat. The game's story is also emotional and impactful, delving deeper into the lore of the world of Nibel and the relationships between its characters.

In terms of gameplay, Ori and the Will of the Wisps builds upon the already incredibly fluid platforming of the first game, with new abilities and power-ups to unlock and a greater emphasis on combat. The controls are responsive and the game is a blast to play, making it a must-play for fans of the side-scrolling genre.

Overall, Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a triumph, surpassing its predecessor in every way and delivering an unforgettable gaming experience. It is a must-play for fans of the series and anyone who appreciates a well-crafted game with beautiful graphics, emotional storytelling, and tight gameplay.

[b]Overall[/b]: As a completionist and a metroidvania fan, this was a decent game. I much preferred the first, because it was much more focused in its direction, but I could not help but notice the ideas picked up from Hollow Knight and similar games. It did round out Ori and the Will of the Wisps to be a better overall journey, and the complexity and timing of some of the stunts you have to pull to loot everything didn't lose out because of it. 

[b]Exploration[/b]: In terms of general traversal and puzzle-solving I think Ori and the Will of the Wisps is fairly challenging. [spoiler]The speed trials are not difficult but some direction (other than an initial cinematic) might have helped, instead of practising till perfect every time, showing just how trial-and-error the whole design philosophy seems to be.[/spoiler] Quest icons being where the player picked them up, instead of showing where to go, is a really strange decision; it threw me off quite a bit sometimes, especially for the [spoiler]Hand to Hand[/spoiler] quest. Honestly some quests would do better to just stay in the text form on the Map screen, without showing a 'false' location. I'm sure I did some puzzles a little more easily than others, and I may have over-complicated others with precision that wasn't necessary, if I'd just looked for the more obvious solution. There was one map bug where I was stuck on 97% in Kwolok's Hollow due to a light orb not showing on the map, once all secrets were revealed. This was solved by simply relaunching the game. Monsters aren't challenging though some can be annoying if you don't have the right abilities and shards chosen (especially those goddamn [spoiler]Hopping Mantises[/spoiler]. 

[b]Boss Fights[/b]: There's value in saying that stepping away from a fight and letting muscle memory and hindsight is a good stance to take, but a really good fight shouldn't require too much guesswork and trial-and-error. In fact, a lot of the bosses felt like that. The checkpoints in a boss fight are generous, and the game doesn't put you far back, but I feel like that's a band aid over a bigger problem. Every chase, every fight, is a huge rush to figure out what you're dealing with and how to deal with it. Overall the boss designs look gorgeous and a well-choreographed one can look cinematic and appealing, but as the player constantly struggling to figure out exactly what the right strategy is, it gets frustrating. A huge part of this is because the visual clues are [b]too[/b] stylised. It's actually the visual design of the final boss fight that completely ruined the entire experience for me. [spoiler]Specifically, in the third phase with Shriek, there's very little to clue you in on what exactly is going on. You have to figure out that Shriek is swooping in on you, that you need to stay airborne, and the billowing smoke on all sides of the screen makes it tough to really keep an eye out on where Ori is and what his position is in relation to the edges of the screen. I could never tell how much space I had to work with. Maybe zooming out and keeping a fixed camera for this fight would be good? Nothing else would need to be changed. The mechanics of the fight certainly are good on paper, in my opinion, but they clash severely with the graphical design, again too stylised for its own good.[/spoiler] 

[b]Story[/b]: No spoilers here, the ending is worth it. Even though every fibre in my body was tingling with rage and anger and my controller was half broken (I'm only that kind of gamer [i]sometimes[/i]...), I actually think they closed out the game really nicely. It's an unexpected twist that's rather gut-wrenching and heart-warming at the same time.

It's just bad. Only good thing about this game is it's graphics. An even then the environments these graphics depict are just kinda 'generic places in real life but in weird colors'. There's not location in this game that I remember just for it's beauty. I only remember locations based off how frustrating they were to get through. I like hard games that challenge my skills and make me feel accomplished when I overcome said challenges, while Ori's challenges are frustrating and I only feel relieved when I 'overcome' them instead of fulfilled. And I feel as if this game is trying way too hard to look beautiful and feel grandiose with it's orchestral score, you can't force greatness and Ori does just that. And in terms of gameplay it feels too floaty, I don't zip from one place to the next while calculating where I need to land. I jump and have to coast and fidget so I land where I need to. And this floatiness becomes most egregious during the game's bosses. The boss between Kwolok especially. This is a very specific comparison but it feels like a boss fight I'd try to make in Mario Maker when I was 10, feels cool and fun to play in my head but when I get around to making it the boss is clunky boring and kills you too much for no fault of your own. It feels like the game as a whole is trying to be like Hollow Knight but it fails in every single way. I don't connect to characters or the game's story. Through and through it's frustrating and when it's not be frustrating this game is overwhelmingly boring. Beware! When watching the game trailer, you will probably think it looks cute and fun. But don't fall for this, they don't show you the difficulties that will drive you insane further in the game. They don't tell you that you will probably give up and uninstall it for your own sanity.

Games should be fun to play, and Ori "is" a fun game at first. But the further you get into it, the more stressful you become. You try over and over to pass each challenge but they get more and more difficult. Up to a point where you're just stuck and can't go any further. That's when I decided to uninstall it.

So if you're looking for a game to relax a little, forget about this one.

Its in a difficult position to judge. All of the component elements of the game are an improvement over the first. Some, like platforming, are only minor improvements while others, most notably combat, are substantial upgrades. But at the same time, the game shifts focus away from its strongest aspects (platforming) towards its relatively weaker ones (combat) which hurts the game in aggregate.

Ultimately, Will of the Wisps still had good stuff to offer, but its best aspects were those it shared with Blind Forest while new additions largely fell flat. It's still a good game overall but I have a moderate preference towards the first.
If you like games like Hollowknight, you'll probably enjoy this too. If you haven't played Hollowknight yet, buy that instead.

[h1] I played it out of boredom BUT... [/h1]

I had this game on my list since they announced it; I wanted to play it, but it was not my priority, so I procrastinated for almost three years.
When I came home for the holidays, I was so bored that I had to play anything, and I chose this.
The art style, the music and the environment are just outstanding, but everyone knows that. Like the first game, "Ori and the Will of the Wisps" can be played just for these factors, and it would not disappoint.
There is a learning curve, but I recommend it to people new to gaming or who want a break from life or work. This title flows very well, even on other platforms.
The story is simple, not perfect, but good enough to enjoy, even if it didn't drive me much. I preferred playing to experience the world instead of living the story.
Exploration was the best aspect of the game for me. The world kept getting bigger and bigger the more I explored it. I got frustrated at some point because I was only concentrating on finishing it, and I almost searched for a guide. Still, it hit me: you must immerse yourself in it. I couldn't find the right way, but it didn't matter; I had other places to explore and discover. Eventually, I found the right way, and it was very satisfying.
Another big satisfying thing is escaping from the bosses/predators. Moving gets smoother and smoother, and being fast is another joy in this awesome game.

That's It; give this game an opportunity you'll not regret.

This game has significantly improved from its predecessor, the Blind Forest. The map is at least two to three times bigger. The gameplay is smooth and polished, and I couldn‚Äôt have imagined the game can be so much better when I first played the Blind Forest. Along with the massive expansion of the map, a lot more content and new mechanics has been added to the game. The character control is less slippery, and Ori feels more in control. News skills for Ori are fun and powerful to play with. It is impressive to see such high quality games in a sequel and I definitely recommend to try this out.

Today the game finally cleared, so I would like to evaluate:
Let's conclude first: it's a great value for money work of art, and yes, I say this game is a work of art

When you enter the game, you will first be attracted by the beautiful scene, each screenshot can be made into high-quality wallpaper, whether it is the background or interactive items are very exquisite, our ori elves are also very cute, and the background music is also outstanding.

In terms of plot, the description is also very clear, the plot is not procrastinating, and there are even scenes that make you can't help but cry, and the two-sided nature of the characters is also reflected, especially the villain will also make you hate but also feel sorry for its experience (further down will be a spoiler haha)

I play the normal mode, and I personally think that the game is moderately difficult and easy to master for novice players. The difficulty of exploration, puzzle solving, parkour, and combat is also well controlled, and if you fail the first attempt and don't finish it, you can pass it with a few practice. The game's save points are designed to be user-friendly, so you won't be forced to start from scratch if you fail at the end. The game's platform jump is also a major feature, and some places may be a little difficult, but you can easily pass it with more practice. The combat system is also very interesting, and by combining different skills and abilities, you can increase the damage effect with less effort.

It is worth mentioning that the cute art style of the game makes it relatively easy to accept insects such as spiders that are usually scary, and will not make people get goosebumps after seeing it haha:)

All in all, this 2D game far exceeded my expectations for a game of its kind and is worth buying

Ignore my listed playtime; I‚Äôve played through the game about four times on Switch.

Anyway, this is my favorite game of all time.

I honestly don‚Äôt even know where to start. The story? The gameplay? The godtier music?

I suppose I‚Äôll start with the story. Spoilers for Blind Forest and the start of Will of the Wisps, obviously.

Continuing from the events of the first game, Ori‚Äôs family has adopted the owl chick Ku into the family. Ku was hatched mostly healthy, but she has one lame wing that prevents her from flying. Ori and Ku are incredibly close, and one day Ori finds one of Kuro‚Äôs feathers. They tie it to Ku‚Äôs lame wing, giving Ku the ability to finally fly. The two go flying out over the ocean, but they get caught in a storm. Ku‚Äôs new feather comes loose, and Ori and Ku get separated, crash-landing in the forest of Niwen. As Ori, you must find a way to reunite with Ku while redtoring balance to the forest of Niwen. Along the way, you‚Äôll meet a colorful cast of characters and take down a variety of threats that have been corrupted by Niwen‚Äôs destabilization.

I‚Äôll grant you that it‚Äôs a pretty basic story, all things considered, but it is no less emotional for it. The first time I played through the game, the ending genuinely made me cry, which is saying a lot, since I was at a point in my life where I didn‚Äôt let myself feel much emotion, positive or negative.

Between story beats, you‚Äôll be exploring the forest of Niwen and its many varied locales. You‚Äôll explore the architecture of the Wellspring, the gorgeous Luma Pools, the panic-inducing Mouldwood Depths, the unsettling Silent Woods, the beautifully glacial Baur‚Äôs Reach, and the scorching Windswept Wastes. Niwen is gorgeous to look at and exhilarating to explore.

While exploring, you‚Äôll get to experience movement and combat that have been completely revamped since the first game. While their basic movement still feels largely the same, floaty but responsive, Ori‚Äôs kit is otherwise largely unrecognizable from before, especially combat. You‚Äôll still be Bashing off of enemies and projectiles, but now you‚Äôve got things like a short Dash, burrowing, and more to aid traversal. And in terms of combat, Sein is gone, replaced by a variety of Spirit weapons, including a sword, hammer, shuriken, javelin, and more. As such, combat is now much snappier and more involved than before, requiring careful spacing and timing while dodging enemy attacks. It‚Äôs a massive improvement, enough that I don‚Äôt think I could ever go back to Blind Forest‚Äôs combat.

All of the above is worthy enough of a purchase on its own, but where Ori and the Will of the Wisps truly shines is in its incredible soundtrack. I‚Äôve never experienced such a masterful soundtrack before or since, even including Blind Forest. The game‚Äôs primary theme has a few key phrases that are woven into every. Single. Song. From start to finish, you‚Äôll be hearing those heavenly chords and vocals incorporated into every theme and boss fight in the most pleasing ways possible. There‚Äôs nothing else quite like it. Even if you don‚Äôt decide to play the game, please, *please* listen to the soundtrack.

I have nothing but praise for this game. If I had the time and wasn‚Äôt worried about spoilers, I could write about Will of the Wisps for hours.

Similar to the first, this game might've been the cause of my depression.

On a serious note, this game was so unbelievably good, just like the first but in my humble opinion, a bit better. The story was very well done and the ending was such a perfect fit for it. I loved the world design and the darker feel that the game had. The best mechanics from the first game were present, along with a variety of new skills and abilities, some of which I loved and some which I struggled with, but I made it through, so it was all fine. The combat system is entirely different from the first game, and while it took some getting used to, I have come to love it, as it gives the game as a whole a much better feel. Another new addition was npcs and side quests, as well as little time trial and combat challenges that allow for upgrades. The variety in skills and upgrades to equip was very refreshing and allowed lots of customization for the experience of the game. The boss fights were spectacular, and the music and art were perfect as always. I definitely recommend this game to anyone who played and enjoyed its predecessor: Ori and the Blind Forest.

For me, Hollow Knight is the paragon of this genre. Ori and the Will of the Wisps is still a pale shadow in comparison with a number of rough edges to the gameplay, but it improves sufficiently compared to Ori and the Blind Forest - primarily in how it has learned from Hollow Knight to inform its own game design - that I feel comfortable recommending it as a fine introduction for less experienced players.

It's also important to make clear that I didn't care for the story. It's just not for me and I was here for the game. The recommendation is in part assuming that if you're looking into the game you like the look of the aesthetics and the narrative.

As a somewhat more experienced player (I wouldn't even say I'm particularly good), I still found it a little too easy to be really satisfying, with my first time playthrough being on hard mode and using spirits to make it harder still (reckless and bounty) and still found my way to 100% without breaking much of a sweat outside of the occasional frustrating platforming section where the mechanics didn't feel right or I couldn't work out where to go next in a rush, which made the bumper number of escape sequences incredibly unwelcome and an easy low light of the game. I'm welcome to believe this is more a skill issue than it being unintuitive, but it made the game less fun either way.

Combat, while still too simplistic, is much better than Blind Forest, and the game even has some honest to god boss fights where you need to pay meaningful attention to attack patterns. The autosaving function could use a little more polish, but it's head and shoulders better than the original. The use of spirits this game has really helped with flexibility over playstyle.

That said, it went a stage too far with abilities, where you can flexibly set a number of powers to three action buttons, but with Attack and Heal being two of those it feels like for the average player most of the game is spent reassigning the third button to whatever action is relevant to the current area, and it feels even more restrictive later as more useful movement actions become available but you can't always keep equipped due to needing to use something else. Given that some controller buttons went unused and one was used solely to change abilities (instead of being in a menu), there are far neater ways this could have been handled.
How can you possibly make a better platformer than this? What Moon Studios has achieved here is nothing short of amazing. A true work of art in my books. Please play this.

First off, let me just say that I do not like games that focus on platforming. However, this game is completely amazing. I don't care if you do or don't like platforming, there is so much to this game and its simply majestic. I never did play the first Ori game, but from what I understand this game is that, but more (especially combat). There is so much progression and very little grinding. You always feel like you're getting new abilities which allow you to explore more areas and finish more puzzles. The puzzles are satisfying and not too hard. You will need some level of basic platforming skills, but take it from me (a non-platformer) when I say that it wasn't too hard. The difficulties in the game mainly adjust the combat aspect of the game, giving enemies and bosses more health and damage. I played on normal, which I suspect is what most people should play on unless they want tougher combat. But the real satisfaction from the game isn't rooted in the combat. Its rooted in constant upgrades, new platforming abilities, beautiful music and the most eye-candy graphics with such a dreamy art style that I have ever seen. I don't think there is very many people who wouldn't enjoy this game, and the reviews for this tell that story. The only thing negative I could say about the game is that I never wanted it to end. It's that good of a game. You owe it to yourself to play this!

This game is awesome in many ways, and while it feels a lot like hollow knight in certain aspects (maps, combat, etc), i don't feel like it hurts the game itself. For one, in this game you don't actually NEED to buy a map, you can construct it yourself no problem. Just explore.

As for the combat mechanics... They are awesome. Slashing away at enemies and hammering those damn purple slime things into oblivion as the cutest damn marshmallow ever just feels... Therapeutic. 

Puzzle-wise, some parts will have you thinking for a while, while others will just be timing-based, some easy and some harder to pull off. The puzzles i think are satisfying in their own way.

As for the story... Oh damn. i still refuse to own the damn end achievement. Call me extreme, whatever. The ending came at me like a cannonball, and i do not appreciate it. I still refuse to consider it canon (Yes i'm overly sensitive at this point, but this is the only game that had me so attached to a character ever... :') )

Conclusion: Awesome game. in (almost) every aspect. well worth the price.

(Previous Review: "For the sake of my own mental health after falling in love with these games and their characters, I will never in a million years consider this game to have happened or be canon in any way. Or at least, not the ending. I have my own headcanon and nothing will change that ever.

The new Fight mechanics and the puzzles are awesome (for me), but... That story, That ending. No.

This game never happened. 

I refuse to bear the "Achievement" of finishing the game.

Game's fun though, You should play it. Just... consider not finishing it.")

Ori and the will of the whisps does what Ori and the blind forest did only more and better.  
More zones, more skills more stuff to do.

It however suffers the sequel syndrome where it's afraid to innovate rather than just enhance. 
Little owlet was perfectly fit to be a playable character with it's own skill set and challenges, keeping game fresh for players  of the first instalment who already saw majority of Ori's moveset there. But nope, she gets relegated to plot device and once again it's Ori-only experience. 

Another small irk is how the game rewards exploration and completion with currency and upgrades to Ori, but nothing in terms of lore. There are not small tidbits of information to be discovered on your own, let alone ground shaking truths that completely change perspective on your endevour and role in the world once learned, not to mention any hidden endings based on your performance. Story wise Ori is a very linear experience.

These do not detract from it being an amazing experience in gameplay and even more so for the eyes, well worth the buy. But greatness could be achieved while it was partially shunned in name of safety.

I am a big fan of the first Ori, it's the only game I ever wrote a review on steam and this one deserves the same! This game took everything that made the first one special, the graphics, the music, the story and the gameplay and made it bigger and better. I recommend this game to everyone, it's not just another generic platformer, It's a unique experience that as amazing combat, music and a very touching story! Experience that as amazing combat, music and a very touching story!

- The visuals are as beautiful and colorful as ever, I caught myself stopping often just to look around and take in the world that studio Moon created. Every different biome of this game is breathtaking and made me want to explore more.

-The music is one of my favorite in gaming, its beautiful, its powerful and its dramatic. Every big moment in this game is made even better by the music that accompanies it. I ain't the type of person who usually puts a lot of attention in music, in games, but these games have such beautiful and impactful songs that have made these games unforgetable ones.

- For the gameplay, I really love that they tried something new, the first game's combat was really good, but this one is even better, more weapons/skills to fight. The combat is fast and impactful, every hit is felt by the player and it as so many way's to fight different foes that I didn't use certain types of skills in my first playthrough. Fair warning I did feel like this game was way harder than the first one, I felt like the boss fights we're rough if you didn't take the time to grind for upgrades.

Beautiful game yet shallow in its combat and strayed-from-story in its gameplay. 

Ori gets an arsenal of weapons. The game just keeps feeding you with new abilities. Sounds nice yet you get no chance to explore---not even a single weapon's limit---before the game gives you something new or before all of a sudden the story just ends. On the other hand, the bow thing just happen to get powerful upgrades yet many other weapons just happen to be neglected and remain what it is the time you bought it. Yeah, weapons you bought are less likely to play a main role in combats. They are the representation of shallowness. They need more reasons to exist in this game. Not to mention the chaotic boss fights. Bosses' moves are not that indicative, and the hitboxes are not that clear. Plus that ori usually stands still to do damage, it's just not a good experience to do a boss like a pro, avoiding attacks and then fight back. Players rather feel, "that hit on me was not fair", "I'm not doing it fairly either. I can beat it by just spamming attack." In the end, it's ambitious to design a combat system like this, but sadly everything feels cheap and shallow.

About gameplay, it's totally disintegrated from the story. Game feels like saving the world, yet the story is about reviving an owl. The game assumes that players will develop a sense of mercy after watching their nicely made intro animation, depicting how ori plays well with the owl. Then will be okay for the game to be entirely not focused on the owl anymore. Most players coming out of a fascinating adventure from luma pools wont remember a bit about their mission of saving an owl. Not only because the game is negligent of this, but also because the player spent too little time with the owl. There is no feelings, no attachment, no pity for the owl just dies.

I completed this game only yesterday, and the one prior only a few days (possibly a week?) before that. MAN was it a journey! Not just because it can be frustratingly difficult to get past some levels without the right abilities without dying multiple times, but the story itself and the atmosphere that accompanies it! Gerard Khalil (aka The Completionist) was right! Much of the story is what you feel when watching the introduction to Pixar's "Up"! Even the antagonist is someone who is relatable! Hell, I cried harder for the final boss than I did for Ku, and that's saying something because Ku is a bright-eyed little owl who is not only Ori's little sister, but also his best friend who went on this journey together!

Does the money-to-time-spent ratio make the game worth it? If you have that mentality, then no. Although I would recommend that the mentality of Trade Prince Gallywix get dropped because as Jynzee from Proper Bird put it: "The length of a game is, on the whole, irrelevant. Especially if the story is compelling enough and the gameplay enjoyable." Though... that might not be her words verbatum.

Would I recommend this game to everyone? Well, it has the thumbs-up symbole, doesn't it? In other words: ABSOLUTELY!!!

I really enjoyed Ori and the Blind Forest, so I was very excited for the Will of the Wisps and it didn't disappoint. Beautiful graphics, a bittersweet storyline and challenging gameplay. When I finished the storyline I wasn't ready to let go of this game so I tried to find all collectibles, complete the side quests and get as many achievements as I could. Amazing game - A 10/10 in it's own right for the pure satisfaction the many challenges this game brings you, from movement to combat to puzzles that make you feel pretty smart.

If you enjoyed the first game, you will LOVE this game. 

As for a Metroidvania game, this game really brings the spirit of the journey, and the trials and tribulations that naturally follow the genre, to life. The adventure is there, you will not find all the collectables easily on a first playthrough although there are elements to help you find said collectables. The combat is fun due to a mix of different abilities (using varying amounts of energy depending on the strength of the ability) and, although the melee combat isn't as naturally platformer-based as Hollow Knight, the combat is unique in its own regard and provides extreme satisfaction when combined with the movement. The movement is much more free flowing than the likes of HK, allowing a significantly higher range of motion during and outside of combat -  I even refrained from unlocking a fast travel option for quite some time, due to enjoying the movement so much.

I played on Hard mode and I will attest that the difficulty was pretty challenging at times, but not hard enough to where it became overly frustrating. There ARE boss battles and as long as you have the patience to learn the move-set, it will be extremely rewarding when you finally succeed (I did all boss fights in approximately 15 mins, on average).
(I also suggest playing on Hard mode if you enjoy challenging platformers - the difficulty is worth it, in my opinion)

I appreciated this game so much that I used all of the abilities at my disposal to zoom around the map for that satisfying 100% profile (which I rarely have the energy to do) as soon as I completed the story. Unlocking an ability and instantly going to certain areas previously unreachable felt extremely fun, truly living up to the excitement the genre can hold.

Highly recommend this game to anybody who loves Metroidvania titles, especially so if you favour them for exploration and movement - the combat is an extremely sweet cherry on top, more fun than competitive.

A powerful but still uniquely adorable protagonist, terrific game mechanics, masterful level design, always fair challenge, engaging soundtrack and beautiful visuals all make Ori an unforgettable experience. This game is another proof that not only are video games art - they just might be the highest form of it.

The visuals of this game are outstanding, everything looks so good. Can‚Äôt think of a better looking 2D game. As a whole Ori is much more focused on platforming than on combat, which isn‚Äôt a negative point since the movement system is amazing. It's immensely fun to jump and dash around with all your abilities. 

There are small bits that can get annoying but it was never anything too bad. One of the games I would recommend to almost anyone. Important to note is also that the difference between the difficulties are quite significant, I played all three of them and it was a very different experience for all of them.

Game becomes hard & frustrating mid way and just no fun at all. It just looks beautiful but gameplay wise, its just too much trial & error & not enjoyable at all. Also, it has a bug that was never fixed where the game window just stays stuck after you exit & either you wait a long time for it to close or kill it via task manager. Not a game breaking bug though as it doesn't effect your save.
If you like to punish yourself playing games like 'Dark Soul', go ahead and buy it but not my style and it just becomes too annoying after mid game to just repeat the same sequence over and over. I play games to enjoy & not punish myself so beware if you are buying this expecting a casual platformer as it is nothing of the sort. The only thing that really stands out are the beautiful visuals which made me want to continue playing but eventually there was no fun to be hard and i just could not see myself unnecessarily grinding the same thing again to again to move ahead.

Will of the Wisps continues the story of Ori beyond the forest of Nibel. You can expect the same fantastically creative area and puzzle design. Will of the Wisps offers a challenge without becoming punishingly difficult; once you unlock all of Ori's core maneuvers, navigating the land of Niwen takes on a Zen-like flow. This second title introduces some wonderful new elements such as side-quests and skill/perk customization. Playing the game with a completionist mindset will grant you a very easy time getting through the final challenge on normal mode.

Like its predecessor, this title introduces a healthy set of multi-dimensional characters (both protagonistic and antagonistic) with very distinct and relatable motivations. The story never feels like an interruption from the game-play and visa versa. It's easy to get sucked in, so be prepared for an emotional conclusion.

Ori is undoubtedly my most favorite title of all time. I am sad that we will likely not see another one, but I am extremely glad that Moon Studios was able to offer this story to us.

I guess I am part of the minority on this game. I have played many platforming metroidvanias in my time, Dead Cells, Blasphemous, Vigil, Bloodstained, even the original SotN and Metroid games but this game has some of the most irritating platforming I have ever experienced in a game. I should be dying more while fighting a boss than trying to traverse a level! Don't get me wrong the game is beautiful. The music mesmerizing. Even the combat seems solid enough, but as soon as I reached that shadow area, lord help me I lost it! The level of skill you need to pass this area, while not knowing exactly where to go is absolutely anger inducing to the highest level. I have died more times in the last hour of playing in that shadow area alone than I did my first few hours of playing a game like Blasphemous from just the platforming alone. Sad really. I really wanted to love this game.

Epic game with outstanding background artwork plus dramatic orchestra. I played the previous title so I could find many improved elements in this title.
The game itself was pretty difficult for me, but still much easier than the former one. I needed whole 2 days to walk through the whole story. It was heartwarming just like the previous title.
Also many action elements are added, many skills and abilities are available in this title. We can pick our favorite skill to build our own favorite fighting style. Some skills are outstandingly useful and maybe that's why I felt this one is much easier than the former title.

If you played the former title and liked the style, perhaps you like this one too. This title inherited almost every single good point from the former one, but added so many new elements that make the gameplay more fun. I can recommend it.
A must play for all kinds of gamers. You won't regret it.

Ori and the Will of the Wisps, basically part 2 of Ori and the Blind Forest, is incredible to put it simply. The soundtrack alone is amazing, but the game play itself is both vibrant and beautiful. The story is very emotional and keeps you engaged with each passing minute. While you can dive right into Will of the Wisps and get caught up pretty easily, If you're like me and like to understand the whole story then I would HIGHLY recommend playing Part 1 (Ori and the Blind Forest: Definitive Edition). The main story has multiple hours of gameplay involved, and when you add in all of the side-quests and obtainable items, there is so much to do! 

I found out about Ori and the Blind Forest when I was on Youtube listening to recommended gaming soundtracks. When the soundtrack for the Blind Forest started playing, I was immediately interested and started my search for the game. I have loved every second of both Blind Forest and Will of the Wisps and I especially love the emotional and heart grabbing soundtrack!!!

Ori and the Will of the Wisps is almost certainly a better game than its predecessor by most objective measures. Everything that made the former great is still here: Bash is back, as satisfying as ever, and the game thankfully knows to return it to you much sooner than the first game did; it comes alongside a host of well-executed improvements to the combat system, and a host of new abilities to complement Bash, with Grapple and Burrow being, for me, the standout additions. 

    The game is also bigger than its predecessor, with more areas, a grander and more expansive soundtrack, and a larger cast of characters; Ori can hardly turn a corner without bumping into some new NPC to bestow a quest upon him. Usually these quests require Ori to travel to some designated location to pick up or deliver a trinket, and some minor reward accompanies it.

    This, for me, is the first sign of cracks in Will of the Wisps‚Äô armor. If I could describe Blind Forest in a single word, I would use ‚Äúelegant‚Äù. It is focused, streamlined, and tightly designed. Will of the Wisps, for all of its mechanical enhancements and improvements, sacrifices this elegance for scope, and in my opinion not usually to any real benefit. The quests are mostly busywork; they provide you with currency, which you might use to buy a shard or a new weapon technique or an upgrade, but you can complete the game while disregarding almost all of these. What do they add to the experience?

    Much is said in the world of game design these days about so-called player expression. ‚ÄúPlay your way!‚Äù the marketing engines howl, but the problem with accommodating multiple styles of play is that each style is diluted as a result. The game cannot run the risk that I haven‚Äôt bought the spirit hammer, or whatever, and so it can never require me to use it. I have a giant palette of paints to choose from and many styles of brushes, but no real painting is demanded of me; what, then, is the paint for?

    Sadly, this same dilution occurs in the structure itself at the midpoint of the game, where Will of the Wisps seems to take a cue from Breath of the Wild and tells you to complete four areas in any order you like. Again, play your way: nice for marketing perhaps, but this means that the previous game‚Äôs elegant progression of Ori‚Äôs abilities cannot be replicated. The game cannot risk that I haven‚Äôt acquired the Burrow move, so I can never be required to use Burrow in any of the other three areas. Gone is the buildup of powers, gone is the designers‚Äô ability to weave them together in increasingly complex and interesting ways; you get a flashlight here, a burrow or a fireball there, and none of it meshes, synergizes, or works together. This, to me, is a colossal missed opportunity, and cuts against what made the first so satisfying from start to finish. The final area of the game provides a token nod to the kind of cumulative design that might have been - but too little, too late.

    The platforming is still pristine, arguably improved from the first game. The combat is undoubtedly more engaging, challenging, and fun, if bloated with excessive options and unnecessary fat. Once again, I think it would be fair to say Will of the Wisps is the better of the two games, and will find a wider audience than the first. But the elegance has been lost in the process, and the focus. It seems a shame. 

4 stars out of 5

I was convinced I was going to love this game after thoroughly enjoying The Blind Forest... sadly I was wrong.

This game is just, messy. You get lost easily, it doesn't feel cohesive, the new focus on combat is a questionable decision at best, and a frustrating, unnecessary, awkwardly cobbled-together addition at worst. The visual design is still gorgeous, but it's undermined by the metroidvania nature of the world causing you to have your eyes stuck to the map more often than the world itself. The music is still good, maybe. I say maybe because, again, I can't even take my time soak it in because I'm too busy wracking my brain trying to figure out where the game wants me to go next, what ability it wants me to find and in what order, and also getting used to a constant onslaught on new abilities that each make the previous one basically obsolete.

It really feels weird leaving a negative review on this franchise, but, I suppose with The Blind Forest they caught lightning in a bottle, and couldn't quite replicate it with the sequel as they bloated out the game with a bunch new unnecessary features taken from other popular games (mostly Hollow Knight, really).

This game has totally flied under the radar for me. Had no idea this was on the making, or even planned. I've had Ori and the blind forest on my wishlist for few years, until last year my dear friend gifted it to me. I started playing, and instantly something happened, that has never happened before. I cried at the beginning cutscene. I do not remember crying at a game EVER prior to that.

Obviously when steam recommended this game to me as it is releasing soon, and since i played the previous game i had to get this game. Me loving owls is a huge +++ So of course i had to buy it.  I recently beat ori and the blind forest, and from there jumped straight into this one when it released on wednesday 11.3.2020.

Ever since i first launched the game the story and happenings in the game have been dwelling in my mind nonstop. The story writers definitely knew how to make a touching story, that stays on your mind, even when you stop playing!

The beginning starts happy and got me crying my eyes out from happiness, I was thinking this will be a happier game than the blind forest, but don't let the happy beginning fool you. The happenings in the game are really heartrending and i cannot count how many times i have cried cause of this game. Big points for the story makers!

Lovely visual style! I found myself gazing on the scenery for multiple times throughout the game.
Really emotional! This game has been a huge rollercoaster of emotions!
I would recommend this game 1000000000000 times over if i could! Best money i have spent ever!

Thank you for reading my rant of a review and hopefully it got you consider buying the game, cause i definitely recommend it from the bottom of my broken heart!!

Thank you also for the developers for making this lovely game! I love your work! Instantly went to the top 3 games of all time for me!

Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a fantastic sequel to the first game that manages to take everything great from the original and make it better. There's a lot of content to unpack here and there's not one bit of it that's bad. 

The Story is simple but sweet and effective. Early on, something big happens that leads to the major catalyst of the story and It's motivational and powerful. The gameplay has evolved since the original in a lot of ways and one of the biggest changes is a Zelda-esque ability system. You will unlock new combat abilities fairly often and each one feels fresh, unique, and powerful compared to others. Levels in this game feel unique compared to each other and it feels great to explore previous areas with new abilities.

All in all, Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a fantastic package that I highly recommend for any Metrioidvania fan.

This review goes for both of the Ori games. These are easily the best 2 games I have played in the past year, if not my entire life. The scenery, music, and character design easily surpass anything I have ever seen in every video game I have ever played, the movement is smooth and rewarding, the platforming is perfectly the right difficulty to provide a fun challenge without being frustrating, and the story is up there with the very best. The only thing that comes a little short is the combat, but luckily it makes up a small enough portion of the game to not make a big difference. 10/10, 100% worth your time and money under any circumstance. If 11/10 was mathematically possible, I would give it to them.
