I am a 43 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Outstanding game. The visuals, the story, the map..... Everything is really nicely made. Backtracking is possible, good. Some new abilities need some getting used to, but nothing that would ruin the experience really. Well, there is one thing, bosses. From start, they aint bad. But the one in Luma pools and every next one after that, they are quite annoying in some way. Hard, yes, but not hardcore. You just need to find a way how to beat them, but even after that it can still take multiple tries to get. Rest of the game tho is very chill, even relaxing imo. Shame that the last cutscene made making another game in series quite.....literally impossible. But i wont spoil, well at least try not to. But i think the they intended this from the start, so its fine. Im just sad. I really enjoyed all 3 Ori games a lot, and I am gonna miss them. Would recommend playing Blind forest one first because of the story, definitive edition or normal, that doesnt really matter, but the story will make sense much more if you do play them. Nontheless, definitely a 9,5/10 for me.

This is one of the best games I have ever played. The animation is top tier and it's multiple layers combined with 3d animation just adds to the experience! Finally, the soundtrack for each area is amazing, the places with more life are filled with up-beat music and the more dangerous and eerie places like the Silent Forest have a matching tune. All in all, this is one of the best games I have ever played.

Ori is an amazing game that is incredibly visually pleasing, fun to play, and has a nice story.

That's it really.
The gameplay is incredible, and the OST and art is very pretty, and the story works perfectly fine with all those systems in check. But it's not an artpiece, and that's okay. 
The Ori games are games that make me feel hollow after finishing them not because the story was so amazing, or the music was so beautiful, or the art was so compelling, but because the gameplay was of a quality you will so rarely find. It flows, it's incredible, it's tight and fun and easy to understand. The challenges are challenging and the platforming is genuinely fun.

So, I highly recommend it if you want an amazing gameplay experience with a pleasing story and artstyle to go with it. I would not recommend it if you're looking for something genuinely artistic or unique in what it offers.

While outshadowed by other metroidvanias in terms of combat, it has the best soundtrack of any video game I have played, with equally breathtaking scenery and platforming coupled with an emotional story that kept me engaged all the way through the end. Also, the side quests have a surprising amount of depth, rewarding those who pay attention to small details in the dialogue, with small-scale changes in the world after the completion of said quest to reward people who look for them. In the amazing art style hide loveable side characters that make the large world feel that much more alive.
Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a true sequel to Ori and the Blind Forest, and you all should play this game if you're into metroidvania.

This game is Amazing. Its everything you want in a Metroidvania. The unusual thing is to get a story that isn't contrived in this format, which makes the game feel linear. This game is legitimately open-ended. The game sets up a very clear path to the end but you are not really beholden to that except for a few instances in the narrative. It also manages not to lose the strength and interest of the story in the mess that you can make of traversing the game. Its Brilliant. Not every big enemy encounter is a boss fight and boss fights are actual fights instead of a string of action sequences. This game needs a sequel.

Unsurprisingly, another beautifully made Ori game. There was a good mixture of combat and platformer challenges, and I finally switched to a controller instead of a keyboard and that made it much easier. The first time I played Ori and the Blind Forest, I died over 2,000 times. The second time I played Ori and the Blind Forest, I died roughly 980 times. The first time I played Ori and the Will of the Wisps I died 460 times. I am working towards completing all of the map, just because I don't really want to be done with this game just yet.

The ending did make me cry though, so like...just a warning. But that's okay, because it really showed me how much thought and care everyone in the studio has put into both Ori games. The Ori series are games that I recommend to everyone that asks me for suggestions for what to play.

This game has my heart and is one of the most impressive platformers I have played yet. As with the previous Ori game, the art and soundtrack are both astoundingly beautiful and create a cute yet awe-inspiring atmosphere. The story is very good, and while some may not like it, it is a cohesive story that tracks well from Ori and the Blind Forest. The devs added just enough new mechanics to the game to make it fun and interesting, however I don't believe it is too much of a change to alter the gameplay style from OBF. Yes, there are changes to how some abilities can be used (some have to be equipped in a charm-like fashion while others are permanent) but overall this did not negatively affect my gameplay with the exception of some early on confusion in Luma Pools. All of the other elements of the game however, quickly overshadow this minor inconvenience and made the experience of Ori and the Will of the Wisps a 10/10 for me. Absolutely recommend this to anyone who enjoys a cute platformer and/or enjoyed playing through Ori and the Blind Forest or Hollowknight (some of the mechanics in this game are more similar to Hollowknight than Blind Forest).

Love this game!
The story is engaging and enjoyable, it had me invested in the characters within the first couple minutes of play. 
The music was phenomenal! A fantastic score by Gareth Coker and his team that captured the essence of each location and story points. It was stuck in my head for weeks on end, and I didn't even mind.
The escape sequences/boss fights were a bit harder than the rest of the game, but not to the level of Ori: Blind Forest. I wish there was a better way to record/save progress in some of the longer fights.
The collectibles and puzzles were highly enjoyable, the sense of accomplishment was great every time I figured out something.
All the characters were immediately personable and fun, despite little dialogue and limited sound effects. The moki in particular were adorable and funny, and provided some much-needed comic relief through dialogue.

My score: 4.5/5 (just because I personally don't like platformer games, otherwise it would be a 5/5)

Love it. Such a beautiful game and first one where I got all the achievements. Wish it had something to do after you did everything again other than explore and replay the whole game. In my opinion the game is super easy even in hard mode just how I like. Side quests are short if you know what you doing and as far as I remember, all of them are fetch quests but aren't tedious at all cause I'm so agile as Ori that those side missions would be done in 2 minutes or less. 

The game has a great saving system that I took full advantage of when getting some of these achievements otherwise it would be an unfair request us to do some of the things on the achievement list. This game actually needs is a bit of a better combat system however. I use a total of 5/12 of the tools earned through progression and purchasing in-game but the rest feel pointless to include. Useless end game tools include the light burst and feather (this only includes its ability to blow wind to increase the flames on a fire or blow a stack  of leaves away to see what is underneath that becomes like a used key in a resident evil game that you cant get rid of, not the gliding aspect). 
The most useless tools in the game are the butterflies and shuriken that I dont even want to waste my time talking about. Get rid of this or tweak it to be of any use in the game. The same goes for many of the shards.

Anyway to sum it up, great game, amazing graphics, system menu and saving system is outstanding (just a personal preference) but the game lacks much meaning and purpose after the main story is complete. 
Theres also a lot of dumb shards, abilities and weapon(s) that dont help in terms of gameplay. (I know people hate comparing the two but still hollow knight made better use of charms, abilities and their weapon(). Sorry but overall it still wins and yes, this game does feel like it copied those features too much without thinking of its impact on the gameplay. Straight up facts, dont hate me for it)

In an industry where there is a sea of absolute garbage pieces of "entertainment" that reigns supreme with manipulative and addicting systems that only exist to get you to spend more and more money, there are masterpieces below the surface. This is one of those masterpieces. One that proves that games are art.

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]Factor[/th]
        [th]Rating[/th]
	[th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Gameplay Loop[/td]
        [td]7[/td]
	[td]Simply an incredible game, while also being one of the most "AAA" indie games I've played - in both good ways and bad. On one hand, the platforming and combat are both fun and polished, with some fun escape sequences and boss fights peppered in, which, while not being as challenging as the previous game, feel smoother and more cinematic because they get done in like a try or two. On the other hand, the "adding MOAARR to Ori" philosophy permeates other factors, as there's all kinds of NPC questlines where one gives you something you use in another then another and so on, a Hollow Knight-y map guy and charms/notches, ores you use to build the hub town, seeds you use to grow trees, spirit trials and all kinds of shit that def has that "AAA" bloaty feel. So while there's a lot of content, there's also a certain lack of direction,, and both the 'increments' def show how the team that worked on this was 4 times larger than the previous game. The sense of exploration sorta gets replaced by a checklist of quests when you open the map. But well, apart from those things and some stuff I'll mention later - it still is a solid AF zero-filler campaign, and the presentation is second to none. I usually take forever to finish games to avoid any fatigue, and this took me like 3 non-stop days, which def says something.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Narrative[/td]
        [td]5[/td]
	[td]Might be sort of a hot take, but I've not been too huge a fan of the stories in Ori games. While I love the Disney fairy-tale type beat - they do come across as a little surface-level-emotion-shortcut in a weird way - where everything is wholesome and everyone has cute googly eyes, but that's where the depth very much ends. The story of this part had pretty much the same structure as the previous, as you keep 'freeing the forest from corruption' by tacking different areas - and considering the ending, it def feels like a sound conclusion. What really makes me give it a 5 here doe is that, unlike the previous one which only had a respectable amount of breaks, 'Wisps' halts the gameplay one too many times for random exposition dumps, drawn-out NPC questlines, and "you can only walk forward" sections - in true AAA fashion.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Visuals[/td]
        [td]10[/td]
	[td]Need I say anything here?[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Mechanics[/td]
        [td]10[/td]
	[td]If there's one aspect in which Wisps completely outdoes Blind Forest - it's gotta be the mechanics. The previous one already had the innovative bash mechanic. This time around we got dash, sand burrow, water dash, launch and a literal grappling hook - combining into one of the most satisfying traversal I've done in any video game. And hey, the combat's not too comprehensive or anything, but it def achieves that cinematic feeling it's going for.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Challenge[/td]
        [td]7[/td]
	[td]While I certainly found the game MUCH easier to play than the first Ori, with the escape sequences and boss fights all being 1-2 tries, hence it not feeling "too" challenging or deep - but it def results in flashy, epic, satisfying sequences that work in the game's favor. Just wish they'd at least pushed the boundaries of the platforming mechanics in this one as they did in the first game. It felt slightly underdeveloped despite being extremely fun for what we did get.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Variety[/td]
        [td]9[/td]
	[td]Literally no complaints here. While there's an argument to be made that there's "too much" in way of quests, redundant abilities, and collectibles - the variety in movement mechanics and crisp pacing with the set pieces and boss fights are incredible.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Mapping[/td]
        [td]7[/td]
	[td]The level design is great and utilizes the abilities etc. really well. The "world" design feels kinda eh to me though. It all felt like video game levels with trees placed just because of game reasons alone, rather than making too much sense as a cohesive world that would exist outside of its purpose of serving me. The map you buy literally marks everything from the area's ability down to breakable floors - removing any residual sense of adventure IMO. Despite being a nonlinear go your way experience - it felt strangely "on a track" all the time. But I guess that's what this game needed, and works for its crisp length.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Sound[/td]
        [td]8[/td]
	[td]There is a common bug I encountered where cutscenes/setpieces would cause an annoying ass buzzing noise. Tried many online solutions, finally worked when I disabled the spatial sound, until several hours in which lead to a pretty shoddy audio experience. The music is great, even doe I feel the most memorable track I heard was actually the same one from Ori 1 lol.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Interface[/td]
        [td]6[/td]
	[td]While the UI etc. was clean and all - I do have a gripe. The control scheme was borderline atrocious. You are  responsible for assigning abilities to either X, Y or B from the wheel. Now, X will pretty much be the sword. Y will be the ability you need in the level possibly, or maybe the hammer - and heal on the B. So it pretty much cockblocks you out of almost any experimentation. And in certain area, I actually found myself having to go to the wheel, then assign an ability, then do it, then change it back when I needed something else. Extremely annoying, when they simply had the entire dpad just lying there unsused. Stuff like the heal, and other passive-y abilities could easily be put there.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Pricing & Performance[/td]
        [td]8[/td]
	[td]I'd go an easy 5 on Pricing and 3 on Performance. There's def random frame freezes even when the FPS was 100+ during certain set pieces etc. and I've heard of others having the issue as well. And of course there's the audio issues I described.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Replay Value [/td]
        [td]8[/td]
	[td]I can def see myself going back to the game for the sheer fun of the movement and mechanics alone.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

[b]SCORE : 7.7/10[/b]

[b] Pros [/b] :-
* Controls are great, offers a fluid gameplay
* Gorgeous art style/ graphics
* Great soundtrack
* Nice story

[b] Cons [/b] :-
* I observed around 20 crashes during my first 10 hours of playtime. There were no frame rate drops though. Later, I didn't observe much crashes, maybe because of an update? But the CPU utilisation  and temperature were pretty high for a 2D platformer, so not sure whether it is well optimized. 
* [i] Nitpick [/i]: If you want 100% achievements, you will start hating this game. There is an achievement for which you should not die in the entire game. I mean, this is a platformer, dying is pretty much unavoidable in some boss chase sequences and some parts. Due to bad luck, sometimes, ledge detection / object grab might not work as expected and you may die, then, you have to start a new game to again try for this achievement, just to die again and start a new game again. Steam says only 1% have this achievement, out of which most of them cheated using achievement cheat softwares or downloading completed save files. Achievements should provide a reasonable challenge rather than being frustrating and borderline impossible. 

  That being said, this is one of the best platformers out there. Even if you are a 100% achievement enthusiast, I would still recommend this game.

Sure, it's pretty fun to play, the level design is fine, movement feels good, blah blah blah. It's not a poorly made game. But I kind of just dislike it, and‚Ä¶ can I say‚Ä¶ distrust it‚Ä¶? In the way that I distrust everything that is extremely clean and polished in a way seemingly intended to be maximally palatable to the widest audience. Even the cheap and hackneyed ways the story tugs at heartstrings feels manipulative, disingenuous, *marketable*. In short, it's Pixaresque. It's funny (that's not quite the right word, is it?) that I felt this way before it was revealed that Moon Studios was oozing with workplace abuses. I am not trying to say everyone involved in making the Ori games was some kind of sleazebag, but it's not surprising that a studio piloted by certain sleazebags would produce the video game equivalent of a Radio Friendly Unit Shifter. It's a game that feels designed to sell copies and be awarded 9/10s by tasteless media presences. It's a bland game with boring ideas. When you play this game you'll feel like the lab rat who presses its button and waits for the inevitable treat. When you play this game you'll feel like maybe you're having a pretty good time, maybe you'll even sometimes try to slightly convince yourself it deserves all its deeply undeserved praise, but a faint voice in your head will be whispering Stop. Life is short. Don't you need something from the grocery store?

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I loved this game, beginning to end, start to finish. I have to say, this game is one of the best games I've ever played in my life. Truly a masterpiece in the video gaming industry. I would highly recommend purchasing this game and its predecessor as soon as you can. It's worth way more than what you pay for it, and it tells a wonderful tale of family, friendship, helping others, and, in the end, sacrifice. I would immediately buy another Ori project should Moon Studios come out with another one. I wholeheartedly believe that this game earns the right to be game of the year, and if not this, then the first game. Everything about it is so wonderful and rich and beautiful that words cannot express my feelings about it properly. I only hope that I may one day create a tale as compelling and story driven as Ori, characters so rich in lore and excellence that I could achieve even a fraction of what the Ori franchise has given to this world.

Thank you, Moon Studios, for all your hard work in this excellent game. I don't think I'll be forgetting it soon, if ever. You are one of the few people who can actually make me cry, and one of the few I can truly appraise without seeing any faults in your creations. I can only hope that one day, I may achieve something even slightly comparable to what you have made. Until then though, I'll be taking my leave.

And to you, Ori, who now lives on as the protector of Niwen and the giver of its life... I hope you're happy where you are. I'm sad your final adventure had to take place outside your home, but at least you've done something truly remarkable in your world. You are a wonderful spirit, and you truly deserve the title of a hero.

What I expected: Hollow knight 4 kidz.
What I got: A phanominal and respectable metroidvania with the most polished platforming in it's genre.
Ori knows both it's strong points and it's weak points, and uses them both at the just right amounts to stitch together a simply impressive gameplay loop that would at first seem simple on the surface.
While Ori isn't hard, it's also not the walk in the park I anticipated and provides an adequete challenge for any player regardless of skill level.
The story is pretty uninspired however, and is simply there as an obligation to show off it's gameplay polish, artstyle, and soundtrack.
Ori seems to fly under alot of radars when compare to other giants in it's weight class, and deserves to be emphatically recommended to your friends and family after a playthrough.

I really enjoyed the original Ori and the Blind Forest. The sequel blew my expectations out of the water.

While it took a bit of a step towards expectations, with more combat elements and traditional boss fights, it still keeps a lot of what made it unique, including a chase scene at the end of each level and the return of the iconic Bash mechanic (this time much earlier in the game).

The graphics are gorgeous, especially the prevalent water effects. The music helps set the mood, ranging from quiet and melancholy to intense and predatory. The world you are exploring is large and the environments vary greatly. The story starts where the original left off, immediately leaves you crushed (as Ori is want to do), and continues taking you on a rollercoaster from start to finish.

Controlling Ori is a delight, with movement being highly animated, quick and fluid as you dodge and weave through your environment. The combat system is a lot more robust than the original, but not as strong as in some games of the same genre (it‚Äôs still not the focus). The platforming, the powers you obtain, exploration and collectibles, are all abundant and wonderful.

If you‚Äôre a fan of metroidvanias with more than crunchy combat, this is probably one of the best ones out there, and honestly one of the best games I have played.

awesomes üëç

It's taken quite some time for me to express how much this game means to me.

I'm nearly finished with my second playthrough, and it feels like I'm playing the game for the first time all over again. The environment and music never fail to make me feel calm. The puzzles are a great blend of being largely unclear with JUST enough of a hint that I rarely get stumped yet always feel like a genius every time I solve them. The story has kept me glued to my screen just as much as the first time I read it. Ori's diverse move set means that it NEVER gets boring to fend off enemies or find new ways to traverse the stages. I always feel good every time I complete a side quest that helps improve the lives of the people I meet.

This game has earned its spot as my favourite of all time, and it's gonna take a LOT for it to be dethroned anytime soon.

Game lacked cohesiveness. Yes, it is beautiful. Yes, it generally does a decent job. But it was not a satisfying experience, neither in narrative or gameplay. The various components did not fit well together. I also heard of the very unwholesome stuff happening behind the scenes in the game's development, and playing the game with that knowledge I just couldn't shake off a grim sorrowful feeling. I don't know. Either way, the game leaves me feeling empty. I'm awestruck by the effort put in, and the ideas on their own, but structurally, on a larger scale, there is something broken here. It feels bad man.

Okay, has fixed some of the annoyances of the first game. The controls are better, the escapes are slightly less awful. The only thing that has gotten worse is the save system which is now out of our control. Usually it is fine, but sometimes especially while backtracking places that are more complicated in reverse, the autosaves can be in bad places. Even had the game save on an autodeath location, but fortunately it automatically reverted to the save before after 3 instadeaths.

Edit: Changed to not recommended. The chase sequences do get utterly stupid later, and unlike the previous game there is no way to adjust the difficulty once a game is started. One "Challenge" didn't even allow me to exit it, I had to look up a walkthrough since guessing which normally non relevant background graphics suddenly had impact on the gameplay took too long.

This game was a true masterpiece and is now in my list of top ever games played. For a 2D platformer, I've never felt more immersed as if in a 3D world. The graphics are beautiful, smooth, and just gorgeous to look at - as well as the animations are absolutely fluid. With no words spoken, you 100% feel the words and emotions of each character.

The music feels like millions were spent on a Hollywood Blockbuster soundtrack, and they totally mirror the feeling and special moments in the game. The storytelling in the animations, the graphics, and the music are absolutely perfectly spot-on. 

As well as a huge number of achievements, and collectables, I spent about 20hrs on the game, and could easily start fresh and play it again. 

I will definitely be following this developer and music composer, as well as getting the other Ori games in the series. 

A totally mesmerising and stunning gaming experience I won't forget.

Finished it yesterday. It hurts me becouse I enjoyed a lot of things in game, probably if not for aticlimactic ending I wouldn't felt so negative towards it. I really don't want adventures of ori as a franchise to go in that direction, that would be huge waste. 
I do not advise against buying it, especialy on sale, since its still a good game. Good game but a bad sequel to something that to me felt unique and magical.
The graphics are beautiful, level design is great, I enjoyed the hell out of platforming through this charming world again. The story is alright, not great tho, feels like microwaved something from last week. There were moments in it that were just plain wrong like e.g. when badly placed controller shakes ruined immersion of game ending cutscenes. But the main offender for me is combat.

Oh I know that fighting feels better in this one, but its only as far as controlling ori is polished, so you can do a lot of cool stuff. On the other hand I don't vibe with the idea of this nimble forest spirit slashing bugs to pieces with a sword, or why is he even wielding arsenal of weapons invented by mankind in firs place. It still feels good to slash, smash and shoot, couse moves are responsive and well animated. But really, due to enemies being boring and sometimes a little spongy, I think I had fun only when doing environmental kills.
And then there are enemies... I cant stress this enough how hopeless they seemed against ori's new abilities. With them having only 2 or 3 moves at best, and not being particularly aggresive, I rarely felt in danger. A lot of times on my playthrough gorleks just stopped moving entirely, becoming passive punching bags. Overall, this combat system got stale pretty fast.
So here is one idea how to make it way better: if only devs focused on environmental kills. Ori was never defenseless, his platforming skills can be frickin deadly. I'm saying lets add more trickery like a feather that blows enemies away, maybe a different kind of lasso that would allow player to switch places with enemy etc. And then make fights as a combat puzzles, in which you have to think quick how to get rid of mobs using  only environment with fun (and not stupidly violent) mechanics. People who designed levels are so talented, I think they may create a masterpiece if core mechanics of the game will be more connected to their ideas. For now, I cant say what was the idea behind will of wisps, its eighter just a mess, or ripoff of mechanics trending in all modern metroidvanias...

Bosses... are awful. They are dissapoiinting, softly speaking. The thing with games that rely on combat experience like dark souls or hollow knight is that they are trying to make you feel like youre fighting for real. Enemies are aggresive, they have decent move pools (with moves that usualy make sense for what those enemies are), and their attacks are aimed at you (very fucking important). In will of wisps bosses are just patterns, with animations slapped on them like no one cares. Why the hell owl is shooting fucking laser from her mouth, and always doing so from left to right, no matter where player is. Why every time its about to hit the ground with claws, there is an air flowing from it to make sure you wont get hit.
Telegraphing attacks is fine if done properly (like e.g. in Furi) but oh god these bosses are like uncle playing with children, inventing some flashy epic punches that are aimed at air, so the kid will think hes agile or whatever. Only chases were cool, and maybe the last phase of final boss (but that also felt wrong how he went from cruelly boring to very challenging only for one or two minutes).

Another dissapointment was that little sister from boxart was barely itegrated into gameplay. Seing trailer and all I was really hoping that this will be the biggeest mixup - ori is not alone anymore, means new moves, completely different way of experiencing this world. Well no, you controll her in only one level if I remember correctly, and she is lame. She cant do nothing that ori can with feather, so this level is just being slightly slower and more limited.

Also, why did they drop one of the most interesting mechanics from blind forest - placing chekpoints as a skill, that costs mana? I was good, felt unique to me, I liked it a lot, it made me way more invested in game. It was also corresponding with worldbiulding. So they had something going for their first game, which was creative and absolutely working, I consider it amongst the best mechanics like showering in blood in ultrakill for example, .... and they dropped it.

I think this game is a mixture of Donkey Kong and Trine, if that makes any sense. And I say this with good intentions, because I love DK and I like Trine. Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a nice follow-up to the first game, with a nice storyline to give a sequence to its predecessor. It starts with a great familiar atmosphere that, then, develops to an original plot in that beautiful natural mythical ambience we saw in the first one. There are some new mechanics but, in general, the playstyle remains the same. The soundtrack continues to be amazing and relaxing at the same time. To me, the new characters are the most interesting new feature presented in this game, being well designed and having defined personality traits that make the story more epic and charming.

Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a fantastic game! Its wonderful graphics, animation, music, gameplay and story make it one of the best Metroidvania games ever.
What I like in Ori is that it's more diverse and not battle-heavy like Hollow Knight (which I enjoy equally) - the escape sequences and Spirit Trials were a big fun! Being easier and shorter than Hollow Knight makes it a good choice too.
This year I played Ori and the Blind Forest, Hollow Knight, Axiom Verge, Guacamelee, and now Ori and the Will of the Wisps - I'm happy and at the same time sad that I already finished some of the best Metroidvania games.
I highly recommend Ori and the WIll of the Wisps to every gamer.

[b]Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a fitting sequel to the originally acclaimed Ori and the Blind Forest. A simple but emotional story complements the beautiful visuals and responsive controls for an overall wholesome experience.[/b]

A classic 2D-style platformer without 3D elements (other than foreground and background visual elements) provides an accessible experience that scales well for new and experienced metroidvania fans alike. Exploration and progression is naturally restricted via unlockable abilities, and backtracking is required should you wish to go for completion. This is good however, as you're able to traverse areas in increasingly novel ways and have a different experience the second of even fifth time around.

Collectibles are strewn throughout, and while seemingly impossible to find at first, follow a pattern and reveal themselves more readily throughout the game. Even for non-completionists, by the end of the game finding all such items and abilities is not a difficult task, as the developers allow you to choose if you need assistance in finding such things, or would rather seek them out without assistance.

Graphics are flat-out amazing, and load times are non-existent if you aren't utilizing fast travel. Fully equipped to make any HDR monitor look great, the diversity of color palettes and lighting intensity is something you'll stop to admire. Dynamic background and foreground elements sway and move with player movements and are deeply integrated with the player area. As wish most graphics this good, you may encounter micro-stutters when loading seams are brought into play, but the dynamic resolution setting built into the game can alleviate this to an extent where it is not a concern except in a few select areas.

Hi,

I have played this entirely on steam desk after playing the Blind forest. It worked fine no issues (apart from very few crashes) but i found the need to mod the A button with the  second function the LEFT Bumper. This function works like the original but if you are on a wooden beam you cannot get down so you need to remove the extra function temporarily  in order to do so. I found this a minor inconvenience. If someone has a better solution please let me know.  I puled down the TDP to 5 W and i was able to get many ours of play at around 40fps without any lag issues.

*There are no spoilers in this review*

I've read good reviews for this side scroller and was not disappointed!  I played on normal difficulty with 90% completion (forgot to hand in last of rebuilding quest before finishing game), and didn't do speed run because it is purely optional.

Pro:
+Beautiful graphics
+Amazing stories
+Great character build options
+Steady progressions

Con:
-On the easy side
-Gameplay was not that long
-Once you've completed the game, not much replayability; I'm ok with that actually
-Would have loved to have alternate endings, I can think of 3
